Text: Tuesday, 30 March 1971

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: H o n . Sir Willia m Aston)

Speaker: NA
Text: took thc chair at 2.30 p.m., and read

Speaker: NA
Text: prayers.

Speaker: NA
Text: Division of Murray-Retur n to Writ

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: I have received a return

Speaker: NA
Text: to the writ which I issued on 15th February

Speaker: NA
Text: f o r the election of a member to serve f o r the

Speaker: NA
Text: electoral division of Murray in the State

Speaker: NA
Text: of Victoria to fill the vacancy caused by the

Speaker: NA
Text: resignation of the Right Honourable Sir

Speaker: NA
Text: John MCEwen. By the endorsement on the

Speaker: NA
Text: writ it is certified that Edward Bruce Lloyd

Speaker: NA
Text: has been elected.

Speaker: NA
Text: New Member Sworn

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Edward Bruce Lloyd was introduced

Speaker: NA
Text: and made and subscribed the oath of

Speaker: NA
Text: allegiance as member f o r the division of

Speaker: NA
Text: Murray , Victoria.

Speaker: Mr WHITTORN
Text: I present the follow-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing petition:

Speaker: NA
Text: To the honourable The Speaker and Members of

Speaker: NA
Text: the House of Representatives in Parliament assem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bled. The humble petition of the residents of the

Speaker: NA
Text: State of Victoria respectfully sheweth:

Speaker: NA
Text: 1. The red kangaroo and many other mar-

Speaker: NA
Text: supials, through shooting for commercial

Speaker: NA
Text: purposes, have been reduced to a numerical

Speaker: NA
Text: level where their survival is in jeopardy.

Speaker: NA
Text: 2. None of the Australian States have sufficient

Speaker: NA
Text: wardens to detect and apprehend people

Speaker: NA
Text: breaking the laws in existence in each State,

Speaker: NA
Text: and in such a vast country only uniform

Speaker: NA
Text: laws and a complete cessation of com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mercialisation can ensure the survival of our

Speaker: NA
Text: national emblem.

Speaker: NA
Text: 3. It is an indisputable fact that no natural

Speaker: NA
Text: resource can withstand hunting on such a

Speaker: NA
Text: ' concentrated scale, unless some provision is

Speaker: NA
Text: made for its future.

Speaker: NA
Text: We, your petitioners, therefore humbly pray that:

Speaker: NA
Text: The export of all kangaroo products be banned

Speaker: NA
Text: immediately and the Commonwealth Government

Speaker: NA
Text: make a serious appraisal of its responsibility in the

Speaker: NA
Text: matter to ensure the survival of tbe kangaroo.

Speaker: NA
Text: And, your petitioners, as in duty bound will ever

Speaker: NA
Text: pray.

Speaker: NA
Text: Petition received and read.

Speaker: NA
Text: Kangaroos

Speaker: Mr FOX
Text: I present the following

Speaker: NA
Text: petition:

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of

Speaker: NA
Text: the House of Representatives in Parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: assembled. The humble petition of residents of

Speaker: NA
Text: the State of Victoria respectfully sheweth:

Speaker: NA
Text: ELECTORAL That because of uncontrolled shooting for

Speaker: NA
Text: commercial purposes, the population of kangaroos,

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly the big red species is now so low,

Speaker: NA
Text: that they may become extinct.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are insufficient wardens in any State of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commonwealth to detect or apprehend those

Speaker: NA
Text: who break the inadequate laws which exist. As a

Speaker: NA
Text: tourist attraction, the kangaroo is a permanent

Speaker: NA
Text: source of revenue to this country.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is an indisputable fact that no species can

Speaker: NA
Text: withstand hunting on such a scale, when there is

Speaker: NA
Text: no provision being made for its future. We, your

Speaker: NA
Text: petitioners, therefore humbly pray, that:

Speaker: NA
Text: The export of kangaroo products be banned

Speaker: NA
Text: immediately, and the Commonwealth Government

Speaker: NA
Text: take the necessary steps to have all wildlife in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia brought under its control.

Speaker: NA
Text: Only a complete cessation of killing for com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mercial purposes can save surviving kangaroos.

Speaker: NA
Text: And your petitioners, therefore, as in duly bound,

Speaker: NA
Text: will ever pray. ..

Speaker: NA
Text: Petition received and read.

Speaker: NA
Text: PETITIONS

Speaker: NA
Text: Aboriginals '

Speaker: NA
Text: Kangaroos

Speaker: Mr KIRWAN
Text: I present the following

Speaker: NA
Text: petition:

Speaker: NA
Text: To the honourable the Speaker and .Members of

Speaker: NA
Text: the House of Representatives in Parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: assembled. The petition of the undersigned citi-

Speaker: NA
Text: zens of Australia respectfully showeth:

Speaker: NA
Text: That there is a crisis in Aboriginal Welfare in

Speaker: NA
Text: the South West Land Division of Western Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia resulting from a population -explosion, poor

Speaker: NA
Text: housing and hygiene and unemployment and

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployability.

Speaker: NA
Text: That there is a need to phase out Native

Speaker: NA
Text: Reserves in the South West Land Division of

Speaker: NA
Text: Western Australia over the next three years.

Speaker: NA
Text: That town housing must be provided for all

Speaker: NA
Text: Aboriginal families where the bread winner has

Speaker: NA
Text: permanent employment or an age or invalid pen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion entitlement.

Speaker: NA
Text: That such housing must be supported by the

Speaker: NA
Text: appointment of permanent 'Home-maker'

Speaker: NA
Text: assistance in the ratio of one home-maker to

Speaker: NA
Text: every eight houses or part thereof.

Speaker: NA
Text: That incentives of housing, 'home-maker'

Speaker: NA
Text: services and training facilities must be created

Speaker: NA
Text: in centres of potential employment for those who

Speaker: NA
Text: are currently unemployed or unemployable.

Speaker: NA
Text: That insufficient State or Federal assistance has

Speaker: NA
Text: been made available to meet these requirements.

Speaker: NA
Text: That adequate finance to meet these require-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments can only be provided by the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth government.

Speaker: NA
Text: Your petitioners most humbly pray that the

Speaker: NA
Text: House of Representatives in Parliament assembled

Speaker: NA
Text: will give earnest consideration to this most vita]

Speaker: NA
Text: matter.

Speaker: NA
Text: And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever

Speaker: NA
Text: pray.

Speaker: NA
Text: Petition received and read.

Speaker: NA

Text: and Treasury. He will also answer questions

Text: on matters for which the Department of

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Daly- I ask leave of the House to

Speaker: Mr MCMAHON
Text: No .

Speaker: NA
Text: TARIFF ON TRUCK PARTS

Speaker: Mr WHITLAM
Text: I ask the Miuister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Trade ancl Industry a question. I apprehend

Speaker: NA
Text: that the honourable gentleman will not

Speaker: NA
Text: again tell me, as he did on Wednesday

Speaker: NA
Text: week, that he is not aware of the decision

Speaker: NA
Text: to cancel tariff concessions on a wide range

Speaker: NA
Text: of commercial vehicle components from

Speaker: NA
Text: 1st October next. I also apprehend that he

Speaker: NA
Text: will remember that the Minister for Cus-

Speaker: NA
Text: toms and Excise thereupon said that a sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: mission wns presently before Cabinet.

Speaker: NA
Text: Accordingly, I ask again: What is the justi-

Speaker: NA
Text: fication in the present circumstances for a

Speaker: NA
Text: decision which' willso obviously increase

Speaker: NA
Text: the costs of all those who use trucks in

Speaker: NA
Text: primary production, in manufacturing

Speaker: NA
Text: enterprises and in transport businesses?

Speaker: Mr ANTHONY
Text: Th e other day when I

Speaker: NA
Text: answered a question on this matter from

Speaker: NA
Text: the Leader of the Opposition 1 was

Speaker: NA
Text: unaware of the facts. It is true that there

Speaker: NA
Text: had been discussions between the Depart-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of Customs ancl Excise and thc

Speaker: NA
Text: Department of Trade and Industry, and

Speaker: NA
Text: indeed a note had been prepared for mc

Speaker: NA
Text: but I had not seen it at that stage. Thc

Speaker: NA
Text: matter has been raised in the House by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister for Customs and Excise.

Speaker: NA
Text: He gave an answer detailing his responsi-

Speaker: NA
Text: bilities in the application of by-law and the

Speaker: NA
Text: cancellation of any by-law that might

Speaker: NA
Text: exist. What he said was proper and correct.

Speaker: NA
Text: The matter now has been studied by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government and it has endorsed the action

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Minister for Customs and Excise.

Speaker: NA
Text: The action is merely the application of thc

Speaker: NA
Text: long-standing principle that rales of

Speaker: NA
Text: decided by the Tariff Board should applv

Speaker: NA
Text: to protected - Australian produced goods

Speaker: NA
Text: when they are a suitable equivalent for

Speaker: NA
Text: goods produced overseas and when they are

Speaker: NA
Text: reasonably available.. The effect of the

Speaker: NA
Text: cellation of tbe by-law on costs of finished

Speaker: NA
Text: commercial vehicles has yet to be seen.

Speaker: NA
Text: However I would like to quote what the

Speaker: NA
Text: Tariff Board had to say in 1965. I t said:

Speaker: NA
Text: . . . The performance of at least one manu-

Speaker: NA
Text: facturer suggests that a significantly higher local

Speaker: NA
Text: content may not mean appreciably higher costs of

Speaker: NA
Text: commercial vehicle production where large

Speaker: NA
Text: volumes of production are concerned.

Speaker: NA
Text: The following extract from the same report

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Tariff Board is also worth noting:

Speaker: NA
Text: When the problem is examined in more detail at a

Speaker: NA
Text: later date the Board would expect to see that the

Speaker: NA
Text: local contents of commercial vehicles as normally

Speaker: NA
Text: sold by vehicle builders have been raised to higher

Speaker: NA
Text: levels.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is very hard to determine at this early

Speaker: NA
Text: stage just what the effects of additional

Speaker: NA
Text: costs will be, but one must say that the

Speaker: NA
Text: action by the Minister for Customs and

Speaker: NA
Text: Excise is consistent with established policy.

Speaker: NA
Text: It was taken after detailed examination by

Speaker: NA
Text: his Department and in consultation with Ihe

Speaker: NA
Text: industry, with both the component manu-

Speaker: NA
Text: facturers and the users of those components.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is in conformity with the expressed

Speaker: NA
Text: expectations of the Tariff Board and, as I

Speaker: NA
Text: mentioned previously, has been endorsed

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Government.

Speaker: NA
Text: RURAL DIVERSIFICATION

Speaker: Mr MCLEAY
Text: I ask the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Trade and Industry whether his attention

Speaker: NA
Text: has been drawn to the recent debate in

Speaker: NA
Text: this House on the loan to the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Wheat Board and the references to his own

Speaker: NA
Text: speech when opening the Agricultural Out-

Speaker: NA
Text: look Conference this year. Is any action

Speaker: NA
Text: being taken by the Minister's Department,

Speaker: NA
Text: the departments of agriculture in the States

Speaker: NA
Text: or the Commonwealth Scientific and In-

Speaker: NA
Text: dustrial Research Organisation to conduct

Speaker: NA
Text: research into and encourage wheat farmers

Speaker: NA
Text: to diversify and to undertake the produc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion and export of other grain? Has the

Speaker: NA
Text: production of edible oil seed, for which

Speaker: NA
Text: there is a world-wide demand and which is

Speaker: NA
Text: imported into Australia in considerable

Speaker: NA
Text: quantities, even been subjected to such an

Speaker: NA
Text: analysis?

Speaker: Mr ANTHONY
Text: Wit h the application

Speaker: NA
Text: duty of the wheat quotas there is indeed

Speaker: NA
Text: encouragement to wheat growers to try to

Speaker: NA
Text: diversify and engage in other types of crop-

Speaker: NA
Text: ping. I did mention at the Agricultural

Speaker: NA
Text: Outlook Conference that there were oppor-

Speaker: NA
Text: cantunities for diversification although they

Speaker: NA
Text: were not limitless. Certainly in the oil seed

Speaker: NA
Text: industry there is a chance for further

Speaker: NA
Text: development and expansion but this must

Speaker: NA
Text: be measured against the domestic require-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments and the economic attractiveness of

Speaker: NA
Text: producing such crops. However, at the

Speaker: NA
Text: moment there does appear to be sufficient

Speaker: NA
Text: local demand to require further production.

Speaker: NA
Text: I know the area for oil seed production has

Speaker: NA
Text: increased quite dramatically in recent years.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is now up to something like 400,000

Speaker: NA
Text: acres, but it appears there is still further

Speaker: NA
Text: room for increased production.

Speaker: NA
Text: TRI-SERVICE ACADEMY

Speaker: Mr BARNARD
Text: 1 ask the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Defence whether his Department's submis-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion on the establishment of a tri-Service

Speaker: NA
Text: academy has been redrafted as directed by

Speaker: NA
Text: Cabinet last October? If so, when will

Speaker: NA
Text: revised plans for the college be approved?

Speaker: NA
Text: Is the Minister now satisfied that abolition

Speaker: NA
Text: of the present system of individual Service

Speaker: NA
Text: colleges is justified? Can he give the House

Speaker: NA
Text: any estimate of savings involved in integrat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the 3 colleges? Will the delay in approv-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the proposal mean that the academy

Speaker: NA
Text: will not be ready to take officer cadets from

Speaker: NA
Text: all 3 Services until 1975 or later?

Speaker: Mr GORTON
Text: A s indicated previously,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government required more informa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, more detailed information, and a good

Speaker: NA
Text: deal more facts presented to it before it felt

Speaker: NA
Text: it could have proper grounds to take a

Speaker: NA
Text: decision that a tri-Service college should

Speaker: NA
Text: be established. Consequently the Depart-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of Defence was asked to make further

Speaker: NA
Text: studies and put forward a further submis-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion to Cabinet. I understand that those

Speaker: NA
Text: studies have been undertaken and that a

Speaker: NA
Text: submission, which has not yet come to me,

Speaker: NA
Text: has been virtually prepared. That is all I can

Speaker: NA
Text: tell the honourable member because I can-

Speaker: NA
Text: not tell him whether or not it will be

Speaker: NA
Text: approved by Cabinet when it does come

Speaker: NA
Text: before the Government.

Speaker: NA
Text: WINE EXCISE

Speaker: Mr GILES
Text: I address my question to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister for Primary Industry. May I

Speaker: NA
Text: say initially that I am grateful to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister and to the Minister for Customs

Speaker: NA
Text: and Excise for the consideration they have

Speaker: NA
Text: shown me in respect of the matter I am

Speaker: NA
Text: about to mention. Has the Minister noticed

Speaker: NA
Text: any trends in recent wine sales relating to

Speaker: NA
Text: price sensitivity on the one hand and

Speaker: NA
Text: flagon sales on the other? Has he

Speaker: NA
Text: been able to discern, from any of his

Speaker: NA
Text: inquiries, any significance in these figures?

Speaker: NA
Text: Finally, in thanking him for the considera-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion shown to me personally recently I ask:

Speaker: NA
Text: Is there any further suggestion he can make

Speaker: NA
Text: about improving the Government's know-

Speaker: NA
Text: ledge of these matters of great concern to

Speaker: NA
Text: the wine industry?

Speaker: Mr SINCLAIR
Text: I know that the hon-

Speaker: NA
Text: ourable gentleman has expressed on fre-

Speaker: NA
Text: quent occasions in this House and in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Murray Valley basin, for which he exer-

Speaker: NA
Text: cises quite a deal of electoral'responsibility,

Speaker: NA
Text: his concern at the impact of excise on wine

Speaker: NA
Text: and grape producers insofar as it apparently

Speaker: NA
Text: has, in the minds of those who are grow-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers, affected their markets and fheir returns.

Speaker: NA
Text: Similarly I know that other honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: members, particularly fhe'honourable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber for Mallee, have raised this question

Speaker: NA
Text: with me. 1 am happy to advise the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member that since he last asked me

Speaker: NA
Text: a question in this House, further inquiries

Speaker: NA
Text: have been made about the'impact of excise

Speaker: NA
Text: on producers' returns and it seems statisti-

Speaker: NA
Text: cally there is no direct evidence that there

Speaker: NA
Text: has been any reduction in outlets this year

Speaker: NA
Text: compared with the same period last year.

Speaker: NA
Text: From a study that my colleague the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Customs and Excise initiated

Speaker: NA
Text: in respect of some 10 wine producers, I

Speaker: NA
Text: am told that there is'still'no direct evi-

Speaker: NA
Text: dence available of an impact. 'Four of these

Speaker: NA
Text: wine producers are co-operatives. I am told

Speaker: NA
Text: that in respect of one'of'them it appears

Speaker: NA
Text: that the direct problem I s ' a marketing

Speaker: NA
Text: problem rather than a problem consequen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tial on the imposition of excise. The Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister has been in contact with me and

Speaker: NA
Text: has expressed his concern that there should

Speaker: NA
Text: be full knowledge of the circumstances

Speaker: NA
Text: surrounding the impact of excise and, as

Speaker: NA
Text: a result, an interdepartmental committee

Speaker: NA
Text: will be constituted to inquire into all the

Speaker: NA
Text: circumstances surrounding the excise and

Speaker: NA
Text: its application. I am sure that the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member's representations will be kept

Speaker: NA
Text: closely in mind.

Speaker: NA
Text: HOSPITAL. COSTS

Speaker: Mr KENNEDY
Text: I address a question lo

Speaker: NA
Text: the Prime Minister. Has the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth bed subsidy to hospitals declined as

Speaker: NA
Text: a percentage of all hospital costs since the

Text: employed at the Morwell. open cut did take

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: missioner Brack to increase..their site allow-

Text: situation are these: As a consequence of

Text: this irresponsible action by a .very small

Speaker: NA
Text: number of men in one of this country's

Speaker: NA
Text: major industrial plants some 200,000

Speaker: NA
Text: workers were thrown out, of work with a

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Text: when unions are unable to discipline effec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tively their members. I might say that Com-

Text: tion by the Federated Engine Drivers ancl

Speaker: NA
Text: Firemen's Association, and that hearing will

Speaker: NA
Text: take place shortly.

Speaker: NA
Text: Finally. I might observe that d uring

Speaker: NA
Text: course of 1970 the number of industrial the situation.

Speaker: NA
Text: disputes in this country was some 2,700,

Speaker: NA
Text: which was an increase of 35 per cent over

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: point of order. I draw your attention to

Speaker: NA
Text: standing order 144 which states in part:

Speaker: NA
Text: Questions should not contain-

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) statements of facts or names of persons

Speaker: NA
Text: unless they are strictly necessary to render

Speaker: NA
Text: the question intelligible and can be authen-

Speaker: NA
Text: ticated;

Speaker: NA
Text: I would ask you to ask the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member to authenticate his statement.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: I think that the ques-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion asked by the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Cowper shows no disrespect or disregard

Speaker: NA
Text: for the honourable member for Riverina.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honourable member for Cowper is

Speaker: NA
Text: referring to a statement. Can he vouch for

Speaker: NA
Text: the accuracy of that statement?

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Robinson-Yes , Mr Speaker.

Speaker: Mr ANTHONY
Text: I did see in a paper a

Speaker: NA
Text: report of a speech made by the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Riverina at, I think, the Uni-

Speaker: NA
Text: versity of Sydney or the University of New

Speaker: NA
Text: South Wales. I doubt whether the depart-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments concerned-th e Department of

Speaker: NA
Text: Health or the Department of Customs and

Speaker: NA
Text: Excise-woul d think that this was a reflec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion on them because, really, this gentle-

Speaker: NA
Text: man makes so many statements on so

Speaker: NA
Text: many things that they just take that state-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment for granted.

Speaker: NA
Text: PERSONAL EXPLANATION

Speaker: Mr GRASSBY
Text: Riverina)- Mr Speaker,

Speaker: NA
Text: I wish to make a personal explanation.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Doe s the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member claim to have been misrepre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sented?

Speaker: Mr GRASSBY
Text: Yes . I claim to have

Speaker: NA
Text: been misrepresented on 2 counts. In phras-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing his question to the Minister for Trade

Speaker: NA
Text: and Industry the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Cowper indicated that I had made criti-

Speaker: NA
Text: cisms of trading and quarantine arrange-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments in relation to an undefined matter

Speaker: NA
Text: which I could not quite identify by the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member's question. In answer

Speaker: NA
Text: to this question the Minister for Trade and

Speaker: NA
Text: Industry was inaccurate in the only thing

Speaker: NA
Text: he said. The Minister mixed up his univer-

Speaker: NA
Text: sities. I made some comments at the Uni-

Speaker: NA
Text: versity of New England. I would commend

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister to study what is happening

Speaker: NA
Text: and perhaps to ask me in future before

Speaker: NA
Text: speculating about something which I was

Speaker: NA
Text: reported to have said.

Speaker: NA
Text: CROWN OF THORNS STARFISH

Speaker: Mr MCMAHON
Text: Lowe-Prim e Minister)

Speaker: NA
Text: - I lay on the table the report of the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mittee appointed by the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: and Queensland Governments on the prob-

Speaker: NA
Text: lem of the Crown of Thorns Starfish.

Speaker: NA
Text: Motion (by Mr Swartz)-b y leave-

Speaker: NA
Text: agreed to:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this House, in accordance with the provi-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions of the Parliamentary Papers Act 1908-63,

Speaker: NA
Text: authorises the publication of the report of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee on the problem of the Crown of

Speaker: NA
Text: Thorns Starfish, and secondly that the paper be

Speaker: NA
Text: printed.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ministerial Statement

Speaker: Mr MCMAHON
Text: Lowe-Prim e Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter)-b y leave-O n 7th April 1970 the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government announced to the House the

Speaker: NA
Text: membership of a joint committee estab-

Speaker: NA
Text: lished by the Commonwealth and Queens-

Speaker: NA
Text: land to investigate the problem of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Crown of Thorns Starfish on the Great

Speaker: NA
Text: Barrier Reef. The committee comprised:

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth Nominees

Speaker: NA
Text: Professor R. J. Walsh, O.B.E., Professor

Speaker: NA
Text: of Human Genetics at the University of

Speaker: NA
Text: New South Wales (Chairman).

Speaker: NA
Text: Professor W. G. H. Maxwell, Associate

Speaker: NA
Text: Professor of Geology at the University of

Speaker: NA
Text: Sydney.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr D. J. Tranter, Senior Research Sci-

Speaker: NA
Text: entist, Division of Fisheries and Oceanog-

Speaker: NA
Text: raphy, Commonwealth Scientific and

Speaker: NA
Text: Industrial Research Organisation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland Nominees

Speaker: NA
Text: Dr J. M. Harvey, Director-General ot

Speaker: NA
Text: Primary Industries.

Speaker: NA
Text: Professor J. M. Thomson, Professor of

Speaker: NA
Text: Zoology at the Queensland University.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr C. L. Harris, of the Department of

Speaker: NA
Text: Primary Industries.

Speaker: NA
Text: The anouncement of the committee's

Speaker: NA
Text: membership followed agreement reached

Speaker: NA
Text: on 29th January 1970 by both Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments that such a committee be established

Speaker: NA
Text: and that it should be financed on a dollar

Speaker: NA
Text: for dollar basis by each Government.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am pleased to be able to tel] the

Speaker: NA
Text: House that on last Thursday, 25th March,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Chairman of the Committee, Professor

Speaker: NA
Text: Walsh, reported to me on the results of

Speaker: NA
Text: the committee's work. In view of the

Speaker: NA
Text: importance of the report and of the wide-

Speaker: NA
Text: spread interest which has been taken in its

Speaker: NA
Text: progress I arranged for Cabinet to consider

Speaker: NA
Text: the report today and for the report to be

Speaker: NA
Text: tabled so that honourable members will be

Speaker: NA
Text: able to inform themselves fully of its con-

Speaker: NA
Text: clusions, and of the reasons underlying

Speaker: NA
Text: these conclusions. Honourable members

Speaker: NA
Text: will be aware of the very deep concern

Speaker: NA
Text: which is felt by many about the possibility

Speaker: NA
Text: of destruction to the Great Barrier Reef by

Speaker: NA
Text: the crown of thorns starfish. This concern

Speaker: NA
Text: has been deepened for many by the belief

Speaker: NA
Text: that perhaps complete destruction of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Reef was inevitable unless early Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment action was taken. Some have sug-

Speaker: NA
Text: gested that it may now be too late to save

Speaker: NA
Text: the Reef. It is therefore pertinent to draw

Speaker: NA
Text: to honourable members' attention a refer-

Speaker: NA
Text: ence in the Committee's report to articles

Speaker: NA
Text: in the Press and in semi-technical journals

Speaker: NA
Text: on the starfish as being either repetitive

Speaker: NA
Text: presentation of eye-catching speculations or

Speaker: NA
Text: exaggerations of .the limited facts available.

Speaker: NA
Text: Some of the confusion appears to have

Speaker: NA
Text: occurred because the available methods of

Speaker: NA
Text: estimating population densities of the

Speaker: NA
Text: starfish are rather crude. Extrapolations

Speaker: NA
Text: from these results are not reliable and are

Speaker: NA
Text: of doubtful value. Also overlooked has

Speaker: NA
Text: been the fact that the publishedfiguresof

Speaker: NA
Text: the proportion of dead coral on reefs

Speaker: NA
Text: attacked by the starfish have included an

Speaker: NA
Text: estimated 10 to 50 per cent of corals killed

Speaker: NA
Text: by other means-suc h deaths being a nor-

Speaker: NA
Text: mal state of affairs. Analogies have been

Speaker: NA
Text: drawn between the action which had been

Speaker: NA
Text: taken on Guam and the situation in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Great Barrier Reef. On Guam, teams of

Speaker: NA
Text: divers were used to combat the starfish.

Speaker: NA
Text: Some felt that a similar operation should

Speaker: NA
Text: be mounted on the Great Barrier Reef.

Speaker: NA
Text: Such suggestions overlooked the fact that

Speaker: NA
Text: Guam has a comparatively simple reef sur-

Speaker: NA
Text: rounding it, around which the starfish were

Speaker: NA
Text: said to move, limited on one side by the

Speaker: NA
Text: island beach and on the other by the sea

Speaker: NA
Text: proper, whereas the Great Barrier Reef is

Speaker: NA
Text: of a size and a complexity which makes

Speaker: NA
Text: similar generalised action to that taken on

Speaker: NA
Text: Guam ineffective.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the light of the wide differences

Speaker: NA
Text: authoritative opinion as to the threat,

Speaker: NA
Text: any, which the starfish posed to the Great

Speaker: NA
Text: Barrier Reef the Commonwealth considered

Speaker: NA
Text: it necessary to obtain more facts before

Speaker: NA
Text: any further action was taken to deal

Speaker: NA
Text: with the starfish beyond that already

Speaker: NA
Text: set in train by the Queensland Government

Speaker: NA
Text: and to which reference is made in the

Speaker: NA
Text: committee's report. The Great Barrier

Speaker: NA
Text: Reef is perhaps the most complex eco-

Speaker: NA
Text: system known to man and many experts

Speaker: NA
Text: considered that it would have been irre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sponsible for generalised action to be taken

Speaker: NA
Text: before knowing the likely consequences of

Speaker: NA
Text: such action upon the chain of life which

Speaker: NA
Text: comprises the Reef as we know it. As to

Speaker: NA
Text: the results of the committee's investiga-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions, the committee has found that:

Speaker: NA
Text: the crown of thorns starfish does not

Speaker: NA
Text: constitute a threat to the Great Barrier

Speaker: NA
Text: Reef as a whole;

Speaker: NA
Text: there is no danger of substantial erosion

Speaker: NA
Text: of the physical structure of the reef; and

Speaker: NA
Text: there is no threat to the Queensland

Speaker: NA
Text: coastline or ports.

Speaker: NA
Text: The entire living cover, or even a large

Speaker: NA
Text: proportion of the coral cover, of the Reef

Speaker: NA
Text: will not disappear as a result of the crown

Speaker: NA
Text: of thorns starfish. Whilst there has been

Speaker: NA
Text: extensive damage to coral because of the

Speaker: NA
Text: starfish, serious damage is limited. Re-

Speaker: NA
Text: colonisation and regeneration of coral have

Speaker: NA
Text: occurred on all reefs examined by the

Speaker: NA
Text: committee. The committee has not been

Speaker: NA
Text: able to determine whether the high density

Speaker: NA
Text: of starfish in some areas is a unique or a

Speaker: NA
Text: cyclical phenomenon but it appears more

Speaker: NA
Text: likely to be an episodic event which may

Speaker: NA
Text: have occurred previously.

Speaker: NA
Text: The committee refers to the fact that

Speaker: NA
Text: the feeding by the crown of thorns on liv-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing coral constitutes, in the long term, part

Speaker: NA
Text: of the reef building process, whereby dead

Speaker: NA
Text: material is consolidated in order to provide

Speaker: NA
Text: the platform necessary for ihe Reef's con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tinued growth. Tourist activity has not

Speaker: NA
Text: declined as a result of the starfish damage.

Speaker: NA
Text: The committee cannot give the reason for

Speaker: NA
Text: the population increase of crown of thorns

Speaker: NA
Text: starfish in some areas. It reports that the

Speaker: NA
Text: hypothesis that local collection of triton

Speaker: NA
Text: shells has reduced predator pressure on the

Speaker: NA
Text: starfish has not been substantiated nor has

Speaker: NA
Text: the hypothesis that pesticides and other

Speaker: NA
Text: organic chemicals may have been causal.

Speaker: NA
Text: of The committee believes that there is no

Speaker: NA
Text: if need to attempt to reduce Ihe population

Speaker: NA
Text: of the crown of thorns starfish throughout

Speaker: NA
Text: the whole of the Great Barrier Reef at the

Speaker: NA
Text: present time. It does not dispute that cer-

Speaker: NA
Text: tain reefs or portion of reefs having social

Speaker: NA
Text: or commercial importance may be pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: tected by manual destruction of accessible

Speaker: NA
Text: starfish.

Speaker: NA
Text: The committee finds that present

Speaker: NA
Text: ledge of reef ecology is inadequate to

Speaker: NA
Text: assess fully present and future problems

Speaker: NA
Text: concerning the crown of thorns starfish

Speaker: NA
Text: and related matters. It therefore suggests

Speaker: NA
Text: programme of research involving continued

Speaker: NA
Text: monitoring of starfish population; research

Speaker: NA
Text: into reef ecology, with particular attention

Speaker: NA
Text: to the biology of the starfish and corals;

Speaker: NA
Text: and experiments in local control of

Speaker: NA
Text: starfish. To achieve this programme it

Speaker: NA
Text: recommends that a sum of money of the

Speaker: NA
Text: order of $90,000 to $120,000 be provided

Speaker: NA
Text: in the first year to allow such research

Speaker: NA
Text: that the sum provided be increased proplay

Speaker: NA
Text: gressively in each of the second and third

Speaker: NA
Text: years at which time there would be a

Speaker: NA
Text: review in the light of the operation of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Institute of Marine Science.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have already mentioned, Cabinet has

Speaker: NA
Text: considered the recommendations of the

Speaker: NA
Text: committee. I am pleased to be able to say

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Government agrees with the recthis

Speaker: NA
Text: ommendations of the committee. I have

Speaker: NA
Text: been in touch with the Queensland Premier

Speaker: NA
Text: and we have agreed that $45,000 be the

Speaker: NA
Text: allocated on a matching basis by each

Speaker: NA
Text: Government for research projects recomquate

Speaker: NA
Text: mended in its first year by an advisory

Speaker: NA
Text: committee. The advisory committee would

Speaker: NA
Text: report to the Minister for Education and

Speaker: NA
Text: Science, who will act on behalf

Speaker: NA
Text: Governments. This amount will be

Speaker: NA
Text: increased by $10,000 by each Government

Speaker: NA
Text: in each of the second and third years.

Speaker: NA
Text: Each Government is prepared to increase

Speaker: NA
Text: its grant on a matching basis to the upper

Speaker: NA
Text: limits recommended by the report if the

Speaker: NA
Text: advisory committee finds in practice that

Speaker: NA
Text: has sufficiently good research projects

Speaker: NA
Text: warrant this. I shall announce the memas

Speaker: NA
Text: bership of the advisory committee as

Speaker: NA
Text: as possible.

Speaker: NA
Text: I present the following paper: .

Speaker: NA
Text: Crown of Thorns Starfish-Ministeria l

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, 30th March 1971.

Speaker: NA
Text: Motion (by Mr Swartz) proposed:

Speaker: NA
Text: .That the House take note of the statement.

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate (on motion by Dr Patterson)

Speaker: NA
Text: adjourned.

Speaker: NA
Text: LEADER OF THE HOUSE

Speaker: NA
Text: Ministerial Statement

Speaker: Mr SWARTZ
Text: Darling Downs-Ministe r

Speaker: NA
Text: for National Development)-b y leave-A s

Speaker: NA
Text: this is the first sitting day since my

Speaker: NA
Text: knowappointment as Leader of the House, I

Speaker: NA
Text: wish to take the opportunity to indicate

Speaker: NA
Text: briefly my intention to work at all times

Speaker: NA
Text: towards the smooth and efficient operation

Speaker: NA
Text: a of the House. It will be my aim to estab-

Speaker: NA
Text: lish as quickly as possible a close co-opera-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive working arrangement with Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker, The Clerks of the House, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government and Opposition Whips, and

Speaker: NA
Text: the the Leader and Deputy Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition. The efficient transaction of

Speaker: NA
Text: Government, general and private members'

Speaker: NA
Text: business can result only from the utmost

Speaker: NA
Text: and co-operation of all members, and I hope to

Speaker: NA
Text: my part in working with the Deputy

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition towards this end.

Speaker: NA
Text: The prestige and dignity of Parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: the are vital to the maintenance of a demo-

Speaker: NA
Text: As cratic system of government, and at this

Speaker: NA
Text: early point of time I can assure the House

Speaker: NA
Text: that there will be no lack of. effort on my

Speaker: NA
Text: part to ensure that the high standing of

Speaker: NA
Text: House is maintained. It is my duty to

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure that the Government's legislative

Speaker: NA
Text: programme proceeds' on schedule, but at

Speaker: NA
Text: same time there must be a full recognis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of the rights of all members to ade-

Speaker: NA
Text: debating time for general and private

Speaker: NA
Text: members' business. I am sure that I can

Speaker: NA
Text: depend upon the support of all members

Speaker: NA
Text: of the House in the maintenance of these

Speaker: NA
Text: of ooth principles and practice.

Speaker: Mr BARNARD
Text: Bass)-b y leave-Firs t

Speaker: NA
Text: of all, on behalf of fhe Opposition, I

Speaker: NA
Text: extend congratulations or commiserations,

Speaker: NA
Text: whichever is in order, to the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: National Development ( Mr Swartz). I can

Speaker: NA
Text: assure the Minister for National Develop-

Speaker: NA
Text: it ment that I will try tb work, as he sug-

Speaker: NA
Text: to gests, in very close co-operation with him

Speaker: NA
Text: the Deputy Leader of the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: soon and the one on this side of the House

Speaker: NA
Text: having the responsibility for duties such as

Speaker: NA
Text: those for which the Minister has responsi-

Speaker: NA
Text: bilities on behalf of the Government. I

Speaker: NA
Text: hope that the same very close relationship

Speaker: NA
Text: Statewill exist between the Minister and me as

Speaker: NA
Text: existed between me and his predecessor,

Speaker: NA
Text: the present Treasurer ( Mr Snedden), with

Speaker: NA
Text: whom I worked for a very. long time and

Speaker: NA
Text: with whom I was very closely associated in

Speaker: NA
Text: conducting the business of the House. I

Speaker: NA
Text: agree that the conduct of the business of

Speaker: NA
Text: the House depends to a very large extent

Speaker: NA
Text: upon the degree of co-operation between

Speaker: NA
Text: the Leader of the House and the Deputy

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition.

Speaker: NA
Text: I certainly welcome the assurance that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister has given that he will give

Speaker: NA
Text: very close consideration to the matters

Speaker: NA
Text: raised by honourable members on this side

Speaker: NA
Text: and lhat all members will be given the

Speaker: NA
Text: fullest opportunity to debate the matters

Speaker: NA
Text: that come before the Parliament: Of

Speaker: NA
Text: course, the Minister was referring particu-

Speaker: NA
Text: larly to private membeis and in this resp-

Speaker: NA
Text: ect one can assume that there will be full

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity to debate all the matters that

Speaker: NA
Text: come before the House. I am now refer-

Speaker: NA
Text: ring more specifically to debates on Bills.

Speaker: NA
Text: hope that there will be no curtailment of

Speaker: NA
Text: members' activities in respect of debating

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation introduced by the Government.

Speaker: NA
Text: We assume that the new Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House will not be moving the guillotine as

Speaker: NA
Text: often as his predecessor did, and that if

Speaker: NA
Text: there arc members on this side of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House who wish to debate a Bill the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister will always agree that the max-

Speaker: NA
Text: imum time should be allowed for debate.

Speaker: NA
Text: May 1 say also that we on this side of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House believe that debating time should

Speaker: NA
Text: not be curtailed and that it would be far

Speaker: NA
Text: better and that far greater advantage

Speaker: NA
Text: would accrue to all members if the length

Speaker: NA
Text: of sittings were extended instead of having

Speaker: NA
Text: members' activities curtailed as they are at

Speaker: NA
Text: present. Finally, I again congratulate the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister. I appreciate that he has made a

Speaker: NA
Text: very concise statement to the Parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: on the way in which he intends to conduct

Speaker: NA
Text: the business of the House on behalf of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government. I am sure I can work with

Speaker: NA
Text: him on the same basis, and, I hope, with

Speaker: NA
Text: the same degree of competence as I was

Speaker: NA
Text: able to work with his predecessor, the pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sent Treasurer.

Speaker: Mr DALY
Text: Grayndler)-b y leave-

Speaker: NA
Text: wish to join in the welcome to the new

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the House ( Mr Swartz). I lisalmost

Speaker: NA
Text: tened with interest to the announcement

Speaker: NA
Text: his appointment. We on this side of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House are becoming almost dizzy from the

Speaker: NA
Text: changes in those appointed fo this imporremind

Speaker: NA
Text: tant position on the other side of the Parsition,

Speaker: NA
Text: liament. We do not know from day to day

Speaker: NA
Text: how long the Minister announced by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Liberals to be in charge of the proceedings

Speaker: NA
Text: of this Parliament will remain in that

Speaker: NA
Text: position. Not long ago we had the former

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Air.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Order ! The matter

Speaker: NA
Text: under discussion is the statement just made

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Leader of the House, the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for National Development. The honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member is not allowed to go outside this

Speaker: NA
Text: subject matter to talk about other Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ters.

Speaker: Mr DALY
Text: I always admire the wis-

Speaker: NA
Text: dom underlying your judgments, Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker, and from long experience I know

Speaker: NA
Text: that you bave the last say. Consequently, I

Speaker: NA
Text: have no wish to infringe today. I was

Speaker: NA
Text: making passing reference to the prede-

Speaker: NA
Text: cessors of the earnest new Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House. I listened with interest to his state-

Speaker: NA
Text: I ment that he will work at all times towards

Speaker: NA
Text: the noble objectives which will govern his

Speaker: NA
Text: administration of this important position. I

Speaker: NA
Text: hope he succeeds in giving effect to that

Speaker: NA
Text: statement because expressions of that kind

Speaker: NA
Text: were made by many of the numerous

Speaker: NA
Text: Ministers who occupied this position in the

Speaker: NA
Text: past and generally the Opposition has

Speaker: NA
Text: never been treated more harshly than it

Speaker: NA
Text: has by the Leaders of the House who

Speaker: NA
Text: uttered those expressions.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Minister said he will uphold the

Speaker: NA
Text: prestige and dignity of the Parliament.

Speaker: NA
Text: Fancy a Liberal member, aftei what has

Speaker: NA
Text: gone on in recent weeks, telling the House

Speaker: NA
Text: that he will uphold the dignity of the Par-

Speaker: NA
Text: liament. The honourable member should

Speaker: NA
Text: first try to establish law and order in his

Speaker: NA
Text: own Party before trying to uphold the dig-

Speaker: NA
Text: nity of the Parliament. Then he said that

Speaker: NA
Text: the high standing of this House will be

Speaker: NA
Text: maintained. These are noble principles but

Speaker: NA
Text: what guarantee have we that he will do all

Speaker: NA
Text: these things? When all is said and done he

Speaker: NA
Text: is only one of many, the voice of a Min-

Speaker: NA
Text: istry elected on a spoils-to-the-victor basis,

Speaker: NA
Text: and if he does not obey the Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr MCMahon) in his every whim, irres-

Speaker: NA
Text: pective of the effects on our rights in this

Speaker: NA
Text: I Parliament, honourable members know as

Speaker: NA
Text: well as I do that he will be replaced

Speaker: NA
Text: overnight. As he is congratulated

Speaker: NA
Text: of today by the Deputy Leader of the Oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sition ( Mr Barnard) on his appointment to

Speaker: NA
Text: this position, we on this side of the House

Speaker: NA
Text: him that we are not just the Oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: that we are not the minority party.

Speaker: NA
Text: We polled more votes at the last Federal

Speaker: NA
Text: election than the collection of nondescripts

Speaker: NA
Text: who govern the country from that side of

Speaker: NA
Text: the House at this stage. Therefore, we are

Speaker: NA
Text: entitled not only to justice but also to the

Speaker: NA
Text: fairest possible treatment.

Speaker: NA
Text: There should not be any curtailment ot

Speaker: NA
Text: debate, and I hope the Leader of thc

Speaker: NA
Text: House understands this. Every member is

Speaker: NA
Text: entitled to talk on every Bill if he so

Speaker: NA
Text: desires. With 12 months available in everv

Speaker: NA
Text: year there is no reason why the Leader of

Speaker: NA
Text: the House should guillotine or curtail

Speaker: NA
Text: debate at any time in the Parliament. The

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Bradfield ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Turner), an outspoken advocate in this

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament of the rights of members, well

Speaker: NA
Text: knows that he has been harshly treated by

Speaker: NA
Text: former Leaders of the House. I hope he

Speaker: NA
Text: will add a few words to what 1 am saying.

Speaker: NA
Text: We expect fair treatment from the Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter who is now responsible for the task of

Speaker: NA
Text: running the Parliament and we expect him

Speaker: NA
Text: to recognise the rights of an Opposition.

Speaker: NA
Text: After all, it is not much satisfaction to

Speaker: NA
Text: members who have been sent here to rep-

Speaker: NA
Text: resent their constituencies to be gagged by

Speaker: NA
Text: a government which is afraid of criticism.

Speaker: NA
Text: Therefore, fhe Minister who in days gone

Speaker: NA
Text: by has had a certain tolerance in the

Speaker: NA
Text: administration of his Department, will be

Speaker: NA
Text: fully tested and'we will judge bim accord-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing to how he treats honourable members

Speaker: NA
Text: on this side of the House.

Speaker: NA
Text: I do not know what the Government has

Speaker: NA
Text: in mind for the future running of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House but already speeches have been cur-

Speaker: NA
Text: tailed, debates have been curtailed and the

Speaker: NA
Text: gag has been used on numerous occasions.

Speaker: NA
Text: 1 understand another Ministry is to be

Speaker: NA
Text: created, to be known as the Department of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Vice-President of the Executive Coun-

Speaker: NA
Text: cil. The Minister's full responsibility prob-

Speaker: NA
Text: ably will be to move the gag in this House

Speaker: NA
Text: as that is generally the responsibility of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister holding that position. Perhaps the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister in reply will tell us, apart from

Speaker: NA
Text: expressing his sentiments, precisely what he

Speaker: NA
Text: intends to do to improve on the adminis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tration of the previous Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House. 1 hope he does not have the chequ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ered career in the Parliament that the new

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer has had. We thought he was a

Speaker: NA
Text: reasonably good leader of the House but

Speaker: NA
Text: the Prime Minister did not, so out he

Speaker: NA
Text: went. The Government thought it had a

Speaker: NA
Text: better one and the next thing we knew the

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer bobbed up again like a jack-in-

Speaker: NA
Text: the-box. We do not know whether this will

Speaker: NA
Text: happen to the present incumbent now sit-

Speaker: NA
Text: ting at the table.

Speaker: NA
Text: I regret the restriction you have placed

Speaker: NA
Text: on my address today, Mr Speaker, but I

Speaker: NA
Text: could not let the occasion pass without

Speaker: NA
Text: saying that we on this side of the House

Speaker: NA
Text: look forward to big things from the Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter, but with some trepidation, because the

Speaker: NA
Text: machine that grinds behind him and tells

Speaker: NA
Text: him precisely what he is to do in this Par-

Speaker: NA
Text: liament does not know much about noble

Speaker: NA
Text: objectives, high principles and all those

Speaker: NA
Text: things of which the Minister, spoke. Let us

Speaker: NA
Text: hope that the Minister gives to honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: members on this side of (he House and all

Speaker: NA
Text: members of the Parliament equitable treat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment in respect of parliamentary business.

Speaker: NA
Text: For instance, we would like to see the 11

Speaker: NA
Text: o'clock rule imposed again so that honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able members would not need to debate in

Speaker: NA
Text: the dead of night. We. would like to sec

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister keep the Parliament going

Speaker: NA
Text: instead of rushing into recess to hide the

Speaker: NA
Text: divisions in the ranks of those who sit

Speaker: NA
Text: behind him. We would like .to know that

Speaker: NA
Text: we can debate the nation's needs in this

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament.

Speaker: NA
Text: 1 suppose the Minister's appointment as

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the House is a matter for con-

Speaker: NA
Text: gratulations because anybody who has sur-

Speaker: NA
Text: vived the' last purge of the Liberal Party is

Speaker: NA
Text: entitled at least to some Credit. The Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter is amongst those who have survived

Speaker: NA
Text: and his elevation is something that must

Speaker: NA
Text: have surprised even him. I urge the Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter to give effect to the things he has enun-

Speaker: NA
Text: ciated today. We look forward to justice,

Speaker: NA
Text: understanding and tolerance being

Speaker: NA
Text: extended to members on this side of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House. Whilst I say that! we look forward

Speaker: NA
Text: to this, we are not too confident that we

Speaker: NA
Text: will get it. In any case, this change indi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cates the turmoil that exists opposite. It

Speaker: NA
Text: indicates also that whilst . Liberal Party

Speaker: NA
Text: members will speak well of what they will

Speaker: NA
Text: do in the Parliament, long, experience has

Speaker: NA
Text: taught us that their actions are totally

Speaker: NA
Text: different. I hope that the Minister retains

Speaker: NA
Text: his position and does not disappear in a

Speaker: NA
Text: night as do some Ministers because, in a

Speaker: NA
Text: funny kind of way, we like him. However,

Speaker: NA
Text: at the same time we are not too confident

Speaker: NA
Text: that he will be much better than those who

Speaker: NA
Text: have preceded him.

Speaker: NA
Text: Motion (by Mr Swartz) agreed to:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the House, at its rising., adjourn until
