Speaker: NA
Text: JOINT COMMITTEE ON THE

Speaker: NA
Text: AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL

Speaker: NA
Text: TERRITORY

Speaker: Mr DALY
Text: Grayndler)-O n behalf of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Joint Committee on the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Capital Territory I bring up the Commit-

Speaker: NA
Text: tee's report on proposals for variations of

Speaker: NA
Text: the plan of the layout of the city of

Speaker: NA
Text: Canberra in tbe Australian Capital Terri-

Speaker: NA
Text: tory as gazetted in 1925-th e forty-seventh

Speaker: NA
Text: series of variations. I ask leave to make a

Speaker: NA
Text: short statement in connection with the

Speaker: NA
Text: report.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Order ! There being no

Speaker: NA
Text: objection, leave is granted.

Speaker: Mr DALY
Text: Mr Speaker, the report

Speaker: NA
Text: which 1 have just tabled is the first of its

Speaker: NA
Text: kind though the mailer with which it deals

Speaker: NA
Text: is one to which the Joint Committee on

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Capital Territory has given

Speaker: NA
Text: consideration ro on a number of previous

Speaker: NA
Text: occasions, namely, proposed variations to

Speaker: NA
Text: the plan of layout of the city of Canberra.

Speaker: NA
Text: Honourable members will be aware that

Speaker: NA
Text: the resolution of appointment of the Joint

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee on the Australian Capital Terri-

Speaker: NA
Text: tory requires it to:

Speaker: NA
Text: examine and report on all proposals for modifica-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions or variations of the plan of lay-out of the

Speaker: NA
Text: City of Canberra and its environs published in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth of Australia Gazette on the ninefor

Speaker: NA
Text: teenth day of November 1925, as previously move:

Speaker: NA
Text: modified or varied, which are referred to the

Speaker: NA
Text: committee by the Minister for the Interior.

Speaker: NA
Text: For a variety of reasons the Committee

Speaker: NA
Text: has not reported to Parliament before

Speaker: NA
Text: considers it proper to do so in the case

Speaker: NA
Text: the current proposals, known as the fortyreason

Speaker: NA
Text: seventh series of variations, and on all

Speaker: NA
Text: future occasions.

Speaker: NA
Text: It will be of interest to honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: members lo know that the proposals for

Speaker: NA
Text: variations are fully explained to the

Speaker: NA
Text: mittee in private session by officers of

Speaker: NA
Text: National Capital Development Commission

Speaker: NA
Text: and the Department of the Interior and

Speaker: NA
Text: following examination of these officers

Speaker: NA
Text: inspection, where necessary, of the sites

Speaker: NA
Text: proposed variations, the

Speaker: NA
Text: satisfies itself as to the desirability

Speaker: NA
Text: practicality of the variations befoie recom-

Speaker: NA
Text: mending their adoption. These matters are

Speaker: NA
Text: not considered lightly, nor are members of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Committee easily satisfied of the worth

Speaker: NA
Text: of the proposals. Much evidence is taken

Speaker: NA
Text: and the National Capital Development

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission and the Department of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Interior go to considerable trouble to satis-

Speaker: NA
Text: fy the penetrating examination of the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: posals made by the members of the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: Report mittee, in short, this is not a rubber stamp

Speaker: NA
Text: procedure. The House is assured that

Speaker: NA
Text: where proposed variations are recommend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ed, they have been well considered.

Speaker: NA
Text: Honourable members will be aware that

Speaker: NA
Text: there is a requirement for the proposed

Speaker: NA
Text: variations to lie on the table in both the

Speaker: NA
Text: Senate and the House of Representatives

Speaker: NA
Text: for a minimum period of 6 sitting days

Speaker: NA
Text: and this procedure follows the consider-

Speaker: NA
Text: ation by members of the Committee. There

Speaker: NA
Text: is, therefore, and there always has been,

Speaker: NA
Text: the opportunity for honourable members to

Speaker: NA
Text: satisfy themselves as to the merit of the

Speaker: NA
Text: proposals. The tabling of this report does

Speaker: NA
Text: not in any way affect the procedure

Speaker: NA
Text: referred to and the proposals will still lie

Speaker: NA
Text: on the table in the customary fashion at

Speaker: NA
Text: some point after this report has been

Speaker: NA
Text: tabled.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ordered that the report be printed.

Speaker: NA
Text: AUSTRALIAN WAR MEMORIAL

Speaker: NA
Text: BILL 1970

Speaker: NA
Text: Discharge of Order of the Day

Speaker: Mr SWARTZ
Text: Darling Downs-Ministe r

Speaker: NA
Text: National Development) (3.45)- I

Speaker: NA
Text: That Government Business, Order of the Day

Speaker: NA
Text: No. 1, Australian War Memorial Bill 1970. sec-

Speaker: NA
Text: ond reading, be discharged.

Speaker: NA
Text: but In moving this motion 1 should like

Speaker: NA
Text: of to explain briefly to the House the

Speaker: NA
Text: behind it. Since the Bill as now

Speaker: NA
Text: drafted was introduced on 21st May last

Speaker: NA
Text: year the Government has been considering

Speaker: NA
Text: further amendments to it. I am advised by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Clerk that the proposed amendments

Speaker: NA
Text: Comwould fall outside the long title of the

Speaker: NA
Text: the present Bill so that the amendments could

Speaker: NA
Text: be incorporated only as a result of some

Speaker: NA
Text: complicated procedures. In addition, the

Speaker: NA
Text: and honourable member for Bradfield ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: of Turner) has indicated to the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee his interest in certain other proposals.

Speaker: NA
Text: and For these reasons the Government believes

Speaker: NA
Text: it preferable to withdraw the present Bill.

Speaker: NA
Text: In due course a redrafted Bill will be

Speaker: NA
Text: introduced by the Minister for the Interior

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Hunt).

Speaker: Mr TURNER
Text: Bradfield) (3.46)-Ther e

Speaker: NA
Text: are 3 observations I should like to make in

Speaker: NA
Text: connection with this matter. First, it is

Speaker: NA
Text: proposed to withdraw the present Bill and

Speaker: NA
Text: to substitute another Bill for it. I would

Speaker: NA
Text: hope that the Leader of the House ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Swartz) may be able to give some assur-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance that the substituted Bill will be

Speaker: NA
Text: brought before the House within a reason-

Speaker: NA
Text: able time. By this I mean that 1 hope that

Speaker: NA
Text: it will not be squeezed into the last week

Speaker: NA
Text: of the sittings, perhaps at a late hour of

Speaker: NA
Text: the night. The reason why I ask for such

Speaker: NA
Text: an assurance is that, as I think most hon-

Speaker: NA
Text: ourable members know both from notices

Speaker: NA
Text: that have appeared in the Party rooms and

Speaker: NA
Text: from a notification in their mail if they

Speaker: NA
Text: have had time to read it, Mr Frank

Speaker: NA
Text: Channon, who represents a particular point

Speaker: NA
Text: of view in relation to the incorporation of

Speaker: NA
Text: a tomb in the Memorial to contain the

Speaker: NA
Text: remains of an unknown Australian soldier,

Speaker: NA
Text: is to come to Parliament House next

Speaker: NA
Text: Thursday at 3.30 p.m. and in Committee

Speaker: NA
Text: Room No. 2 to give an explanation of his

Speaker: NA
Text: point of view which is supported by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Returned Services League. It would be

Speaker: NA
Text: unfortunate if, when members' minds have

Speaker: NA
Text: been freshly devoted to this matter, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill were to be postponed for such a time

Speaker: NA
Text: that they had forgotten what they had

Speaker: NA
Text: heard about the issue.

Speaker: NA
Text: The second matter that I wish to raise

Speaker: NA
Text: concerns an assurance from the Leader of

Speaker: NA
Text: the House that the long title of the Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: will be amended in such a way as to make

Speaker: NA
Text: possible the incorporation of an amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment dealing with the matter which Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Channon will be discussing with members

Speaker: NA
Text: on Thursday. Standing order 227 states in

Speaker: NA
Text: part:

Speaker: NA
Text: Any amendment may be moved to any part of

Speaker: NA
Text: tbe Bill, provided the same be within the title or

Speaker: NA
Text: relevant to the subject matter of the Bill.

Speaker: NA
Text: The long title of the Bill that is to be

Speaker: NA
Text: withdrawn is: 'To amend section 6 of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian War Memorial Act 1962-1966'.

Speaker: NA
Text: The standing order I have just quoted

Speaker: NA
Text: limits amendments to amendments to sec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion 6. If when the substituted Bill is

Speaker: NA
Text: brought forward the title is restrictive, for

Speaker: NA
Text: example to amend section 6 and some

Speaker: NA
Text: other section of the Act, then amendments

Speaker: NA
Text: will be limited to those 2 sections and it

Speaker: NA
Text: may be that those 2 sections do not offer

Speaker: NA
Text: the opportunity to me to move an amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment in relation to Mr Channon's pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: posal. I therefore hope that when the sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: stituted Bill is produced in the House it

Speaker: NA
Text: will have a wide long title-fo r example,

Speaker: NA
Text: simply to amend the Australian War

Speaker: NA
Text: Memorial Act 1962-1966. This will then

Speaker: NA
Text: allow for the kind of amendment that I

Speaker: NA
Text: think should be moved in order that the

Speaker: NA
Text: sense of the House may be tested on this

Speaker: NA
Text: matter which has too long waited for a

Speaker: NA
Text: decision.

Speaker: NA
Text: The third and last matter that I wish to

Speaker: NA
Text: raise is this: I should like to appeal to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the House to decide for himself,

Speaker: NA
Text: if he has the authority to do so, or to seek

Speaker: NA
Text: the opinion of the Government upon this,

Speaker: NA
Text: that this is a matter- I refer to the tomb

Speaker: NA
Text: with which Mr Channon . is concerned-

Speaker: NA
Text: that should be the subject of a free vote.

Speaker: NA
Text: The question whether or not the tomb con-

Speaker: NA
Text: taining the remains of an unknown Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian serviceman should be incorporated

Speaker: NA
Text: in the War Memorial is in no sense a

Speaker: NA
Text: Party matter. It affects the people of Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia as represented by members in this

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament and in no way can it be consid-

Speaker: NA
Text: ered a matter of Government policy. So I

Speaker: NA
Text: appeal to the Leader of - the House to

Speaker: NA
Text: decide for himself or to bring to the con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sideration of the Government the question

Speaker: NA
Text: of making this matter, when raised on an

Speaker: NA
Text: amendment to the Bill ' proposed to be

Speaker: NA
Text: brought into the House, the subject of a

Speaker: NA
Text: free vote - 1

Speaker: Mr SWARTZ
Text: Darling Downs-Ministe r

Speaker: NA
Text: for National Development) (3.51)-i n

Speaker: NA
Text: reply- I just want to make the brief com-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment that the last point raised by the hon-

Speaker: NA
Text: ourable member for Bradfield ( Mr Turner)

Speaker: NA
Text: will certainly be examined. The other mat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ters relating to the Bill willbe referred to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister for the Interior ( Mr Hunt)

Speaker: NA
Text: who has responsibility for the Bill.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question resolved in the affirmative.

Speaker: NA
Text: DRIED FRUITS RESEARCH

Speaker: NA
Text: BILL 1971

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate resumed from. 25 February (vide

Speaker: NA
Text: page 659), on motion by. Mr Sinclair:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the Bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: Mr SWARTZ
Text: Darling Downs-Ministe r

Speaker: NA
Text: for National Development)- I ask the

Speaker: NA
Text: indulgence.of the House to raise a point of

Speaker: NA
Text: procedure on this legislation. Before the

Speaker: NA
Text: debate is resumed on this Bill I would like

Speaker: NA
Text: to suggest that it may suit the convenience

Speaker: NA
Text: of the House to have a general debate cov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ering this Bill, the Dried Fruits Levy Bill,

Speaker: NA
Text: and the Dried Fruits Levy Collection Bill,

Speaker: NA
Text: as Ihey are related measures. Separate

Speaker: NA
Text: questions may, of course, be put on each

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Bills at the conclusion of the

Speaker: NA
Text: debate. I suggest, therefore, Mr Deputy

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker, that you permit the subject mat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter of the 3 Bills to be discussed in this

Speaker: NA
Text: debate.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr Lucock)

Speaker: NA
Text: -Ther e being no objection, that course

Speaker: NA
Text: will be followed.

Speaker: Dr PATTERSON
Text: Dawson) (3.53)-Th e

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition supports in principle the 3 Bills

Speaker: NA
Text: before the House. In the Committee stages

Speaker: NA
Text: we shall move 2 amendments dealing

Speaker: NA
Text: specifically with penalties and in relation

Speaker: NA
Text: evidence secured by people authorised by

Speaker: NA
Text: writ to do so. The principal objective of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Dried Fruits Research Bill 1971 is to

Speaker: NA
Text: establish a joint Commonwealth-industry

Speaker: NA
Text: research scheme following the accepted

Speaker: NA
Text: and tried principles laid down by legisla-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion pertaining to other industries. Funds

Speaker: NA
Text: will be raised by means of a levy on dried

Speaker: NA
Text: fruit, and in addition the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: Government, following again the principles

Speaker: NA
Text: adopted with respect to other industries,

Speaker: NA
Text: will match this contribution on a $1 for $1

Speaker: NA
Text: basis. The second Bill, the Dried Fruits

Speaker: NA
Text: Levy Bill, authorises the imposition of the

Speaker: NA
Text: levy relating to dried fruits. The amounts

Speaker: NA
Text: equivalent to levy collection will be

Speaker: NA
Text: credited to the Dried Fruits Research

Speaker: NA
Text: Trust Account and this Account will be

Speaker: NA
Text: the working arrangement whereby the

Speaker: NA
Text: moneys which are used for research pur-

Speaker: NA
Text: poses are debited. The second Bill will

Speaker: NA
Text: provide that the rate of levy must not

Speaker: NA
Text: exceed $1 a ton of currants, sultanas and

Speaker: NA
Text: raisins and $5 a ton of dried apricots,

Speaker: NA
Text: pears, peaches, nectarines and prunes. As

Speaker: NA
Text: with other similar pieces of legislation the

Speaker: NA
Text: operative rates of levy to be imposed will

Speaker: NA
Text: be prescribed by regulation.

Speaker: NA
Text: As the Minister for Primary Industry

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Sinclair) pointed out in his second

Speaker: NA
Text: reading speech, the levy will be imposed

Speaker: NA
Text: on a net sweat box weight of all dried

Speaker: NA
Text: fruits of these kinds delivered to packing

Speaker: NA
Text: houses after the commencement of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Act. The operative rate is the rate which

Speaker: NA
Text: will apply in the first instance. The opera-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive rate in respect of currants, sultanas

Speaker: NA
Text: and raisins will be 50c a ton and in respect

Speaker: NA
Text: of dried tree fruits the operative rates of

Speaker: NA
Text: levy relating broadly' to' the prospective

Speaker: NA
Text: sale value of each kind of fruit will be

Speaker: NA
Text: prescribed. As the Minister pointed out,

Speaker: NA
Text: this will be done in consultation with the

Speaker: NA
Text: research committee.' The third Bill is sim-

Speaker: NA
Text: ply the machinery Bill which again is com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mon to all similar pieces of legislation in

Speaker: NA
Text: Connection with the collection of research

Speaker: NA
Text: funds. This Bill enables the Government to

Speaker: NA
Text: provide the machinery" necessary for the

Speaker: NA
Text: collection of the levy On dried fruits

Speaker: NA
Text: imposed by the Dried Frdits Levy Bill.

Speaker: NA
Text: The principal objective, of this legisla-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, of course, is to. enable the industry,

Speaker: NA
Text: by a process of self-help backed by Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth finance, to - undertake specific

Speaker: NA
Text: measures of research-directly or indirectly

Speaker: NA
Text: to concerned with the production and market-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing of dried fruits. It will relate specifically

Speaker: NA
Text: to currants, sultanas .and raisins and the

Speaker: NA
Text: deciduous tree fruits.; such as apricots,

Speaker: NA
Text: pears, peaches, nectarines and prunes. I

Speaker: NA
Text: understand from reading the second read-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing speech of the Minister that although

Speaker: NA
Text: there are some small . pockets of dried

Speaker: NA
Text: apple production in. Tasmania, at this stage

Speaker: NA
Text: this part of the Tasmanian apple industry

Speaker: NA
Text: will not be the. subject of research. I do

Speaker: NA
Text: not know the reason for that. I would

Speaker: NA
Text: have thought that it could easily have been

Speaker: NA
Text: included beoause although it is only a

Speaker: NA
Text: minor industry as such, nevertheless the

Speaker: NA
Text: principles in the process of drying fruit

Speaker: NA
Text: could equally apply in some instances to

Speaker: NA
Text: apples. We will not . make an issue of this

Speaker: NA
Text: but I cannot see any - basic reason why

Speaker: NA
Text: dried apples should not be covered by this

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill even though they represent only a

Speaker: NA
Text: small proportion of the apple industry

Speaker: NA
Text: located in Tasmania. '

Speaker: NA
Text: There is no need for me to emphasise

Speaker: NA
Text: the great importance .ofdried fruits to

Speaker: NA
Text: some regions of Australia, basically the

Speaker: NA
Text: area in close proximity to the Murray

Speaker: NA
Text: River. There are areas in Western Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia where dried fruits are also important

Speaker: NA
Text: but without question it is the Murray

Speaker: NA
Text: environment which is the principal produc-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing region in Australia and with which we

Speaker: NA
Text: are concerned here. Members who repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sent such areas fully realise the great

Speaker: NA
Text: importance to the economies of those

Speaker: NA
Text: regions of specific industries, in this case,

Speaker: NA
Text: the dried fruits industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: Honourable members who represent that

Speaker: NA
Text: Murray River electorates know full well

Speaker: NA
Text: great importance of regional development

Speaker: NA
Text: and the economic consequences if anything

Speaker: NA
Text: goes wrong with the financial health of

Speaker: NA
Text: specialised industry. I represent an elecWe

Speaker: NA
Text: torate wbich contains the biggest sugar

Speaker: NA
Text: growing area in Australia. The same

Speaker: NA
Text: nomic principles as regards regional develfruits

Speaker: NA
Text: opment apply there. It is of utmost imporof a fruit.

Speaker: NA
Text: tance that vve realise this because in recent

Speaker: NA
Text: years we have had under discussion the

Speaker: NA
Text: consequences of Britain's entry into the

Speaker: NA
Text: European Common Market. Although the

Speaker: NA
Text: loss of markets, specifically in terms

Speaker: NA
Text: fruit, sugar, soft wheat and similar

Speaker: NA
Text: ucts may not be in aggregate greatly

Speaker: NA
Text: mental to the economy of Australia-tha

Speaker: NA
Text: is relative to the total gross value of

Speaker: NA
Text: duction or even the gross value of our

Speaker: NA
Text: exports-t o a region any significant loss

Speaker: NA
Text: a market and any significant reduction

Speaker: NA
Text: income could not only affect primary

Speaker: NA
Text: ducers but, through the multiplier theory,

Speaker: NA
Text: influence and affect greatly those who

Speaker: NA
Text: depend on the hard core or nucleus of

Speaker: NA
Text: primary production. We have seen pracresentatives

Speaker: NA
Text: tical examples of this in Australia quite

Speaker: NA
Text: clearly in the great wool industry because

Speaker: NA
Text: of recent droughts and falling prices.

Speaker: NA
Text: belies'e that the principle of regional

Speaker: NA
Text: opment is something we have to emphasise

Speaker: NA
Text: a lot more. Too often we look at primary

Speaker: NA
Text: industry in Australia as a whole and

Speaker: NA
Text: not concentrate sufficiently on regional

Speaker: NA
Text: development. That is one reason why

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition will always support the GovCommittee

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment in any constructive plan to duction

Speaker: NA
Text: increase the economic health of a basic

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian industry, be it primary or

Speaker: NA
Text: ondary industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think the 2 main avenues of research

Speaker: NA
Text: in dried fruits are processing and marketrepresents

Speaker: NA
Text: ing. The actual production of dried fruits

Speaker: NA
Text: is important but this is a separate matter.

Speaker: NA
Text: In this Bill the 2 areas of priority for

Speaker: NA
Text: research funds would, I think, be the proof

Speaker: NA
Text: cessing and marketing of the product. This

Speaker: NA
Text: would involve economic research into the

Speaker: NA
Text: packaging and marketing of the finished

Speaker: NA
Text: product both in Australia and overseas. We

Speaker: NA
Text: must keep abreast of technological changes

Speaker: NA
Text: and one way to do this is to utilise

Speaker: NA
Text: own scientists, agricultural economists

Speaker: NA
Text: marketing economists in their respective

Speaker: NA
Text: specialised fields. In the dried fruits indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: try technology is on the move and anyone

Speaker: NA
Text: who believes that we can sit still and hope

Speaker: NA
Text: markets will come to Australia is in for

Speaker: NA
Text: the a shock. We have to' produce a product

Speaker: NA
Text: which will sell in competition from other

Speaker: NA
Text: major exporting countries and we have to

Speaker: NA
Text: a get out and find markets for our products.

Speaker: NA
Text: have had research in the dried fruits

Speaker: NA
Text: industry but it has been on an ad hoc

Speaker: NA
Text: ecoapproach and it has applied to specific

Speaker: NA
Text: rather than to the different varieties

Speaker: NA
Text: The Research Committee will follow the

Speaker: NA
Text: usual pattern of other' research organisa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions. From memory I think there are

Speaker: NA
Text: of approximately 9 industries which have vol-

Speaker: NA
Text: produntarily agreed to contribute finance,

Speaker: NA
Text: detribacked by Commonwealth contributions.

Speaker: NA
Text: t The Dried Fruits Research,Committee will

Speaker: NA
Text: probroadly follow the same basis of other

Speaker: NA
Text: research committees in that the industry

Speaker: NA
Text: of itself will have the dominant voice on the

Speaker: NA
Text: in Committee as to the allocation of funds

Speaker: NA
Text: proand the evaluation and the determination

Speaker: NA
Text: of priorities. The Research Committee will

Speaker: NA
Text: comprise 4 representatives of the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian Dried Fruits Association, 2 rep-

Speaker: NA
Text: of packers of dried fruits, 3

Speaker: NA
Text: representatives of the Australian Agricul-

Speaker: NA
Text: tural Council, one Representative of the

Speaker: NA
Text: I Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial

Speaker: NA
Text: develResearch Organisation and one represen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tative of the Department, of Primary

Speaker: NA
Text: Industry. This will be, a, well balanced

Speaker: NA
Text: do Committee with men of practical experi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ence of the problems .relating to specific

Speaker: NA
Text: the areas and industries. The men on this

Speaker: NA
Text: will be experienced in the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: and marketing of dried fruits, both

Speaker: NA
Text: domestically and overseas. The Committee

Speaker: NA
Text: secwill also have the assistance of funda-

Speaker: NA
Text: mental and applied scientists. Taken by

Speaker: NA
Text: and large I believe that the Committee

Speaker: NA
Text: another excellent step forward

Speaker: NA
Text: in tbe formulation of research projects for

Speaker: NA
Text: the benefit of the dried fruits industry and

Speaker: NA
Text: for the benefit of the nation. One function

Speaker: NA
Text: the Committee will be ,to receive appli-

Speaker: NA
Text: cations from various institutions such as

Speaker: NA
Text: universities in Australia and from people

Speaker: NA
Text: concerned with production or with

Speaker: NA
Text: scientific research into dried fruits, includ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing fundamental, applied or technical

Speaker: NA
Text: our research. The Committee will decide

Speaker: NA
Text: and whether to allocate funds to the research

Speaker: NA
Text: proposals submitted to it. The research will

Speaker: NA
Text: be administered and supervised by compe-

Speaker: NA
Text: tent authorities. At the same time the

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee will be highly conscious of the

Speaker: NA
Text: principles underlining priorities.

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to say something about research

Speaker: NA
Text: because it is something about which I feel

Speaker: NA
Text: very strongly, and I am not the only one

Speaker: NA
Text: in industry or in research fields who feels

Speaker: NA
Text: this way. We are inclined to look at a lot

Speaker: NA
Text: of research in isolation when we do not

Speaker: NA
Text: have the machinery with which to examine

Speaker: NA
Text: at length whether there is any overlapping

Speaker: NA
Text: of research. We are also inclined to take

Speaker: NA
Text: for granted that because a first class scienare

Speaker: NA
Text: tist is doing the research such research

Speaker: NA
Text: must be good, and this applies particularly

Speaker: NA
Text: in the field of fundamental research. 1 do

Speaker: NA
Text: not question in any way the value of

Speaker: NA
Text: research. What I am saying is that 1

Speaker: NA
Text: believe that today we have to think more

Speaker: NA
Text: of priorities, particularly economic

Speaker: NA
Text: research and we should give it a greater

Speaker: NA
Text: weighting than perhaps even fundamental

Speaker: NA
Text: research. I do not in any way decry the

Speaker: NA
Text: work of the fundamental research scientist.

Speaker: NA
Text: We need these people. But world markets

Speaker: NA
Text: are changing so quickly and the profitabi-

Speaker: NA
Text: lity in the dried fruits market, which is

Speaker: NA
Text: small, is also changing, so that we have to

Speaker: NA
Text: have greater emphasis placed on economic

Speaker: NA
Text: and marketing research.

Speaker: NA
Text: I do not want my remarks to be conpast

Speaker: NA
Text: strued in any way that I am criticising

Speaker: NA
Text: work of the fundamental scientist. I was

Speaker: NA
Text: associated with research organisations prior

Speaker: NA
Text: to entering into politics. What I am trying

Speaker: NA
Text: to say is that I know that very often

Speaker: NA
Text: fundamental scientist is treated as some

Speaker: NA
Text: sort of a god, that what he says goes

Speaker: NA
Text: if you question or evaluate the benefits

Speaker: NA
Text: his work he will say T do not know, but

Speaker: NA
Text: may be able to tell you in one year or

Speaker: NA
Text: years time'. This is fundamental research

Speaker: NA
Text: and there is nothing wrong with it. We

Speaker: NA
Text: need replicated research. I may criticise

Speaker: NA
Text: any overlapping of fundamental research

Speaker: NA
Text: but by the same token the more people

Speaker: NA
Text: have doing the research the greater

Speaker: NA
Text: chance we have of achieving a constructive

Speaker: NA
Text: and substantive conclusion. The point

Speaker: NA
Text: want to make is that I believe this

Speaker: NA
Text: Research Committee will have to detercern

Speaker: NA
Text: mine priorities and this is one reason why

Speaker: NA
Text: the industry should have the dominant say

Speaker: NA
Text: in determining research proposals rather

Speaker: NA
Text: than perhaps the scientists.

Speaker: NA
Text: I urge the Government to give consider-

Speaker: NA
Text: ation to the evaluation of research. I am

Speaker: NA
Text: not one of the those people who treat

Speaker: NA
Text: research as a magic word. As one who has

Speaker: NA
Text: been trained in the field of research 1 am

Speaker: NA
Text: fully conscious of its deficiencies. I am

Speaker: NA
Text: conscious of the fact that any Government

Speaker: NA
Text: that is spending huge amounts of Federal

Speaker: NA
Text: money on research carried out by the

Speaker: NA
Text: CSIRO or by universities should ensure

Speaker: NA
Text: that there is some accounting of that

Speaker: NA
Text: research to the Parliament. Where indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tries are involved there should also be

Speaker: NA
Text: some accounting to those industries. There

Speaker: NA
Text: plenty of scientists who would like to

Speaker: NA
Text: build a research empire; given the chance

Speaker: NA
Text: they would and good luck to them if they

Speaker: NA
Text: can get away with it.. One can always

Speaker: NA
Text: argue that all research is good. Perhaps it

Speaker: NA
Text: is, provided it is constructive and adds to

Speaker: NA
Text: knowledge. However, research has to be

Speaker: NA
Text: subject to evaluation and I believe it has to

Speaker: NA
Text: be subject to scrutiny. It should be

Speaker: NA
Text: accountable to the Parliament from time to

Speaker: NA
Text: time and particularly to the industry

Speaker: NA
Text: involved. which is supplying half of the

Speaker: NA
Text: funds. I make that plea in regard to the

Speaker: NA
Text: evaluation of research.

Speaker: NA
Text: As I have said, I "feel' very strongly

Speaker: NA
Text: about this. Perhaps one of these days when

Speaker: NA
Text: we get a chance we will be able to debate

Speaker: NA
Text: some of the avenues of research over the

Speaker: NA
Text: 20 years. If we evaluated this research

Speaker: NA
Text: the we might have second thoughts about

Speaker: NA
Text: spending hundreds of thousands of dollars

Speaker: NA
Text: in a particular field of research. I repeat

Speaker: NA
Text: that this is not to decry in any way the

Speaker: NA
Text: the role of fundamental or applied research.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have to have both;, we have to have

Speaker: NA
Text: and extension, but at the same time we must

Speaker: NA
Text: of have the machinery for evaluation. I hope

Speaker: NA
Text: I that in the debate on this Bill the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: 10 will give honourable members some idea

Speaker: NA
Text: of what is to happen to the stability of the

Speaker: NA
Text: dried vine fruits industry. This industry is

Speaker: NA
Text: vitally affected by this .legislation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Honourable members will recall that on

Speaker: NA
Text: we 10th September 1969 the then Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: the Primary Industry, now the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Trade and Industry ( Mr Anthony) made a

Speaker: NA
Text: I statement in which he said that the Gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment was considering' with some con-

Speaker: NA
Text: the question Of the stability of the

Speaker: NA
Text: dried vine fruits industry and that it had

Speaker: NA
Text: agreed in principle to consider the possibil-

Speaker: NA
Text: ity of implementing a further stabilisation

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme, which would be an extension of

Speaker: NA
Text: the 1964-68 dried vine fruits stabilisation

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme. The Minister, after considerable

Speaker: NA
Text: discussion with the Australian Dried Fruits

Speaker: NA
Text: Association, had arrived at a stabilisation

Speaker: NA
Text: plan for currants, sultanas and raisins. This

Speaker: NA
Text: generated considerable speculation and

Speaker: NA
Text: controversy throughout the industry. In

Speaker: NA
Text: fact, a major split developed in the indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: try, which is something that an industry

Speaker: NA
Text: should attempt to avoid. The people in the

Speaker: NA
Text: dried vine fruits industry were for and

Speaker: NA
Text: against the plan. Some wanted a statutory

Speaker: NA
Text: authority and others wanted a stabilisation

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme.

Speaker: NA
Text: Uuder such circumstances a referendum

Speaker: NA
Text: was held to decide whether a stabilisation

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme would he acceptable to a majority

Speaker: NA
Text: of growers. The closing date of the poll

Speaker: NA
Text: was 23rd March 1970. Then the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: made a statement to the effect that the

Speaker: NA
Text: proposal had been rejected by the eligible

Speaker: NA
Text: growers on the criteria laid down by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government. Although 65 per cent of

Speaker: NA
Text: growers voted in favour of the proposal

Speaker: NA
Text: and 35 per cent voted against it, the fact

Speaker: NA
Text: was that only two-thirds of all eligible

Speaker: NA
Text: growers voted, so only 42 per cent of eligi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ble growers voted in favour of the scheme.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is important to consider this factor

Speaker: NA
Text: because no matter whether we establish a

Speaker: NA
Text: statutory authority or introduce a stabilisa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion scheme, as we know it, we must have

Speaker: NA
Text: a stable industry, and the research which is

Speaker: NA
Text: to be undertaken as a result of this Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: must and should be applied to a stable

Speaker: NA
Text: industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: The question that I ask the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: What is happening to the stability of the

Speaker: NA
Text: dried vine fruits industry? At the present

Speaker: NA
Text: time we are receiving disturbing reports

Speaker: NA
Text: about the increasing production of the dual

Speaker: NA
Text: variety of grapes, that is, grapes which can

Speaker: NA
Text: be used for drying and for fresh consumpmajor

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. Of course, once the bearing acreage

Speaker: NA
Text: increased the industry can be confronted

Speaker: NA
Text: with the problem of oversupply. From

Speaker: NA
Text: time to time in this Parliament I have

Speaker: NA
Text: argued strongly that all phases of primary

Speaker: NA
Text: industry have to be reorganised and that

Speaker: NA
Text: we have to refrain from adopting this ad

Speaker: NA
Text: hoc, uncoordinated approach to primary

Speaker: NA
Text: industry. We have, to reorganise primary

Speaker: NA
Text: industry in relation to realistic markets;

Speaker: NA
Text: not airy-fairy markets which,

Speaker: NA
Text: sised, might eventuate, but realistic mar-

Speaker: NA
Text: kets which exist at the present time and

Speaker: NA
Text: which wiil exist in the immediate future.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have to tailor our production in basic

Speaker: NA
Text: demand to fit the realistic markets. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: important to consider this factor because

Speaker: NA
Text: the dried fruit industry is unlike the wheat

Speaker: NA
Text: industry which produces a cash crop, and

Speaker: NA
Text: production can be increased or decreased

Speaker: NA
Text: very quickly. Once vines and trees are

Speaker: NA
Text: established there are virtually fixed produc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion levels and the only way in which

Speaker: NA
Text: production can be reduced is to chop

Speaker: NA
Text: down the vines or trees or for the vines or

Speaker: NA
Text: trees to be subjected to weather conditions,

Speaker: NA
Text: such as frost. I ask that question so that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister might be able to give honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able members and the industry some indi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cation of what the Government is thinking

Speaker: NA
Text: at the present lime.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is all I have to say on this

Speaker: NA
Text: measure. The Opposition supports the leg-

Speaker: NA
Text: islation, as it has done with other research

Speaker: NA
Text: Bills which have come before the Parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. However, at the Committee stage we

Speaker: NA
Text: will move 2 amendments dealing with the

Speaker: NA
Text: questions of penalties and the collection of

Speaker: NA
Text: evidence by those people authorised under

Speaker: NA
Text: the legislation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate (on motion by Mr Turnbull)

Speaker: NA
Text: adjourned.

Speaker: NA
Text: FUTURE OF AUSTRALIAN FORCES

Speaker: NA
Text: IN VIETNA M

Speaker: NA
Text: Ministerial Statement

Speaker: Mr MCMAHON
Text: Lowe-Prim e Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter)-b y leave- Mr Speaker, the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment has been reviewing the position of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's military forces in Vietnam in

Speaker: NA
Text: is: order to determine what further with-

Speaker: NA
Text: drawal options are open to it, having

Speaker: NA
Text: regard to the security situation and the

Speaker: NA
Text: intentions of the Government of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Republic of Vietnam and of our other

Speaker: NA
Text: allies. This review follows from the

Speaker: NA
Text: is policy stated by the then Prime Minister,

Speaker: NA
Text: now the Minister for Defence ( Mr Gor-

Speaker: NA
Text: ton), in April 1970 when, in announcing

Speaker: NA
Text: the withdrawal of one Army battalion, he

Speaker: NA
Text: said that 'Should the progress of pacifica-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion and Vietnamisation succeed as the

Speaker: NA
Text: President (of the United States) hopes and

Speaker: NA
Text: believes that it will, then at some stage

Speaker: NA
Text: during the 12 months period we will con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sider phasing additional troops into the

Speaker: NA
Text: it is hypotheplanned withdrawal'.

Speaker: NA
Text: During his recent visit to Vietnam, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Defence had valuable discus-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions with Vietnamese leaders and with the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commander of United States forces in

Speaker: NA
Text: Vietnam. These consultations

Speaker: NA
Text: confirmed our assessment that steady

Speaker: NA
Text: improvement is being achieved in the secu-

Speaker: NA
Text: rity situation. Many factors have contri-

Speaker: NA
Text: buted to this improvement. The policy of

Speaker: NA
Text: Vietnamisation, that is, the development of

Speaker: NA
Text: the capability and effectiveness of South

Speaker: NA
Text: Vietnam's armed forces, has produced a

Speaker: NA
Text: much stronger and more cohesive fighting

Speaker: NA
Text: force. The pacification programme has also

Speaker: NA
Text: achieved notable successes, and its contri-

Speaker: NA
Text: bution towards improved security in the

Speaker: NA
Text: rural areas has necessitated the enemy con-

Speaker: NA
Text: centrating his effort against that pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: gramme. These developments, in combina-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion with North Vietnam's manpower

Speaker: NA
Text: problems, have seen a significant decline in

Speaker: NA
Text: enemy-initiated activity over the last 2

Speaker: NA
Text: years.

Speaker: NA
Text: An important consequence of these

Speaker: NA
Text: achievements has been that the South Viet-

Speaker: NA
Text: namese have been able to continue their

Speaker: NA
Text: operations in Cambodia against North

Speaker: NA
Text: Vietnamese regular forces. Additionally

Speaker: NA
Text: they were able to initiate and conduct the

Speaker: NA
Text: recent operations against the North Viet-

Speaker: NA
Text: namese supply lines in southern Laos. The

Speaker: NA
Text: effect of these operations so far has been

Speaker: NA
Text: to prevent the enemy mounting large-scale

Speaker: NA
Text: actions inside South Vietnam and thus they

Speaker: NA
Text: have given the South Vietnamese time for

Speaker: NA
Text: the further development of their forces

Speaker: NA
Text: and for strengthening the pacification pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: gramme. In a number of key areas within

Speaker: NA
Text: South Vietnam the North Vietnamese have

Speaker: NA
Text: for the present lost the military initiative.

Speaker: NA
Text: The enemy forces are thus being forced to

Speaker: NA
Text: a position of reacting to the South Viet-

Speaker: NA
Text: namese rather than being able to fight at a

Speaker: NA
Text: time and place of their own choosing.

Speaker: NA
Text: Turning to the overall security of South

Speaker: NA
Text: Vietnam, it is undeniable that there has

Speaker: NA
Text: been satisfactory progress towards the

Speaker: NA
Text: objective of establishing the circumstances

Speaker: NA
Text: in which South Vietnam can determine its

Speaker: NA
Text: own future. There remain, of course,

Speaker: NA
Text: difficulties which should not be minimised.

Speaker: NA
Text: The North Vietnamese at the Paris talks

Speaker: NA
Text: have remained intransigent. Nothing con-

Speaker: NA
Text: structive has been offered by them towards

Speaker: NA
Text: a negotiated settlement. In Vietnam itself

Speaker: NA
Text: there has been some resurgence in Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munist terrorism, political agitation, and

Speaker: NA
Text: attacks against lines of communication.

Speaker: NA
Text: These tactics by the Communists, using

Speaker: NA
Text: their remaining infrastructure in the

Speaker: NA
Text: country, will doubtless be employed

Speaker: NA
Text: have against the Government and people for

Speaker: NA
Text: some time to come.

Speaker: NA
Text: ln its weighing up of the overall situa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, the Government has. decided that fur-

Speaker: NA
Text: ther reductions of the Australian forces in

Speaker: NA
Text: Vietnam are feasible and desirable. With

Speaker: NA
Text: the agreement of the Government of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Republic of Vietnam, and following con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sultations with United States military auth-

Speaker: NA
Text: orities in Saigon, some forces will now be

Speaker: NA
Text: withdrawn. These are:

Speaker: NA
Text: Selected - combat and -supporting forces

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Army task force,- including the

Speaker: NA
Text: tank squadron, totalling about 650

Speaker: NA
Text: Royal Australian Navy., personnel, about

Speaker: NA
Text: 45 in number, serving with the United

Speaker: NA
Text: States Assault Helicopter Company;

Speaker: NA
Text: The RAN Clearance. Diving Team

Speaker: NA
Text: (clearance of underwater explosives)

Speaker: NA
Text: of 6 personnel;

Speaker: NA
Text: No. 2 Canberra . Bomber Squadron

Speaker: NA
Text: involving 280 men; - ;

Speaker: NA
Text: Some aircraft of the;Caribou transport

Speaker: NA
Text: squadron and about 44 men.

Speaker: NA
Text: The reductions are therefore to be

Speaker: NA
Text: spread over the 3 Services and will have

Speaker: NA
Text: the effect of reducing the tolai Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: personnel by about 1,000" men: The Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian forces then remaining in South

Speaker: NA
Text: Vietnam will comprise 6,(300 men com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pared with a peak of 8,000 .'in 1968-70. All

Speaker: NA
Text: these remaining forces, including the 2-bat-

Speaker: NA
Text: talion Task Force in Phuoc Tuy, will

Speaker: NA
Text: retain an effective operational capability.

Speaker: NA
Text: The tasks of our forces' will continue to

Speaker: NA
Text: change as the Vietnamese territorial forces

Speaker: NA
Text: accept increased operational, responsibility.

Speaker: NA
Text: The units and personnel, involved in these

Speaker: NA
Text: reductions will be withdrawn gradually

Speaker: NA
Text: over a period of 4 months to 6 months,

Speaker: NA
Text: commencing in May. This timetable will

Speaker: NA
Text: permit detailed adjustments to be made

Speaker: NA
Text: between the Australian, South Vietnamese,

Speaker: NA
Text: and United States military, authorities in

Speaker: NA
Text: relation to the security requirements of the

Speaker: NA
Text: areas involved.

Speaker: NA
Text: Events in South Vietnam,., to which our

Speaker: NA
Text: own fighting men made such a notable

Speaker: NA
Text: contribution, have made these withdrawals

Speaker: NA
Text: possible and they are entirely in accor-

Speaker: NA
Text: dance with the policy of the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: as announced in Parliament. It must be

Speaker: NA
Text: acknowledged that enemy forces in Indo-

Speaker: NA
Text: China still retain a considerable offensive

Speaker: NA
Text: capability, and there remains in South

Speaker: NA
Text: Vietnam a structure of Vietcong cadres

Speaker: NA
Text: and guerillas which has been long estab-

Speaker: NA
Text: lished and whose strength is very difficult

Speaker: NA
Text: to assess. No doubt the Government and

Speaker: NA
Text: forces of the Republic may from time to

Speaker: NA
Text: time suffer military setbacks, and the con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tinuance of the war against aggression will

Speaker: NA
Text: be a heavy burden upon them. But perhaps

Speaker: NA
Text: more than ever before, the Government of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Republic acknowledges that getting on

Speaker: NA
Text: top of the internal threat to security and

Speaker: NA
Text: the development of progressive government

Speaker: NA
Text: in the provinces are tasks best performed

Speaker: NA
Text: by themselves once a sufficient degree of

Speaker: NA
Text: security from massive external attack has

Speaker: NA
Text: been established. Greater confidence now

Speaker: NA
Text: exists. The Vietnamese authorities have

Speaker: NA
Text: developed a variety of programmes which

Speaker: NA
Text: are becoming increasingly effective in

Speaker: NA
Text: bringing better administration in the

Speaker: NA
Text: tryside. The Australian Government will

Speaker: NA
Text: continue to assist the Republic of Vietnam,

Speaker: NA
Text: though the character of our assistance will

Speaker: NA
Text: progressively change. For example, the

Speaker: NA
Text: new Jungle Warfare Training Centre at

Speaker: NA
Text: Nui Dat has just completed its first course.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian economic and military aid in a

Speaker: NA
Text: variety of forms will continue. We will

Speaker: NA
Text: continue to build houses for members of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Territorial Forces and their families.

Speaker: NA
Text: Other forms of civil aid and civic action

Speaker: NA
Text: will be examined by the Government. As

Speaker: NA
Text: to the future of our forces in Vietnam, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government will keep the matter under

Speaker: NA
Text: constant review, bearing in mind the secu-

Speaker: NA
Text: rity of our own forces and our obligations

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Government of the Republic of

Speaker: NA
Text: Vietnam.

Speaker: Mr WHITLAM
Text: Werriwa-Leader of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition)-b y leave-Th e new

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister ( Mr MCMahon), is the last

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australia's leading guilty men of Viet-

Speaker: NA
Text: nam. With the Postmaster-General ( Sir

Speaker: NA
Text: Alan Hulme), he alone survives of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Menzies Government which committed

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia to this disastrous, divisive war.

Speaker: NA
Text: He was one of the architects; he remains

Speaker: NA
Text: chief apologist. He and Sir Keith Holyoake

Speaker: NA
Text: are the only heads of government who

Speaker: NA
Text: have participated at every stage in the

Speaker: NA
Text: escalation of the war. But Sir Keith

Speaker: NA
Text: Holyoake at least has the grace to stop

Speaker: NA
Text: tifying it.

Speaker: NA
Text: The commitment itself, ill-conceived as

Speaker: NA
Text: it was, has not been the worst aspect of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Government's baleful role

Speaker: NA
Text: in this vast, interminable tragedy. At every

Speaker: NA
Text: stage in this war the Australian Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment-th e Menzies Government, the Holt

Speaker: NA
Text: Government, the Gorton Government-ha s

Speaker: NA
Text: used whatever influence it had to enlarge

Speaker: NA
Text: and lo prolong the war. No government or

Speaker: NA
Text: administration has been so consistent or

Speaker: NA
Text: more malign. Even the Johnson Adminis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tration stopped the bombing of North

Speaker: NA
Text: Vietnam. This Government was supporting

Speaker: NA
Text: such bombing to the bitter end. The John-

Speaker: NA
Text: son Administration started negotiations and

Speaker: NA
Text: included the National Liberation Front in

Speaker: NA
Text: those negotiations. Four successive Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian Prime Ministers denounced the very

Speaker: NA
Text: concept of negotiations.

Speaker: NA
Text: The present Prime Minister was the

Speaker: NA
Text: most trenchant in his denunciations. It was

Speaker: NA
Text: coun- left to the present Prime Minister in

Speaker: NA
Text: November 1967 to denounce as treason

Speaker: NA
Text: proposals which were accepted in part by

Speaker: NA
Text: the United States in March 1968 and in

Speaker: NA
Text: whole by November 1968. Of all these

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Ministers he has been the hottest in

Speaker: NA
Text: his optimism and the coldest in his percep-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of what this war has meant in human

Speaker: NA
Text: terms-i n terms of scorched earth and

Speaker: NA
Text: scorched bodies, in terms of the devas-

Speaker: NA
Text: tation of the whole of Indo-China, in terms

Speaker: NA
Text: of the destruction of one of the proudest

Speaker: NA
Text: civilisations in the region and in terms of

Speaker: NA
Text: the degradation of an entire generation of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Vietnamese people. One can go

Speaker: NA
Text: through all his speeches-h e has made

Speaker: NA
Text: many on this subject-ye t not find one

Speaker: NA
Text: word to indicate the slightest conception,

Speaker: NA
Text: compassion or compunction about what we

Speaker: NA
Text: are doing to a whole race of human

Speaker: NA
Text: beings. On the contrary, to him such ques-

Speaker: NA
Text: tioning and such doubts were treason. He

Speaker: NA
Text: remains unrepentant, defiant to the last. In

Speaker: NA
Text: November 1967 he was predicting victory

Speaker: NA
Text: just around the corner. In March 1968,

Speaker: NA
Text: just after the Tet offensive, he was one of

Speaker: NA
Text: those who claimed that this had been a

Speaker: NA
Text: great setback to the Vietcong because they

Speaker: NA
Text: its had over-extended and exhausted them-

Speaker: NA
Text: selves. As Minister for Foreign Affairs he

Speaker: NA
Text: endorsed the inruption into Cambodia. As

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister a fortnight ago he was

Speaker: NA
Text: claiming victory in Laos. His reaction to

Speaker: NA
Text: justhese events shows that, even after a dec-

Speaker: NA
Text: ade of blood and blunders, he and his gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment are incapable of learning the les-

Speaker: NA
Text: son of Vietnam and are wilfully blind to

Speaker: NA
Text: the nature of this war. They still see this

Speaker: NA
Text: struggle solely in military terms. They still

Speaker: NA
Text: seek the mirage of military victory.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Prime Minister has made a state-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment which continues the tradition of

Speaker: NA
Text: deceit which has characterised this war.

Speaker: NA
Text: continues the charade that the disposition

Speaker: NA
Text: of our forces is related to the military

Speaker: NA
Text: ation in the Province of Phuoc Tuy. This

Speaker: NA
Text: was a war conceived in deceit, nurtured in

Speaker: NA
Text: deceit and it is ending in deceit. It is an

Speaker: NA
Text: appalling thing-appallin g for demo-

Speaker: NA
Text: cracy-whe n 70 per cent of the American

Speaker: NA
Text: people say that they no longer believe their

Speaker: NA
Text: Administration on Vietnam. Yet the Amer-

Speaker: NA
Text: ican Administration has been infinitely

Speaker: NA
Text: more truthful with its people than any of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian governments since 1965.

Speaker: NA
Text: Brigadier Serong, formerly with the Task

Speaker: NA
Text: Porce in Vietnam, told the truth when he

Speaker: NA
Text: said in Canberra in January that the role

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Australian Army in Vietnam had

Speaker: NA
Text: always been political. Politics determined

Speaker: NA
Text: our going in and politics are determining

Speaker: NA
Text: our coming out.

Speaker: NA
Text: Politics sent in the first battalion in

Speaker: NA
Text: 1965. The political situation in Australia,

Speaker: NA
Text: not the military situation in Phuoc Tuy,

Speaker: NA
Text: decided Mr Holt on a second escalation of

Speaker: NA
Text: our commitment in 1966 and a third esca-

Speaker: NA
Text: lation in 1967. It was the political situation

Speaker: NA
Text: of February 1968 that induced the present

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Defence ( Mr Gorton), then

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister, to announce immediately

Speaker: NA
Text: after the Tet offensive that no more troops

Speaker: NA
Text: would be sent to Vietnam. It was the politi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cal situation in 1969 that persuaded him

Speaker: NA
Text: to say that it must be one out all out, that

Speaker: NA
Text: a phased withdrawal, as I proposed, would

Speaker: NA
Text: endanger the lives of the troops remaining.

Speaker: Mr MORRISON
Text: Wh o said that?

Speaker: Mr WHITLAM
Text: Th e immediate past

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister, the present Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Defence. It was the political situation of

Speaker: NA
Text: 1970 that forced him to announce that the

Speaker: NA
Text: withdrawal would, after all, be piecemeal.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is the political situation, not the situ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ation in Phuoc Tuy Province or Vietnam or

Speaker: NA
Text: Indo-China, that has prescribed the terms

Speaker: NA
Text: of the announcement today by the new

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister. And it will be the political

Speaker: NA
Text: situation of 1972 that will spell the end of

Speaker: NA
Text: our commitment altogether. Never in its

Speaker: NA
Text: history has the Australian Army been so

Speaker: NA
Text: shamefully treated. It is a remarkable trib-

Speaker: NA
Text: ute to the honour of the Australian Army

Speaker: NA
Text: that it has so steadfastly served so dishon-

Speaker: NA
Text: ourable a government, so disgraceful a

Speaker: NA
Text: policy.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Prime Minister's statement contains

Speaker: NA
Text: perhaps the most disturbing indication of

Speaker: NA
Text: policy since the commitment. For the

Speaker: NA
Text: alarming fact is that the forces remaining

Speaker: NA
Text: situin Vietnam are being endangered for

Speaker: NA
Text: reasons of sheer political expediency. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Government proposes to achieve a statis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tical reduction in the number of personnel

Speaker: NA
Text: in Vietnam; that is the minimum reduction

Speaker: NA
Text: required by the politics of Vietnam. It

Speaker: NA
Text: proposes to do this by trimming the sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: port for the 2 combat battalions remaining.

Speaker: NA
Text: A force of 2 battalions is itself

Speaker: NA
Text: dangerously unbalanced. Their security

Speaker: NA
Text: requires more, not less, support. The force

Speaker: NA
Text: is now dangerously exposed, more so than

Speaker: NA
Text: at any time since it arrived in Vietnam. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is folly to believe that the reduced level of

Speaker: NA
Text: Vietcong activity in Phuoc Tuy Province

Speaker: NA
Text: means long term security for Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: forces there. We delude ourselves if we

Speaker: NA
Text: think that this reduced activity in Phuoc

Speaker: NA
Text: Tuy and throughout South Vietnam is sole-

Speaker: NA
Text: May ly the result of allied superiority over the

Speaker: NA
Text: Vietcong forces. It is also, the result of a de-

Speaker: NA
Text: cision by the Vietcong and Hanoi them-

Speaker: NA
Text: selves. They will not undertake military

Speaker: NA
Text: actions which would pave the effect of

Speaker: NA
Text: seriously slowing down or reversing the

Speaker: NA
Text: American withdrawal., Hanoi , and Washing-

Speaker: NA
Text: ton are in unspoken accord on this point-

Speaker: NA
Text: that the American withdrawal must go on

Speaker: NA
Text: as rapidly as possible. The Australian Gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment is placing our troops in a position

Speaker: NA
Text: of dependence on decisions of their adver-

Speaker: NA
Text: saries. If it suits the enemy to raise the

Speaker: NA
Text: level of activity in Phuoc Tuy, they can do

Speaker: NA
Text: it and they will do it. at a time when our

Speaker: NA
Text: troops have been rendered most vulner-

Speaker: NA
Text: able. This Government is placing Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian soldiers in jeopardy.

Speaker: NA
Text: The extent to which. political consider-

Speaker: NA
Text: ations are deciding the Australian Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment's actions in Vietnam are exposed by

Speaker: NA
Text: the phoney preliminaries .of this announce-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment-th e Minister for Defence's farcical

Speaker: NA
Text: visit to Vietnam. His, predecessor was

Speaker: NA
Text: booked to go to Vietnam for 10 days, so

Speaker: NA
Text: he went for 4. His predecessor had created

Speaker: NA
Text: a Cabinet convulsion because of allegations

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Army had unilaterally decided tp

Speaker: NA
Text: curtail civil aid; so the new Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Defence, having himself chosen that port-

Speaker: NA
Text: folio to give the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Wannon ( Mr Malcolm Fraser) a slap in

Speaker: NA
Text: the face, pointedly spent most of his time

Speaker: NA
Text: inspecting our civil aid projects. Does

Speaker: NA
Text: body believe that today's announcement

Speaker: NA
Text: owes anything to such insights or know-

Speaker: NA
Text: ledge as the Minister for Defence may

Speaker: NA
Text: have gained in his 4 days in Vietnam?

Speaker: NA
Text: Nothing so fully epitomises the whole

Speaker: NA
Text: approach of this Government to the Viet-

Speaker: NA
Text: nam commitment from its inception.

Speaker: NA
Text: Nothing so fully epitomises the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment's total lack of understanding of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Indo-China catastrophe as fhe Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Defence's statements on the operation in

Speaker: NA
Text: Laos. His considered judgment was that

Speaker: NA
Text: the operation had been, and. I quote his

Speaker: NA
Text: very words: 'about four times as successful

Speaker: NA
Text: as the Press had made out'.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ever since the war began to go sour, its

Speaker: NA
Text: sponsors have blamed the Press. In fact all

Speaker: NA
Text: that has happened is that the Press could

Speaker: NA
Text: not for ever suppress the realities of this

Speaker: NA
Text: war. This is what fhe Australian Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment resents. It resents that Indo-China

Speaker: NA
Text: refuses to fit into its own preconceptions

Speaker: NA
Text: and preoccupations or, as the Prime Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter himself pnt it last year when as Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter for External Affairs he was speaking on

Speaker: NA
Text: Cambodia: 'it does not readily fit into my

Speaker: NA
Text: framework'. In Australia and overwhelm-

Speaker: NA
Text: ingly in the Australian Press the war did

Speaker: NA
Text: initially enjoy a great deal of support. This

Speaker: NA
Text: was based not only on. the natural patrio-

Speaker: NA
Text: tism of the Australian people but on a

Speaker: NA
Text: predisposition to believe that their govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment would tell the truth. People in a

Speaker: NA
Text: democracy are reluctant to think that their

Speaker: NA
Text: elected government is party to lies and

Speaker: NA
Text: deception, particularly in matters involving

Speaker: NA
Text: the Armed Forces and the nation's security.

Speaker: NA
Text: In 1965 rhe people were inclined to

Speaker: NA
Text: accept that our commitment was justified,

Speaker: NA
Text: not to say required, by the American alli-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance. The Government sold its case on the

Speaker: NA
Text: basis that America would be strengthened

Speaker: NA
Text: in our region and that our commitment

Speaker: NA
Text: would strengthen the alliance. Now of

Speaker: NA
Text: course people have had it brought home to

Speaker: NA
Text: them that, as a result of Vietnam, the

Speaker: NA
Text: United States will never again intervene on

Speaker: NA
Text: land in Asia and that the American Con-

Speaker: NA
Text: gress and people are bitterly resentful of

Speaker: NA
Text: those who they believe inveigled them into

Speaker: NA
Text: this imbroglio which has deeply divided

Speaker: NA
Text: their country', 'alienated their youth;

Speaker: NA
Text: demoralised their army and disrupted their

Speaker: NA
Text: economy.

Speaker: NA
Text: This has been the end result of Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia's conduct as far as the United States

Speaker: NA
Text: any- is concerned. All these negative results

Speaker: NA
Text: have been achieved at the price of the dev-

Speaker: NA
Text: astation of Indo-China. We are leaving

Speaker: NA
Text: Vietnam; but what are we leaving? By pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: longing the war we have put a political

Speaker: NA
Text: solution further and further away and

Speaker: NA
Text: made a political solution more and more

Speaker: NA
Text: difficult ever to achieve. Our real military

Speaker: NA
Text: achievement has been to raise the level of

Speaker: NA
Text: violence to unprecedented heights. Three

Speaker: NA
Text: times the weight of bombs have been

Speaker: NA
Text: dropped as were dropped in the Second

Speaker: NA
Text: World War. In a kind of unholy alliance

Speaker: NA
Text: with Russia and China, we have provided

Speaker: NA
Text: the 2 Vietnams with almost limitless capac-

Speaker: NA
Text: ity for mutual self-destruction. We are

Speaker: NA
Text: leaving 2 of the world's largest armies to

Speaker: NA
Text: confront each other. We have exchanged a

Speaker: NA
Text: neutral ancl peaceful Cambodia for war

Speaker: NA
Text: and chaos. In Laos we have undermined

Speaker: NA
Text: the neutralist settlement of 1962. In South

Speaker: NA
Text: Vietnam itself we are leaving a regime

Speaker: NA
Text: which carries within itself the seeds of

Speaker: NA
Text: inevitable failure. Even if the Thieu regime

Speaker: NA
Text: were reformist or democratic, it has 2

Speaker: NA
Text: insuperable disqualifications for genuine

Speaker: NA
Text: support in that country. It is a regime visi-

Speaker: NA
Text: bly dependant on outside support-foreig n

Speaker: NA
Text: support-i n a country with a thousand

Speaker: NA
Text: years' history of rebellion against foreign

Speaker: NA
Text: dominance. Secondly, it is committed to, it

Speaker: NA
Text: in fact embodies, the concept of keeping

Speaker: NA
Text: Vietnam divided. This is an impossible

Speaker: NA
Text: basis for popular support in any nation,

Speaker: NA
Text: much less a nation with the history of

Speaker: NA
Text: Vietnam. What we have done in Vietnam

Speaker: NA
Text: is to give the Communists a monopoly of

Speaker: NA
Text: the issues of nationalism, independence

Speaker: NA
Text: and unity.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Australian Government now has no

Speaker: NA
Text: recognisable or achievable war aims in

Speaker: NA
Text: Vietnam. It has no influence on events in

Speaker: NA
Text: Vietnam. It has no role in Vietnam. Viet-

Speaker: NA
Text: namisation is not a solution or a settlement-

Speaker: NA
Text: for Vietnam; it is the means the United

Speaker: NA
Text: States has chosen to secure the withdrawal

Speaker: NA
Text: of her combat forces. The justification

Speaker: NA
Text: President Nixon has given for expanding

Speaker: NA
Text: the war into Cambodia and Laos is that it

Speaker: NA
Text: was necessary to ensure the safe with-

Speaker: NA
Text: drawal of American troops. However

Speaker: NA
Text: much we may deplore the means, let us at

Speaker: NA
Text: least accept the aim-th e safest, quickest

Speaker: NA
Text: withdrawal. The method chosen by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Government is neither quick

Speaker: NA
Text: nor safe. It is monstrous that Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: lives should be endangered simply because

Speaker: NA
Text: this Government refuses to admit its folly.

Speaker: NA
Text: How long must the courage of Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: soldiers be used to cover ihe cowardice of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Ministers?

Text: Therefore, I am very concerned with anyScience

Text: thing that happens in the dried fruits the world market.

Speaker: NA
Text: industry. I am most happy with the Dried

Speaker: NA
Text: Fruits Research Bill which has been

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: ture and the Australian Dried Fruits Associ-

Text: ation and which is generally accepted by opment

Speaker: NA
Text: growers. I would like to make one or two greater

Text: remarks. I do not want to repeat what has crops.

Text: been said by the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Dawson for I am always a great co-operatries

Speaker: NA
Text: tor if I get the opportunity. It is only

Speaker: NA
Text: I think that what has been said by some

Text: members is not right that I try to put them

Text: right, but never in a personal way.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Bill is in line with the normal

Speaker: NA
Text: Government procedure of providing matchabout

Speaker: NA
Text: ing contributions on a $1 for $1 basis to

Text: meet expenditure on approved research

Speaker: NA
Text: projects. One thing about the Bill with

Text: staff there numbers 70. It has an annual

Speaker: NA
Text: budget of about $500,000. The station has

Speaker: NA
Text: been operating for 50 years. The people

Speaker: NA
Text: of the area are quite rightly very proud of

Text: economically, did point tlie way to an

Speaker: NA
Text: social and economic as well . . .

Text: ways research bad helped the dried fruits
