Text: Generally speaking, in all primary indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: throughout Australia there has been

Speaker: NA
Text: when some research, more in some industries

Speaker: NA
Text: than in others. The Australian dried fruits

Speaker: NA
Text: industry is one which requires continual

Speaker: NA
Text: research, perhaps more than any other

Speaker: NA
Text: industry. I think I am right in saying that

Speaker: NA
Text: 50 years ago the research station of

Speaker: NA
Text: the CSIRO at Merbein started to operate

Speaker: NA
Text: because of an outbreak of fungus black

Speaker: NA
Text: spot. The station has been operating ever

Speaker: NA
Text: since. Black spot and all sorts of pests

Speaker: NA
Text: have cut down the volume and the quality

Speaker: NA
Text: of dried fruits. This Bill, in addition to

Speaker: NA
Text: what the CSIRO and the State departments

Speaker: NA
Text: of agriculture do, will add greatly to effec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tiveness by showing growers how they can

Speaker: NA
Text: overcome at least what is possible to over-

Speaker: NA
Text: come of the menaces that sap the dried

Speaker: NA
Text: fruits industry of its economic wealth.

Speaker: NA
Text: The dried fruits industry is a very great

Speaker: NA
Text: export industry. I refer to the 'Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Handbook' for 1971 which points out that

Speaker: NA
Text: from 1930 to 1939 the dried fruits produc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion averaged 70,000 tons and for the

Speaker: NA
Text: seasons from 1950 tr> 1959 the average was

Speaker: NA
Text: 78,389. It is necessary to have irrigation

Speaker: NA
Text: for growing grapes for dried fruits. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Handbook points out that the irrigated

Speaker: NA
Text: areas produced 85,000 tons of dried vine

Speaker: NA
Text: fruits in the 1967-68 season, and 67,000

Speaker: NA
Text: tons of these were exported. The 1968-69

Speaker: NA
Text: crop was severely affected by heavy rain

Speaker: NA
Text: and was 40 per cent below average. This

Speaker: NA
Text: year again the crop is very low, I am sorry

Speaker: NA
Text: to say. Growers are concerned about the

Speaker: NA
Text: general prospects. I have kept in close

Speaker: NA
Text: touch with the industry, which is situated

Speaker: NA
Text: chiefly in the Mallee electorate. I have cor-

Speaker: NA
Text: responded with people when I could not

Speaker: NA
Text: visit them due to my attendance in tbis

Speaker: NA
Text: chamber.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honourable member for Dawson

Speaker: NA
Text: spoke about stabilisation. I think that any

Speaker: NA
Text: primary industry that is not stabilised is

Speaker: NA
Text: out of touch with reality. A number of

Speaker: NA
Text: years ago the stabilisation of the dried

Speaker: NA
Text: fruits industry was started and ran for

Speaker: NA
Text: quite a period. As has been stated, about

Speaker: NA
Text: 12 months ago or a little more the growers

Speaker: NA
Text: in a poll refused to give their approval to

Speaker: NA
Text: the stabilisation plan that was put forward

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Government. I think that 65 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent of the growers voted for it and about

Speaker: NA
Text: 35 per cent against it. A statutory number

Speaker: NA
Text: of votes was required, not just a simple

Speaker: NA
Text: majority, so the stabilisation plan suggested

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Government on that occasion

Speaker: NA
Text: lapsed. I would like the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Primary Industry ( Mr Sinclair) when he is

Speaker: NA
Text: replying in this debate to give some esti-

Speaker: NA
Text: mate of what the dried fruits industry

Speaker: NA
Text: might have lost by not supporting stabilisa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. It has been stated, that there has been

Speaker: NA
Text: a split in the dried fruits industry. This is

Speaker: NA
Text: right to a certain extent, but it is right

Speaker: NA
Text: only in relation to that vote, because cer-

Speaker: NA
Text: tain people in the industry advised growers

Speaker: NA
Text: to vote against the proposition.

Speaker: NA
Text: The greatest trouble was the apathy of

Speaker: NA
Text: growers who thought that the proposal

Speaker: NA
Text: would be carried quite easily and did not

Speaker: NA
Text: vote at all. 1 know that the Minister has

Speaker: NA
Text: had long and serious discussions with rep-

Speaker: NA
Text: resentatives of the ADFA. 1 hope-h e may

Speaker: NA
Text: tell us this-tha t he is reaching a stage

Speaker: NA
Text: where another proposition for stabilisation

Speaker: NA
Text: will be submitted to the growers. It is my

Speaker: NA
Text: prediction that this time they will not let it

Speaker: NA
Text: pass by. They will vote for it and so will

Speaker: NA
Text: have stabilisation. I regard the dried fruits

Speaker: NA
Text: industry as one of the most precarious

Speaker: NA
Text: industries of all. First of all the crop is

Speaker: NA
Text: supposed to show a certain production.

Speaker: NA
Text: The growers say that the sugar has come

Speaker: NA
Text: down into it. It is sometimes hard to get

Speaker: NA
Text: pickers. When the grower does get pickers

Speaker: NA
Text: and the crop is picked and put on the

Speaker: NA
Text: racks, his troubles usually continue. The

Speaker: NA
Text: grower does not know what his return will

Speaker: NA
Text: be even when the crop is in the packing

Speaker: NA
Text: shed for then there is the situation with

Speaker: NA
Text: markets and the world conditions.

Speaker: NA
Text: The reasonable attitude adopted by the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Dawson in this

Speaker: NA
Text: debate is appreciated. I support the Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: very strongly. The honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: said that in the Committee stages the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition will move 2 amendments. I

Speaker: NA
Text: shall wait to see what they are before I

Speaker: NA
Text: can comment on them. The growers rep-

Speaker: NA
Text: resentatives in negotiation with the Gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment and with all the Ministers of

Speaker: NA
Text: Agriculture have brought forward a Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: very acceptable to this Parliament and to

Speaker: NA
Text: that great primary producing unit, the

Speaker: NA
Text: dried fruits industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: I refer now to increased plantings. There

Speaker: NA
Text: is some concern in the dried fruits industry

Speaker: NA
Text: that increased plantings may bring about

Speaker: NA
Text: quantities of grapes, especially dried fruit

Speaker: NA
Text: grapes, that the growers may not be able

Speaker: NA
Text: to market. I do not want to say more

Speaker: NA
Text: about this, because the matter of increased

Speaker: NA
Text: plantings is definitely in the hands of the

Speaker: NA
Text: State governments. The Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: Government has nothing whatever to do

Speaker: NA
Text: with it and can perhaps only offer advice

Speaker: NA
Text: on the subject. It is not my idea to offer

Speaker: NA
Text: advice on it here today, but in my elector-

Speaker: NA
Text: ate I am always willing to meet people and

Speaker: NA
Text: discuss the matter with them. I support the

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill. 1 believe it will be in the best interests

Speaker: NA
Text: of the industry, of the exports that benefit

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, and of the Commonwealth gen-

Speaker: NA
Text: erally.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr FitzPATRICK (Darling) (4.49)- I

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot understand why the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Mallee ( Mr Turnbull) made a

Speaker: NA
Text: point of informing the House that he rep-

Speaker: NA
Text: resents more dried fruit growers than any

Speaker: NA
Text: other honourable member. Of course there

Speaker: NA
Text: are many fruit growers in my electorate.

Speaker: NA
Text: Whether they represent the largest number

Speaker: NA
Text: of fruit growers in any electorate does not

Speaker: NA
Text: seem to me to be the most important issue in

Speaker: NA
Text: this debate. Whether or not they represent

Speaker: NA
Text: the greatest number, they are entitled to

Speaker: NA
Text: good representation in this Parliament, and

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable members on this side of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House intend to see that they gel such repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sentation. Mention was made of the stabilis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ation scheme and the fact that some of the

Speaker: NA
Text: growers failed to vote on this very impor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tant issue. Of course, it is well known why

Speaker: NA
Text: they did not vote. It was because they

Speaker: NA
Text: were not satisfied with the proposition that

Speaker: NA
Text: was being put forward, and they wanted

Speaker: NA
Text: some say in the alteration of the proposi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. The honourable member for Mallee

Speaker: NA
Text: mentioned that a new stabilisation scheme

Speaker: NA
Text: has been considered. It is to be hoped that

Speaker: NA
Text: greater notice will be taken of the growers'

Speaker: NA
Text: opinion in the formulation of the new

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme and that greater consideration will

Speaker: NA
Text: be given to their wishes in the matter.

Speaker: NA
Text: I support in principle the establishment

Speaker: NA
Text: of rhe Dried Fruits Research Trust

Speaker: NA
Text: Account mentioned in the Dried Fruits

Speaker: NA
Text: Research Bill 1971. However, I consider

Speaker: NA
Text: that many of the clauses of the Bill are

Speaker: NA
Text: obnoxious in that they fail to guarantee the

Speaker: NA
Text: grower any real representation on the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: posed Dried Fruits Research Committee.

Speaker: NA
Text: These clauses must create the impression

Speaker: NA
Text: in the grower's mind that he will have

Speaker: NA
Text: little or no say regarding the direction that

Speaker: NA
Text: research will take. Clause 11 states:

Speaker: NA
Text: The Committee shall consist of-

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) four persons to represent the organisation

Speaker: NA
Text: known as the Australian Dried Fruits

Speaker: NA
Text: Association;

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) two persons to represent the packers of

Speaker: NA
Text: dried fruits;

Speaker: NA
Text: (c) three persons to represent the organisation

Speaker: NA
Text: known as the Australian Agricultural

Speaker: NA
Text: CouncU;

Speaker: NA
Text: (d) one person to represent the CommonweaUh

Speaker: NA
Text: Scienlific and Industrial Research OrganisaThe

Speaker: NA
Text: tion: and

Speaker: NA
Text: (e) one person to represent the Department of

Speaker: NA
Text: Primary Industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: In other words, on the Committee, there is

Speaker: NA
Text: not to be direct representation of the dried

Speaker: NA
Text: fruit grower; yet he is the one most depen-

Speaker: NA
Text: dent on the results of research. It is evi-

Speaker: NA
Text: dent from the wording of the Dried Fruits

Speaker: NA
Text: Levy Bill that this Government, irrespec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive of its wishes regarding the composition

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Committee, leaves no doubt which

Speaker: NA
Text: group it thinks should pay the piper. Of

Speaker: NA
Text: course this is not any of the groups men-

Speaker: NA
Text: tioned in the clause relating to the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: position of the Committee. These groups

Speaker: NA
Text: will have all the say about where the

Speaker: NA
Text: research will take place, who shall be

Speaker: NA
Text: trained for the purpose of such research,

Speaker: NA
Text: and the publication of reports, periodicals,

Speaker: NA
Text: books and papers in connection with such

Speaker: NA
Text: research. As far as the grower is concerned

Speaker: NA
Text: everything is done in an indirect manner in

Speaker: NA
Text: regard to the dried fruits research. Until

Speaker: NA
Text: we reach the point at which it is decided

Speaker: NA
Text: who should pay the levy lo support the

Speaker: NA
Text: Dried Fruits Research Committee's

Speaker: NA
Text: expenses and the expenses involved in car-

Speaker: NA
Text: rying out its decisions, it is very indirect.

Speaker: NA
Text: But from this point on the Bill leaves no

Speaker: NA
Text: doubt that it is the grower who is expected

Speaker: NA
Text: to pay. Clause 5(1.) of the Dried Fruits

Speaker: NA
Text: Levy Collection Bill is one of the most vis-

Speaker: NA
Text: cious clauses in that Bill. It states:

Speaker: NA
Text: . . . levy on dried fruits of a season received

Speaker: NA
Text: for packing on or before the thirtieth day of Sep-

Speaker: NA
Text: tember in that season is due for payment on the

Speaker: NA
Text: thirtieth day of November in that season.

Speaker: NA
Text: This means that the grower, who at pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sent is badly in need of credit and often

Speaker: NA
Text: has to wait more than 2 years to receive

Speaker: NA
Text: payment for his dried fruiis, is now

Speaker: NA
Text: expected to pay this extra levy in 3

Speaker: NA
Text: months. If he cannot pay the levy in 3

Speaker: NA
Text: months he then has to pay interest on the

Speaker: NA
Text: amount to the extent of 10 per cent per

Speaker: NA
Text: annum. It appears to me that whoever

Speaker: NA
Text: drew up this Bill gave little or DO consider-

Speaker: NA
Text: ation to the very serious economic, situa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of the dried fruit industry. The Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: provides ample protection for the packers.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is given in swch clauses as clause 9 of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Dried Fruits Levy Collection Bill,

Speaker: NA
Text: which states:

Speaker: NA
Text: Where the packer of any dried fruits received

Speaker: NA
Text: for packing has paid a levy on those dried fruits,

Speaker: NA
Text: he is entitled lo recover the amount of that levy

Speaker: NA
Text: from the grower of the dried fruits as a debt due

Speaker: NA
Text: to the packer from thc grower.

Speaker: NA
Text: Government is also protected because

Speaker: NA
Text: not only is the interest rate on unpaid levy

Speaker: NA
Text: 10 per cent but the grower Ls also liable to

Speaker: NA
Text: a fine of $200. if he fails or neglects to

Speaker: NA
Text: furnish a return or information that he is

Speaker: NA
Text: required under the regulations to furnish.

Speaker: NA
Text: This provision can be found in clause 11

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Dried Fruits Levy Collection Bill.

Speaker: NA
Text: In addition, a prosecution for an offence

Speaker: NA
Text: against this proposed section may be com-

Speaker: NA
Text: menced at any time within 5 years after

Speaker: NA
Text: the commission of the offence. This clause

Speaker: NA
Text: will be the subject of the amendment we

Speaker: NA
Text: have foreshadowed in the Committee stage.

Speaker: NA
Text: I believe that the whole spirit of this

Speaker: NA
Text: takes no cognisance of the grave economic

Speaker: NA
Text: position of the dried fruits industry. It does

Speaker: NA
Text: not consider what is to happen to the

Speaker: NA
Text: grower who pays the levy. The products

Speaker: NA
Text: have to pass inspection to ensure that the

Speaker: NA
Text: citrus, dried or canned fruits are whole-

Speaker: NA
Text: some and fit for consumption; that they

Speaker: NA
Text: will in fact conform to specifications. Bu:

Speaker: NA
Text: when the producer makes a purchase of

Speaker: NA
Text: pesticide or spray chemical he receives no

Speaker: NA
Text: such guarantee of effectiveness. As has

Speaker: NA
Text: already been mentioned in this Parliament,

Speaker: NA
Text: a particular case is that of citrus red scale.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is nil tolerance for rod scale on cit-

Speaker: NA
Text: rus fruit packed for export. The grower is

Speaker: NA
Text: forced to spray the fruit nr his fruit will

Speaker: NA
Text: not be accepted. Yet grower-financed tests

Speaker: NA
Text: have shown that of 20-odd brands of a

Speaker: NA
Text: recommended chemical onlv one will con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sistently kill red scale. There i.s no Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment inspectorial service in m..s field, and

Speaker: NA
Text: yet many of the growers say that spray

Speaker: NA
Text: chemical bills exceed their net taxable

Speaker: NA
Text: income.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the production of sultanas it is well

Speaker: NA
Text: known that prices are low and costs are

Speaker: NA
Text: high. The seemingly obvious answer is to

Speaker: NA
Text: produce more tons per acre. The growers'

Speaker: NA
Text: organisation already contributes a large

Speaker: NA
Text: sum towards research into better root

Speaker: NA
Text: stocks and high producing cones for graft-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing on to them. I am told that they are

Speaker: NA
Text: now available for planting in Mildura, bu!

Speaker: NA
Text: a. man-made rule decrees that vines

Speaker: NA
Text: certified in Victoria may not be planted in

Speaker: NA
Text: South Australia. The whole of this

Speaker: NA
Text: research must be duplicated in South Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia, and while the grower waits there

Speaker: NA
Text: comes the really serious blow. Growers

Speaker: NA
Text: completely new to the industry are taking

Speaker: NA
Text: the improved varieties and planting large

Speaker: NA
Text: areas further upstream. While the present

Speaker: NA
Text: production is already in excess of demand,

Speaker: NA
Text: of course this can only depress further the

Speaker: NA
Text: present low prices. The new grower will

Speaker: NA
Text: survive because he is on virgin soil witb

Speaker: NA
Text: high per acre production. The struggling

Speaker: NA
Text: grower who paid for the research will not

Speaker: NA
Text: be able to afford to replant his property.

Speaker: NA
Text: What guarantee has the grower that the

Speaker: NA
Text: same sort of thing will not happen under

Speaker: NA
Text: this new Dried Fruits Research Act, when

Speaker: NA
Text: there is no reai protection written into the

Speaker: NA
Text: Act that directly concerns the grower? It

Speaker: NA
Text: must also be remembered that there comes

Speaker: NA
Text: a time when further increases in efficiency

Speaker: NA
Text: are just not possible due to limitations

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill imposed by high soil salinity and other

Speaker: NA
Text: matters. At this point the dried fruits

Speaker: NA
Text: grower can add to the size of his property

Speaker: NA
Text: or get out. Yet he is forced to pay a levy

Speaker: NA
Text: which will help others produce more and

Speaker: NA
Text: thus put him out of business more quickly.

Speaker: NA
Text: Due to his precarious credit position he is

Speaker: NA
Text: often unable to purchase the property next

Speaker: NA
Text: door so that he can increase, his production

Speaker: NA
Text: and allow a dignified retreat for his neigh-

Speaker: NA
Text: bour. Both continue to eke out an exis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tence on their increasingly unecpnomically-

Speaker: NA
Text: sized properties. At the same time they see

Speaker: NA
Text: Government support and encouragement

Speaker: NA
Text: given to new outside finance to come on

Speaker: NA
Text: new land and plant 200 acres pf apricots,

Speaker: NA
Text: 500 acres of citrus and nearly 1,000 acres

Speaker: NA
Text: of wine grapes.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the light of this it would .be reason-

Speaker: NA
Text: able to expect other sections ofthese Bills

Speaker: NA
Text: to assist the grower or give him a further

Speaker: NA
Text: say in the way in which the research will

Speaker: NA
Text: be directed. But this is not the case and it

Speaker: NA
Text: appears, as we look further into the

Speaker: NA
Text: clauses of the Bill, that less and less con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sideration seems to be given to the know-

Speaker: NA
Text: ledge, experience and wishes of the grow-

Speaker: NA
Text: er. To indicate this, let us examine section

Speaker: NA
Text: 11. (5.) of the Dried Fruits Research Trust

Speaker: NA
Text: Account Bill which says:

Speaker: NA
Text: Tbe appointment of a nominated member is not

Speaker: NA
Text: invalidated and shall not be called in question by

Speaker: NA
Text: reason of a defect or irregularity iri' connexion

Speaker: NA
Text: with his nomination -' - '

Speaker: NA
Text: Section 13. (I.) says:

Speaker: NA
Text: A membei may. with the approval of ihe

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister, appoint a person to be his deputy.1

Speaker: NA
Text: My point is that a member could be

Speaker: NA
Text: appointed to the Committee in 'spite of a

Speaker: NA
Text: defect or irregularity. Not only could he

Speaker: NA
Text: retain his seat in spite of this defect or

Speaker: NA
Text: irregularity; he could appoint as' his deputy

Speaker: NA
Text: someone else who was even less entitled to

Speaker: NA
Text: act on this Committee. If the member

Speaker: NA
Text: elected by defect or irregularity were the

Speaker: NA
Text: chairman of the Committee! his deputy

Speaker: NA
Text: could then act as chairman. In my opinion

Speaker: NA
Text: this is far outside the wishes of the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: ducer and shows a disregard for his wel-

Speaker: NA
Text: fare. These growers should have access to

Speaker: NA
Text: the best advice and advisers in the indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: try, people who should be able to make a

Speaker: NA
Text: decision for the grower and who are not

Speaker: NA
Text: influenced by any political leaning. These

Speaker: NA
Text: decisions should be made only after full

Speaker: NA
Text: consultation with the growers. The only

Speaker: NA
Text: conclusion that one can reach after a close

Speaker: NA
Text: study of these Bills is that they offer no

Speaker: NA
Text: signposts to the future but lay down plenty

Speaker: NA
Text: of controls and penalties for the grower

Speaker: NA
Text: who ts asked to pay the costs of their

Speaker: NA
Text: implementation.

Speaker: NA
Text: If this Government really wanted to

Speaker: NA
Text: help the dried fruit growers it would have

Speaker: NA
Text: introduced long before now the new dried

Speaker: NA
Text: fruits stabilisation scheme which has been

Speaker: NA
Text: talked about for so long. Also it would

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure that information already gathered

Speaker: NA
Text: by Government departments, such as

Speaker: NA
Text: departments of agriculture and the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth Scientific and Industrial

Speaker: NA
Text: Research Organisation, as mentioned by

Speaker: NA
Text: the honourable member for Mallee ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Turnbull), is available to all growers and

Speaker: NA
Text: not only those in areas that enjoy a rural

Speaker: NA
Text: broadcasting programme. During the last

Speaker: NA
Text: session both the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Mallee and the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Angas ( Mr Giles) made this point. They

Speaker: NA
Text: pointed out the great disadvantage that

Speaker: NA
Text: fruit growers in the Sunraysia area suffered

Speaker: NA
Text: because they did not have a rural broad-

Speaker: NA
Text: casting programme. It is not the intention

Speaker: NA
Text: of honourable members on this side of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House to oppose these Bills. However, we

Speaker: NA
Text: say that due regard should be given to

Speaker: NA
Text: some of these problems. The grower is

Speaker: NA
Text: entitled to be told that he is a part of any

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme claimed to have been introduced

Speaker: NA
Text: for his welfare. He is entitled to feel part

Speaker: NA
Text: of it. He can feel part of it only if he is

Speaker: NA
Text: given equal rights on the Committee and

Speaker: NA
Text: equal rights to say where research will take

Speaker: NA
Text: place. I hope honourable members opposite

Speaker: NA
Text: will give some consideration to these mat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ters.

Speaker: Mr GRASSBY
Text: Riverina) (5.06)- I rise

Speaker: NA
Text: with great pleasure to follow my colleague,

Speaker: NA
Text: the honourable member for Darling ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: FitzPatrick), who has given a masterly

Speaker: NA
Text: exposition of the problems that confront

Speaker: NA
Text: dried fruits growers at the present time. He

Speaker: NA
Text: has also dissected the legislation before us

Speaker: NA
Text: in a particularly commendable way. I am

Speaker: NA
Text: delighted to be able to follow the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member and pay him that compliment. I

Speaker: NA
Text: stand with him in the comments he made

Speaker: NA
Text: about the serious problems facing the dried

Speaker: NA
Text: fruits industry at the present time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Turnbull-Wha t about the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Dawson?

Speaker: Mr GRASSBY
Text: M y friend, the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Mallee interjects and

Speaker: NA
Text: asks me: 'What about the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Dawson?' I may say that

Speaker: NA
Text: the honourable member for Dawson (Dr

Speaker: NA
Text: Patterson) led for the Opposition in this

Speaker: NA
Text: debate and we on this side of the House

Speaker: NA
Text: are at one with him. There is no need

Speaker: NA
Text: for the honourable meniber for Mallee

Speaker: NA
Text: to be concerned with the Opposition; he

Speaker: NA
Text: shbuld apply himself to some of the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: blems facing the industry which are rather

Speaker: NA
Text: more urgent than was indicated by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Primary Industry ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Sinclair). I agree with the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Darling that it does not matter

Speaker: NA
Text: whether we have a greater or lesser number

Speaker: NA
Text: of growers. We stand with them and serve

Speaker: NA
Text: them to tbe best of our ability. The references

Speaker: NA
Text: the honourable member made to industry

Speaker: NA
Text: stabilisation are very much to the point.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is a desire in the industry generally

Speaker: NA
Text: to see a stabilisation programme, but the

Speaker: NA
Text: industry wants to see discussions continued

Speaker: NA
Text: not on the basis of the Government's

Speaker: NA
Text: edict of take it or leave it, whatever propo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sition is put forward by the Government, but

Speaker: NA
Text: on the basis of taking into account all the

Speaker: NA
Text: doubts, worries and concerns that my

Speaker: NA
Text: colleague mentioned in relation to stabilisa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion in the future. The honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: did a very fine service in referring to the

Speaker: NA
Text: need for regional broadcasting services. This

Speaker: NA
Text: is something that all honourable members,

Speaker: NA
Text: from both sides of the Murray, are con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cerned about, and I hope we will not lose

Speaker: NA
Text: sight of this need. It seems to me to be

Speaker: NA
Text: pretty disgraceful that in Australia at the

Speaker: NA
Text: present time there are areas in the South-

Speaker: NA
Text: east corner of the continent that just cannot

Speaker: NA
Text: get good radio reception. I am sure this is

Speaker: NA
Text: a problem in the Congo Republic but we

Speaker: NA
Text: do not expect it in Australia in 1971. How-

Speaker: NA
Text: ever, this is what we have got.

Speaker: NA
Text: In relation to the measures before us the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Primary Industry in his second

Speaker: NA
Text: reading speech did not seem to be fully

Speaker: NA
Text: seized with the seriousness of the problems

Speaker: NA
Text: the industry faces. Let me quote a fraction

Speaker: NA
Text: of his speech. He said:

Speaker: NA
Text: Dried fruit production is of considerable economic

Speaker: NA
Text: importance to the rural communities where these

Speaker: NA
Text: fruits are grown and exports of dried fruits con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tribute significantly to our export earnings.

Speaker: NA
Text: They are not just of considerable economic

Speaker: NA
Text: importance to some of these communities;

Speaker: NA
Text: they are the life and death of these com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munities. I think this should be recognised.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Minister went on to say:

Speaker: NA
Text: In common with other primary industries, dried

Speaker: NA
Text: fruit producers are faced with rising costs,

Speaker: NA
Text: increasing competition in world markets and more

Speaker: NA
Text: stringent standards imposed by importing countries.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is as much as to say that these are the

Speaker: NA
Text: normal sorts of things the Government deals

Speaker: NA
Text: with and there is no real cause for special

Speaker: NA
Text: concern. I feel this is a great understate-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of the position. It may be due to lack

Speaker: NA
Text: of knowledge of the position. In the dried

Speaker: NA
Text: fruits industry we should recognise that

Speaker: NA
Text: more than in any other industry, disaster

Speaker: NA
Text: is endemic and in nearly every other year

Speaker: NA
Text: the industry has to face a crisis either in

Speaker: NA
Text: marketing or, and particularly, in relation

Speaker: NA
Text: to the weather and the crop. Yet every

Speaker: NA
Text: year that it has been in existence in this

Speaker: NA
Text: century no basic measures have been

Speaker: NA
Text: taken to remove some of this lack of

Speaker: NA
Text: security. I refer particularly to the fact

Speaker: NA
Text: that even at this stage we are considering a

Speaker: NA
Text: research proposal- a measure to improve

Speaker: NA
Text: industry research and to make funds avail-

Speaker: NA
Text: able for a better approach to problems

Speaker: NA
Text: within the industry. As a principle the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition has always supported the need

Speaker: NA
Text: for increased and improved industry

Speaker: NA
Text: research. Tbe 2 things are not always syn-

Speaker: NA
Text: onymous, but I make that point quite

Speaker: NA
Text: clearly. We have before us a measure

Speaker: NA
Text: which says, in effect, that we are dedicated

Speaker: NA
Text: to further research to improve the product

Speaker: NA
Text: yet, at present, the Government has turned

Speaker: NA
Text: its face away from the position confronling

Speaker: NA
Text: one of our major export markets, the

Speaker: NA
Text: United Kingdom. We still have no commit-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment from the Government about what

Speaker: NA
Text: will happen to the range of industries that

Speaker: NA
Text: will be affected by Britain's entry into the

Speaker: NA
Text: European Economic Community or her

Speaker: NA
Text: association with the European Common

Speaker: NA
Text: Market.

Speaker: NA
Text: J believe that in the quiet of the evening

Speaker: NA
Text: some members of the Government still get

Speaker: NA
Text: down on their knees and pray very hard

Speaker: NA
Text: that Britain does not enter the Community.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is their forward planning-the y pray

Speaker: NA
Text: desperately that tbe problem they see com-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing does not arise. This is a bankruptcy of

Speaker: NA
Text: thought. We have no commitment from

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government regarding the survival of

Speaker: NA
Text: these industries in the face of changes

Speaker: NA
Text: which must be made in advance of Britain

Speaker: NA
Text: entering the European EconomicCommu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nity. This Bill relates to one industry, yet

Speaker: NA
Text: we have no Government commitment con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cerning that industry if Britain enters the

Speaker: NA
Text: European Economic Community. I suggest

Speaker: NA
Text: that prayers, however commendable in the

Speaker: NA
Text: dark of the evening, are not a substitute

Speaker: NA
Text: for action. Both should apply.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Turnbull-D o not make a joke of

Speaker: NA
Text: Christianity.

Speaker: Mr GRASSBY
Text: A n honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: from the Government benches interjects

Speaker: NA
Text: that this is a joke. It is not a joke to the

Speaker: NA
Text: growers who have waited for many years

Speaker: NA
Text: for some semblance of action. We have

Speaker: NA
Text: been waiting for 50 years-no t that the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Mallee ( Mr Turn-

Speaker: NA
Text: bull) has been in this place for 50 years,

Speaker: NA
Text: although he has been here for. a genera-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion-an d still we do not have a national

Speaker: NA
Text: disaster authority or a nations! disaster

Speaker: NA
Text: fund. We still do not have any national

Speaker: NA
Text: crop or livestock insurance provisions such

Speaker: NA
Text: as are enjoyed by our competitors in other

Speaker: NA
Text: countries. We do not have any of these

Speaker: NA
Text: things and yet Government members inter-

Speaker: NA
Text: ject and say: 'Oh, some joking is going on'.

Speaker: NA
Text: There has been joking and lethargy for a

Speaker: NA
Text: generation and it is time it caine .to an end

Speaker: NA
Text: because, after all, if we deal witb' the prob-

Speaker: NA
Text: lems of the industries in the dim future

Speaker: NA
Text: instead of now, the industries will not sur-

Speaker: NA
Text: vive. The Pontius Pilate attitude of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government saying: 'We will', await the

Speaker: NA
Text: industry's desires; we will await ' advice

Speaker: NA
Text: from the States; and we will not establish

Speaker: NA
Text: any positive guidelines ourself jiist will not

Speaker: NA
Text: do. However, I pay the Government, a trib-

Speaker: NA
Text: ute for being consistent in tliis regard. It

Speaker: NA
Text: has never said: 'We will give you' a lead' or

Speaker: NA
Text: 'We will take the lead'. What it has said is:

Speaker: NA
Text: 'We will wait on the industry* or 'We will

Speaker: NA
Text: wait on the States'.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let us examine the position of the dried

Speaker: NA
Text: fruits industry. The refusal of the Victor-

Speaker: NA
Text: ian Government to control expansion of

Speaker: NA
Text: plantings of dual purpose or drying variety

Speaker: NA
Text: grapes has not been accepted as 'final by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Dried Fruits Association.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Association has said that it will make

Speaker: NA
Text: a direct approach to the Government on

Speaker: NA
Text: this. The Association submits that over

Speaker: NA
Text: production already poses serious problems.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Association has had before it the

Speaker: NA
Text: report of the United States Department of

Speaker: NA
Text: Agriculture Foreign Agricultural Service

Speaker: NA
Text: that the combined world sultana produc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion is estimated at 704,900 tons or some 5

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent more than last year's production.

Speaker: NA
Text: The estimate of Australia's total sultana

Speaker: NA
Text: production is 94,900 tons. It is obvious

Speaker: NA
Text: that there is a desire by the industry to see

Speaker: NA
Text: some action. Likewise there is a desire by

Speaker: NA
Text: a State to do something different. I am

Speaker: NA
Text: suggesting that the Commonwealth Gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment cannot wash its hands once again

Speaker: NA
Text: in its recurring role of Pontius Pilate and

Speaker: NA
Text: say: 'We have no guidelines. We have no

Speaker: NA
Text: leadership to give. We will just have to

Speaker: NA
Text: await developments'. This is exactly the

Speaker: NA
Text: kind of policy, or attitude, which has got

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia into serious difficulty with prac-

Speaker: NA
Text: tically every primary industry in the

Speaker: NA
Text: nation.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is a need for positive guidelines in

Speaker: NA
Text: relation to the dried fruits industry. There

Speaker: NA
Text: is a need for action on the 3 points that

Speaker: NA
Text: have been raised in this debate. There is

Speaker: NA
Text: need for stabilisation. As a matter of fact I

Speaker: NA
Text: would suggest that even before stabilisation

Speaker: NA
Text: there is a need for a firm commitment by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government concerning the dried

Speaker: NA
Text: fruits industry if Britain enters

Speaker: NA
Text: Economic Community. If Britain enters

Speaker: NA
Text: that Community will the Government say:

Speaker: NA
Text: 'Well, this is bad for that industry. We

Speaker: NA
Text: have lost that export market. We will have

Speaker: NA
Text: to cut the industry down or cut it out'? We

Speaker: NA
Text: need a commitment now because obviously

Speaker: NA
Text: action should, be intrain in advance of Bri-

Speaker: NA
Text: tain's entering the European Economic

Speaker: NA
Text: Community. This is the first point I raise.

Speaker: NA
Text: Secondly, we should be taking all posGrassby)

Speaker: NA
Text: sible steps to confer with all sides of

Speaker: NA
Text: industry to ensure a basic stabilisation

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme. Thirdly, the Government should

Speaker: NA
Text: make a commitment that the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: has already made, namely, to establish

Speaker: NA
Text: national disaster fund which could be

Speaker: NA
Text: great and continuing value to the dried

Speaker: NA
Text: fruits industry. Concurrently or conjointly

Speaker: NA
Text: with that we should be exploring the poswrong.

Speaker: NA
Text: sible introduction of a national crop and

Speaker: NA
Text: livestock insurance fund which is needed

Speaker: NA
Text: and which has been needed all this

Speaker: NA
Text: or ever since primary industry was estab-

Speaker: NA
Text: lished. These are matters on which the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition has made commitments and I slightly.

Speaker: NA
Text: invite the Government to share our commit-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments. The Government is in power and it

Speaker: NA
Text: should be taking action now.

Speaker: NA
Text: I agree with the points that were made

Speaker: NA
Text: by thc honourable member for Darling

Speaker: NA
Text: about the present Act. There is always a

Speaker: NA
Text: tendency to impose the greatest burden on

Speaker: NA
Text: the producers. This has been revealed in

Speaker: NA
Text: many directions but as an Opposition we

Speaker: NA
Text: have said that we will support legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: which has the support of the industry or

Speaker: NA
Text: the overwhelming number of people in the

Speaker: NA
Text: industry. Despite growers' reservations

Speaker: NA
Text: about the Bill, there is a great and con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tinuing need for improved ancl extended

Speaker: NA
Text: research. Because of that urgency members

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Opposition support the Bill. How-

Speaker: NA
Text: ever, it is no use having measures such as

Speaker: NA
Text: this before the Parliament in isolation. In

Speaker: NA
Text: dealing with the great rural industries of

Speaker: NA
Text: this nation ihe fundamental problems

Speaker: NA
Text: should be acknowledged. I again express

Speaker: NA
Text: my dismay that the Minister, in his second

Speaker: NA
Text: reading speech, tended to dismiss the great

Speaker: NA
Text: problems of the industry and dealt with

Speaker: NA
Text: only this one facet. This is not good

Speaker: NA
Text: enough. It will not do and I suggest that

Speaker: NA
Text: while members of the Opposition accept

Speaker: NA
Text: this Bill they have served notice that they

Speaker: NA
Text: will expect a belter performance in relation

Speaker: NA
Text: to the other rural problems than they have

Speaker: NA
Text: the European seen this afternoon.

Text: Angas) (5.19)- Mr Deputv

Text: Speaker, now that the little argument in

Text: way, of growers who do not necessarily

Speaker: NA
Text: four persons to represent the organisauon known

Speaker: NA
Text: as thc Australian Dried Fruits Association;

Text: The honourable member for Riverina ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Grassby) did mention that he feit it wns

Speaker: NA
Text: hard to have a policy until we knew

Speaker: NA
Text: whether tbe United Kingdom was goinj> to

Speaker: NA
Text: join the European Common' Market or

Speaker: NA
Text: not. I do not argue very much with the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Riverinj in rela-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion to this. Obviously . whether Britain

Text: joins the Common Market or not will

Speaker: NA
Text: determine the way future policies will have

Speaker: NA
Text: to go, and if he thinks verbosity or verbal

Speaker: NA
Text: diarrhoea is a substitute for policy in rela-

Text: tion to these matters, I cannot help that.

Text: Anyone with an ounce o'f commonsense

Speaker: NA
Text: would surely agree that until'we know the

Speaker: NA
Text: exact marketing conditions to apply to this

Speaker: NA
Text: industry in the future we cannot very well

Speaker: NA
Text: have a certain policy. The policy' might be

Text: to produce more or to produce less, or

Speaker: NA
Text: perhaps to stabilise the industry, hut until

Speaker: NA
Text: we know the direction in which production

Speaker: NA
Text: is going I submit that only an ass wou'd

Speaker: NA
Text: consider it of any importance at all to he

Speaker: NA
Text: more specific than that. However, it is up

Text: to the honourable member for Riverina to

Speaker: NA
Text: make up his own mind. .

Speaker: NA
Text: The most important thing about the

Speaker: NA
Text: dried fruit industry in my electorate i.s that

Speaker: NA
Text: over many years it has been what I might

Speaker: NA
Text: the basic common denominator or the

Speaker: NA
Text: fall-back industry of the area. The canned

Speaker: NA
Text: fruit, citrus and wine industries have their

Speaker: NA
Text: As peaks of profitability to' growers on

Speaker: NA
Text: of irrigated properties in those' areas, but

Speaker: NA
Text: fundamentally it is the dried fruits industry

Speaker: NA
Text: honon which they can fall back when times

Speaker: NA
Text: are not so good in the other industries that

Speaker: NA
Text: 1 mentioned, it is on the basis of this his-

Speaker: NA
Text: torical fact that this legislation is of great

Speaker: NA
Text: importance to my area, we are now faced

Speaker: NA
Text: with a situation in my electorate in which

Speaker: NA
Text: predominantly citrus growing farms are

Speaker: NA
Text: very often not proving profitable. We are

Speaker: NA
Text: also faced with a situation in which certain

Speaker: NA
Text: sections of the canned fruit industry

Speaker: NA
Text: around Berri and Renmark have had their

Speaker: NA
Text: difficulties, particularly with

Speaker: NA
Text: peaches, much more, I think, than growers

Speaker: NA
Text: in any other part of Australia, due to

Speaker: NA
Text: peculiarities of production patterns in

Speaker: NA
Text: which peaches from that area form a pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: dominant part of tolal production. This

Speaker: NA
Text: pattern is not mirrored in other areas of

Speaker: NA
Text: Auslralia. So we therefore have a situation

Speaker: NA
Text: in which, with problems of surplus produc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion facing the wine industry within the

Speaker: NA
Text: next 5 years if not sooner, the producers

Speaker: NA
Text: will once again want to know where they

Speaker: NA
Text: stand in relation to the dried fruits

Speaker: NA
Text: industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is for that very purpose that the

Speaker: NA
Text: duction of a stabilisation scheme to come

Speaker: NA
Text: foi ward shortly is a matter of grave con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cern to growers of gordo and sultana

Speaker: NA
Text: grapes in particular in that locality. So

Speaker: NA
Text: not purely a matter of a policy in relation

Speaker: NA
Text: to dried fruits. There is an automatic inter-

Speaker: NA
Text: weaving of different products, affecting the

Speaker: NA
Text: entire economy of those areas, as in the

Speaker: NA
Text: diversity of uses for grapes in both the wine

Speaker: NA
Text: and dried fruit industries. It is important

Speaker: NA
Text: that all possible efforts be made to conduct

Speaker: NA
Text: proper research into alternate uses and

Speaker: NA
Text: functions for sultana and gordo grapes

Speaker: NA
Text: produced in those areas. Very often this

Speaker: NA
Text: type of research does not hold the answer

Speaker: NA
Text: to the marketing or merchandising of these

Speaker: NA
Text: products. I think, for instance, of years

Text: gone by when the average production of

Speaker: NA
Text: sultanas on an irrigated farm was perhaps

Text: 10 tons to the acre. It is entirely due to

Text: this type of research that there are varities

Text: of sultana grapes available today which

Text: an example where we are not necessarily

Text: solving marketing difficulties through

Text: research, but research is making it possible

Text: for individual farmers on irrigated proper-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties to make some gains in productivity

Speaker: NA
Text: within their enterprise.

Speaker: NA
Text: I appreciate that the Opposition views

Speaker: NA
Text: the word 'productivity' with complete

Speaker: NA
Text: ror and a lack of understanding but I

Speaker: NA
Text: assure them that people struggling to keep

Speaker: NA
Text: their heads above the debt structures in

Speaker: NA
Text: industries such as thc dried fruit industry

Speaker: NA
Text: do not see it in that light. Productivity,

Speaker: NA
Text: whether it be related to the poorer sectors

Text: of primary industry such as small dairy

Speaker: NA
Text: farmers and dried fruit producers or other

Speaker: NA
Text: more profitable industries, is a matter of

Speaker: NA
Text: great concern and the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: deserves great commendation for introduc-

Speaker: NA
Text: canned ing or formalising-i f I could put it that

Speaker: NA
Text: way-industr y investment on the one hand

Speaker: NA
Text: and Government matching grants for

Text: research on the other in a search for pro-

Text: ductivity, for new marketing methods and

Text: a higher quality of dried fruit produced.

Speaker: NA
Text: Many honourable members have toured

Speaker: NA
Text: areas such as South East Asia on behalf of

Speaker: NA
Text: their electorates for the purpose of assist-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing businesses and industries within their

Speaker: NA
Text: electorates. 1 expect that many of them

Speaker: NA
Text: will have run into, as I have in the past in

Speaker: NA
Text: countries such as Japan, the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Trade Commissioner who has said 'Come

Speaker: NA
Text: introalong with me and try a sample of an

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian product'. This happened to me

Speaker: NA
Text: many years ago and it may be that the

Speaker: NA
Text: position has now been remedied. The

Speaker: NA
Text: it is Trade Commissioner might say 'Try this

Speaker: NA
Text: piece of dried fruit' and you sample it but

Speaker: NA
Text: you find some grit in it.. For some quaint

Speaker: NA
Text: reason not only Australians but also the

Speaker: NA
Text: Japanese seem to think that grit has an

Speaker: NA
Text: association with dirt.. Being a race with

Speaker: NA
Text: very hygienic attitudes the Japanese do not

Speaker: NA
Text: like the association of a gritty taste in the

Speaker: NA
Text: mouth with dirt. When the fruit is con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tracting in the drying stages on racks it is

Speaker: NA
Text: difficult to exclude grit that might be in

Speaker: NA
Text: the air, but its presence can have an

Speaker: NA
Text: adverse effect on a small bu! important

Speaker: NA
Text: export industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: I believe that in the progressive areas,

Speaker: NA
Text: such as those represented by tbe honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Mallee, the drying of sul-

Speaker: NA
Text: tanas and other grapes is now being done

Speaker: NA
Text: on vine. This is a breakthrough. The process

Speaker: NA
Text: involves cincturing the bark on the rods of

Speaker: NA
Text: sultanas or whatever variety is being treated,

Speaker: NA
Text: thereby stopping the flow of sap therein

Speaker: NA
Text: and drying the product on the vine. By

Speaker: NA
Text: this process there is a fair chance, through

Speaker: NA
Text: eliminating triple handling and rack drying

Speaker: NA
Text: that airborne earth particles will not attach

Speaker: NA
Text: to the dried fruit. I believe the quality of

Speaker: NA
Text: horthe fruit produced in this way is of an

Speaker: NA
Text: can exceptionally high order. Any industry

Speaker: NA
Text: worth its salt will look at change and

Speaker: NA
Text: vation. It needs this type of research.

Speaker: NA
Text: the dried fruits industry is

Speaker: NA
Text: position as a most dependable industry, as

Speaker: NA
Text: it traditionally has been in irrigated areas,

Speaker: NA
Text: this type of research must take pride

Speaker: NA
Text: place. The growers themselves must

Speaker: NA
Text: to profit by the type of research and

Speaker: NA
Text: results when they are announced.

Speaker: NA
Text: 1 think 1 need say no more at the

Speaker: NA
Text: ond reading stage of these associated Bills.

Speaker: NA
Text: I look forward to seeing what amendments

Speaker: NA
Text: arc moved during the Committee stage

Speaker: NA
Text: the Bills. I hope that when they are moved

Speaker: NA
Text: by honourable members on either side

Speaker: NA
Text: the House they will bear directly towards

Speaker: NA
Text: the betterment of an industry in which the

Speaker: NA
Text: people involved are struggling to make

Speaker: NA
Text: their way in life and in many cases to

Speaker: NA
Text: off their commitments. I commend fhe

Speaker: NA
Text: Government very heartily for working with

Speaker: NA
Text: the industry and in bringing in the type

Speaker: NA
Text: research that will not penalise or interfere

Speaker: NA
Text: with research that has been contributed

Speaker: NA
Text: by both sides in the past. In other words,

Speaker: NA
Text: this research is in addition to any research

Speaker: NA
Text: which has previously been carried out I

Speaker: NA
Text: support the Bill.

Speaker: Mr SINCLAIR
Text: New England-Ministe r

Speaker: NA
Text: for Primary Industry) (5.34)-Severa l mat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ters were raised during the course of this

Speaker: NA
Text: debate about which I would like to compart

Speaker: NA
Text: ment briefly. First of all, significant

Speaker: NA
Text: ence was made by the honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Dawson (Dr Patterson) to the fact that

Speaker: NA
Text: in the view of tbe Opposition there should

Speaker: NA
Text: be an organisation of primary industry

Speaker: NA
Text: relation lo realistic markets. Whilst one

Speaker: NA
Text: can on the surface see that here is perhaps

Speaker: NA
Text: a realistic approach I think that one must

Speaker: NA
Text: look below the surface to see the spectre

Speaker: NA
Text: of arbitrary control applied by governfor

Speaker: NA
Text: ments. For my part 1 would be apprehenwithin

Speaker: NA
Text: sive that such a move might well ignore

Speaker: NA
Text: the prospects of the maintenance of normarketing

Speaker: NA
Text: mal production by those who own the

Speaker: NA
Text: land, who work the land, who share farm

Speaker: NA
Text: the land and who traditionally take investof

Speaker: NA
Text: ment decisions. Whilst one must acknowlnear

Speaker: NA
Text: edge that at a time of market contraction

Speaker: NA
Text: and marketing difiiculties there is a very

Speaker: NA
Text: real need for research in the terms of this

Speaker: NA
Text: Biil and for marketing exploration and

Speaker: NA
Text: development, both in terms of the prosthe

Speaker: NA
Text: pects abroad and within Australia, I think

Speaker: NA
Text: one must still ensure that there is a preserthrough

Speaker: NA
Text: vation of the role and capacity of the stantial

Speaker: NA
Text: innoproducer himself. It is, of course, towards

Speaker: NA
Text: If that end and in that connotation that this

Speaker: NA
Text: to maintain its Bill has been framed.

Speaker: NA
Text: Several specific matters have been

Speaker: NA
Text: of referred to by a number of honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: learn members. The honourable meniber for

Speaker: NA
Text: the Dawson suggested the inclusion of dried

Speaker: NA
Text: apples in this research and he said that

Speaker: NA
Text: whilst it was a small industry there would

Speaker: NA
Text: secseem to be some advantage in research

Speaker: NA
Text: being pursued with regard to dried apples

Speaker: NA
Text: as well as to all the other dried varieties of

Speaker: NA
Text: of fruit included in this Bill. 1 am advised

Speaker: NA
Text: that the proposals originated with the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: of tralian Dried Fruits Association and the

Speaker: NA
Text: specific varieties that are included in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill result from that Association's submis-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion and from discussions within the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: pay tralian Agricultural Council. I can assure

Speaker: NA
Text: the honourable member that if the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: ducers of dried apples were to make a sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: of mission to the Government it would be

Speaker: NA
Text: considered in the same light as submissions

Speaker: NA
Text: to now included in the Bill were considered.

Speaker: NA
Text: Should there be some basis on which the

Speaker: NA
Text: dried apple industry should be included

Speaker: NA
Text: either in this or in similar legislation the

Speaker: NA
Text: representations would of course be taken

Speaker: NA
Text: into account.

Speaker: NA
Text: Several suggestions were made during

Speaker: NA
Text: the course of this debate that this is only a

Speaker: NA
Text: of the total problem of the dried vine

Speaker: NA
Text: referfruits industry. I completely concur with

Speaker: NA
Text: that statement. In fact very real problems

Speaker: NA
Text: are emerging, both this year in relation to

Speaker: NA
Text: what has been an unexpectedly poor crop

Speaker: NA
Text: in and in the future in relation to market

Speaker: NA
Text: contraction. It is true that 12 months ago

Speaker: NA
Text: in April 1970 the industry unfortunately

Speaker: NA
Text: did not support a stabilisation scheme sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: mitted to it. As the honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: Dawson said, 2 factions emerged

Speaker: NA
Text: the industry and the result was that

Speaker: NA
Text: unfortunately the indu.stry suffered with

Speaker: NA
Text: difficulties last year and this

Speaker: NA
Text: year from a marked contraction, in thc

Speaker: NA
Text: crop so that the general economic position

Speaker: NA
Text: the dried fruits producers is nowhere

Speaker: NA
Text: as viable as one would like it to be.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honourable member for Mallee ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Turnbull) wanted to know what the indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: try lost by not accepting that scheme. It

Speaker: NA
Text: might be possible to put some figure on

Speaker: NA
Text: loss that was incurred but I think it is

Speaker: NA
Text: suffice to say that if the scheme had gone

Speaker: NA
Text: there would have been a very sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: payout to the industry in respect of

Speaker: NA
Text: last year's crop. I would prefer not to quan-

Speaker: NA
Text: tify it other than to say that under the

Speaker: NA
Text: terms of the proposal which was rejected

Speaker: NA
Text: by the industry, without doubt the money

Speaker: NA
Text: that would have been paid to the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: ducers would have given them very real

Speaker: NA
Text: assistance in their present difficulties.

Speaker: NA
Text: Negotiations have been continuing in the

Speaker: NA
Text: last month or 6 weeks between officers of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Department of Primary Industry, exec-

Speaker: NA
Text: utive officers and elected officers of the

Speaker: NA
Text: ADFA and me. As late as yesterday we

Speaker: NA
Text: moved quite well along the way towards

Speaker: NA
Text: settling the details of a new proposition

Speaker: NA
Text: which I hope will be submitted as a pack-

Speaker: NA
Text: age deal to growers. I trust that we will be

Speaker: NA
Text: in a position to do this fairly shortly. This

Speaker: NA
Text: new scheme has some modifications of the

Speaker: NA
Text: previous proposal which was placed before

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government. This scheme has emerged

Speaker: NA
Text: largely as a result of discussions between

Speaker: NA
Text: the producer representatives and me. When

Speaker: NA
Text: we are in a position to submit a firm pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: posal it will be done as a total package

Speaker: NA
Text: deal. As I said, I hope that this will be

Speaker: NA
Text: fairly soon. When the new scheme in detail

Speaker: NA
Text: is available to producers I trust that this

Speaker: NA
Text: time they will give it their full support

Speaker: NA
Text: because there is no doubt that their unfor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tunate rejection of the last scheme has cer-

Speaker: NA
Text: tainly prejudiced their present financial

Speaker: NA
Text: position.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honourable member for Darling

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr FitzPatrick) referred to 2 specific mat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ters. I did not quite follow the point that

Speaker: NA
Text: he made regarding representation of pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: ducers. Clause 11 (l.)(a) of the Dried

Speaker: NA
Text: Fruits Research Bill 1971 provides that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Research Committee shall include 4 per-

Speaker: NA
Text: sons representing an organisation known as

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Dried Fruits Association

Speaker: NA
Text: and clause ll(l.)(b) provides that 2 per-

Speaker: NA
Text: sons will represent the packers of dried

Speaker: NA
Text: fruits. There is in fact no packers organisathe levy.

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. Those 2 representatives will be

Speaker: NA
Text: nominated by the ADFA. The ADFA is

Speaker: NA
Text: specifically a producers' organisation. The

Speaker: NA
Text: members of that organisation consist

Speaker: NA
Text: entirely of elected representatives of pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: ducers and they will control 6 out of the

Speaker: NA
Text: 11 members on the Committee who will

Speaker: NA
Text: determine the allocation of research pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: jects. I am sure that when the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Darling looks at the detail of

Speaker: NA
Text: this Bill he will see that his concern about

Speaker: NA
Text: lack of producer representation will be

Speaker: NA
Text: alleviated.

Speaker: NA
Text: Indeed, on the Dried Fruits Research

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee will be other persons represent-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing government in one form or another.

Speaker: NA
Text: There will be 3 persons to represent the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Agricultural Council, one per-

Speaker: NA
Text: son to represent the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: Scientific and Industrial Research Organis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ation and one person to represent the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth Department of Primary

Speaker: NA
Text: Industry. So there is no provision for rep-

Speaker: NA
Text: resentation other than by those persons

Speaker: NA
Text: representing government and those repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: senting producers. In that sense I believe

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Dried Fruits Research Committee

Speaker: NA
Text: is truly reflective of the wishes and the

Speaker: NA
Text: requirements of producers themselves.

Speaker: NA
Text: The other question which the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Darling raised refers to a

Speaker: NA
Text: matter contained in clause 5 of the Dried

Speaker: NA
Text: Fruits Levy Collection Bill. Specifically he

Speaker: NA
Text: expressed concern that growers would have

Speaker: NA
Text: only 2 months in which to pay the levy as

Speaker: NA
Text: set out in clause 5 (1.). The position as I

Speaker: NA
Text: understand it-an d I believe that this

Speaker: NA
Text: applies to nearly all districts-i s that in

Speaker: NA
Text: most seasons delivery is completed by the

Speaker: NA
Text: end of May or, at the latest, in June and

Speaker: NA
Text: consequently there will be a considerable

Speaker: NA
Text: period between the time when delivery is

Speaker: NA
Text: completed and 30th November when the

Speaker: NA
Text: payment of the levy is required. If grapes

Speaker: NA
Text: should be delivered after 30th September,

Speaker: NA
Text: of course, payment of the levy would not

Speaker: NA
Text: be required until 30th November of the

Speaker: NA
Text: following year. So growers, instead of

Speaker: NA
Text: having 2 months in which to pay the levy,

Speaker: NA
Text: in fact will have a very considerable period

Speaker: NA
Text: in which to pay it. I am told that most

Speaker: NA
Text: pickings commence at some time in Febru-

Speaker: NA
Text: ary, and this year, because of the very

Speaker: NA
Text: small size of the crop, they have already

Speaker: NA
Text: been completed. Consequently, growers

Speaker: NA
Text: have between now and 30th November- a

Speaker: NA
Text: period of some 8 months-i n which to pay

Speaker: NA
Text: I believe that the other matters which

Speaker: NA
Text: have been raised relate more to the mar-

Speaker: NA
Text: keting side of the industry. I agree that

Speaker: NA
Text: they are of great significance to the indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: try. I believe that the industry is passing

Speaker: NA
Text: through a period of some uncertainty

Speaker: NA
Text: which has been caused by the virtual col-

Speaker: NA
Text: lapse of the International Sultana Agree-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. But I assure honourable members

Speaker: NA
Text: that the suggestion that nothing is being

Speaker: NA
Text: done to produce an alternative policy in

Speaker: NA
Text: the event of Britain entering into the Euro-

Speaker: NA
Text: pean Economic Community is incorrect

Speaker: NA
Text: and that exactly the contrary is the case.

Speaker: NA
Text: In fact, the Government's firm intention

Speaker: NA
Text: and its actions have been aimed at 2 areas.

Speaker: NA
Text: The first is the development of new mar-

Speaker: NA
Text: kets, and a great deal of activity, both

Speaker: NA
Text: direct and indirect, has taken place in this

Speaker: NA
Text: regard, and the second is the negotiation

Speaker: NA
Text: of international commodity agreements.

Speaker: NA
Text: One hopes that the International Sultana

Speaker: NA
Text: Agreement can be replaced in some form

Speaker: NA
Text: because it has served the industry well. It

Speaker: NA
Text: has provided a reliable and stable price

Speaker: NA
Text: over a considerable period. I believe that

Speaker: NA
Text: this has been very much to the advantage

Speaker: NA
Text: of Greece, Turkey and Australia, which

Speaker: NA
Text: are the 3 principal producing countries and

Speaker: NA
Text: which, of course, are members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: International Sultana Agreement. Some

Speaker: NA
Text: peculiar problems have arisen from Tur-

Speaker: NA
Text: key's devaluation of its currency. These

Speaker: NA
Text: problems have been mentioned not in the

Speaker: NA
Text: debate this afternoon but to me on other

Speaker: NA
Text: occasions. I can recognise the industry's

Speaker: NA
Text: concern about its future, but I believe that

Speaker: NA
Text: the positive steps which have been taken

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Govemment in searching for over-

Speaker: NA
Text: seas markets will be in the long term of

Speaker: NA
Text: real assistance to the industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: Of course, within Australia I think there

Speaker: NA
Text: is a necessity for the continued promotion

Speaker: NA
Text: and encouragement of the use of dried

Speaker: NA
Text: fruits. I was surprised to hear that

Speaker: NA
Text: apparently there has been a slight reduc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion in the sale of dried fruits across the

Speaker: NA
Text: grocery counter and that the only increase

Speaker: NA
Text: in the domestic demand for dried fruits

Speaker: NA
Text: has been for manufacturing purposes.

Speaker: NA
Text: Thanks to the efforts of the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Mallee, honourable members

Speaker: NA
Text: have been able lo sample dried fruits in

Speaker: NA
Text: their dining room for many years. I believe

Speaker: NA
Text: that if more Australians were given the

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity to eat dried fruits the domestic

Speaker: NA
Text: demand for them across the grocery

Speaker: NA
Text: counter might similarly increase. I com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mend thc Bill to the House.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question resolved in the affirmative.

Text: SOCIAL SERVICES BILL 1971

Speaker: Mr WENTWORTH
Text: Mackellar-Minis -

Speaker: NA
Text: ter for Social Services) (8.0)- I move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the Bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Bill gives effect to the announcement

Speaker: NA
Text: made by the Prime Minister ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: MCMahon) on 15th March that an imme-

Speaker: NA
Text: diate increase would be granted in pensions

Speaker: NA
Text: now being paid at maximum rates, with

Speaker: NA
Text: similar increases for certain other benefits.

Speaker: NA
Text: The increase of 50c a week in the basic

Speaker: NA
Text: standard rate payable to age, invalid and

Speaker: NA
Text: widow pensioners will bring the new rate

Speaker: NA
Text: to $16 a week-this , of course, excludes

Speaker: NA
Text: to the pension such as supple-

Speaker: NA
Text: mentary assistance and additional pay-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments for children. The increase of $1 a

Speaker: NA
Text: week for married couples will bring their

Speaker: NA
Text: combined basic rate to $28.50 a week. The

Speaker: NA
Text: maximum basic rate for widows without

Speaker: NA
Text: a children will rise to $14.25 a week. The

Speaker: NA
Text: full increase of 50c will be payable to all

Speaker: NA
Text: pensioners who are now receiving the max-

Speaker: NA
Text: imum rate-tha t is, those whose means as

Speaker: NA
Text: assessed are not more than $10 a week in

Speaker: NA
Text: the case of unmarried persons or $17 a

Speaker: NA
Text: week for married couples. A proportion of

Speaker: NA
Text: the 50c increase will be payable to unmar-

Speaker: NA
Text: ried pensioners whose means as assessed

Speaker: NA
Text: fall between $10 a week and $11 a week

Speaker: NA
Text: and to married pensioners where the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: bined means as assessed of husband and

Speaker: NA
Text: wife are between $17 a week and $19 a

Speaker: NA
Text: week. The provisions to pay portion of the

Speaker: NA
Text: 50c increase to these pensioners will ensure

Speaker: NA
Text: that their total income is not less than that

Speaker: NA
Text: of maximum rate pensioners with full

Speaker: NA
Text: allowable means. Similar increases will

Speaker: NA
Text: apply to sheltered employment and rehabil-

Speaker: NA
Text: itation allowances. Long-term sickness

Speaker: NA
Text: benefits will also be increased by 50c a

Speaker: NA
Text: week, bringing the maximum rate to $16 a

Speaker: NA
Text: week for single adults and married minors

Speaker: NA
Text: or to $10.50 a week for other persons.

Speaker: NA
Text: These rates apply after a person has been

Speaker: NA
Text: in receipt of sickness benefit for a continu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ous period of 6 weeks. Additional amounts

Speaker: NA
Text: payable for dependants will, where applica-

Speaker: NA
Text: ble, continue as at present.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government has decided on these ration?

Speaker: NA
Text: increases outside the course of the Budget

Speaker: NA
Text: having regard to movements in the Conrence of the House.

Speaker: NA
Text: sumer Price Index since pension rates were

Speaker: NA
Text: last fixed. In addition, honourable members

Speaker: NA
Text: will recall that the Prime Minister has

Speaker: NA
Text: indicated that the increase in pension

Speaker: NA
Text: proposed here is an interim measure only table.

Speaker: NA
Text: and he said that 'any increases given in the

Speaker: NA
Text: budget would, in justice to pensioners, leave granted?

Speaker: NA
Text: need to be quite substantial'. Furthermore

Speaker: NA
Text: he stated that the Government is underthat.

Speaker: NA
Text: taking 'a fundamental review of social ser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vices and related pensions and also of

Speaker: NA
Text: methods of adjusting such benefits. This

Speaker: NA
Text: review, which has already been com-

Speaker: NA
Text: menced, will be under consideration in the follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: Date

Speaker: NA
Text: July 1947

Speaker: NA
Text: October 1948

Speaker: NA
Text: December 1949

Speaker: NA
Text: November 1950

Speaker: NA
Text: November 1951

Speaker: NA
Text: near future with the object of bringing

Speaker: NA
Text: emerging decisions into effect for the year

Speaker: NA
Text: Honourable members will be

Speaker: NA
Text: interested in the progress that has been

Speaker: NA
Text: made over the years by Liberal-Country

Speaker: NA
Text: Party governments in improving the real

Speaker: NA
Text: value of pensions-honourabl e members

Speaker: NA
Text: who are interjecting will appreciate this.

Speaker: NA
Text: The rates proposed wiil not only be the

Speaker: NA
Text: highest on record in terms of money, but

Speaker: NA
Text: will also give to pensioners a greater pur-

Speaker: NA
Text: chasing power than at any previous time in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's history. A table has been pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: pared, having regard to the Consumer

Speaker: NA
Text: Price Index for the December 1970

Speaker: NA
Text: quarter-th e latest available-showin g the

Speaker: NA
Text: actual purchasing power of the pension in

Speaker: NA
Text: force at various dates since 1947,

Text: expressed in terms of current prices. I seek

Speaker: NA
Text: the concurrence of the House to incorpor-

Speaker: NA
Text: ate this in Hansard.

Text: The real level of the pension-tha t is, its

Text: The present proposed increases in the pen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion rate are substantially greater than

Speaker: NA
Text: this-namel y 3.2 per cent in the single rate

Text: rise in the consumer price index; they indi-

Speaker: NA
Text: It is true that the December quarter

Speaker: NA
Text: price rise was 1.9 per cent, which was out

Speaker: NA
Text: of line with previous experience. The

Speaker: NA
Text: March quarter figure is not, of course, yet

Speaker: NA
Text: available, and it would be wrong to pretend

Speaker: NA
Text: to any accuracy in forecasting it, but

Speaker: NA
Text: preliminary indications, for what they are

Speaker: NA
Text: worth, suggest that the rise will be less

Speaker: NA
Text: than that for the December quarter. Never-

Speaker: NA
Text: theless the price rise which has already

Speaker: NA
Text: taken place gives grounds for the present

Speaker: NA
Text: extra-budget rise in the basic pension rate,

Speaker: NA
Text: and one hopes that future price rises will

Speaker: NA
Text: slow down. The Prime Minister has

Speaker: NA
Text: already described the present pension

Speaker: NA
Text: increase as an interim measure, and it

Speaker: NA
Text: would be agreeable indeed- I hope that

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable members would find it agree-

Speaker: NA
Text: able-i f the rise in money rate which he

Speaker: NA
Text: substantially a rise in the real rate of

Speaker: NA
Text: sion-tha t is a rise which would not be

Speaker: NA
Text: significantly eroded by subsequent price

Speaker: NA
Text: increases.

Speaker: NA
Text: Price increases occur through excess

Speaker: NA
Text: demand, which makes possible sales at an

Speaker: NA
Text: increased price. Behind this process there

Speaker: NA
Text: are 2 engines, a big engine and a small

Speaker: NA
Text: one. The small engine is the tendency of

Speaker: NA
Text: certain business men to increase their

Speaker: NA
Text: profit margin-tha t is, to increase their

Speaker: NA
Text: prices faster than their costs. The big

Speaker: NA
Text: engine is the tendency of workers to

Speaker: NA
Text: demand over-award payments, beyond the

Speaker: NA
Text: increase in net productivity. This increases House.

Speaker: NA
Text: costs, and leads to massive price rises with-

Speaker: NA
Text: out any profit increase. The reason

Speaker: NA
Text: the extra profit margin must be considered

Speaker: NA
Text: the 'small' engine, and over-award pay-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments the 'big' engine is purely one of

Text: figures; as a component of total prices

Text: I think it should

Speaker: NA
Text: be apparent even to members of the Oppo-

Text: that the rise in prices is of particular

Text: it is importance to pensioners. Indeed, the

Text: reason for this Bill is the rise in prices.

Speaker: NA
Text: you Therefore I am entirely in order in dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: cussing this matter now. I know that cer-

Speaker: NA
Text: tain trade union leaders have gone on

Speaker: NA
Text: record saying: 'If wages are controlled by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Court, then prices should be controlled

Speaker: NA
Text: by law'. I venture to suggest that these

Speaker: NA
Text: trade union spokesmen have not thought

Speaker: NA
Text: out their position. The Court does not pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: scribe a maximum wage-i t prescribes a

Speaker: NA
Text: minimum wage. Over-award payments are

Speaker: NA
Text: perfectly legal, and, indeed even though

Speaker: NA
Text: they may sometimes be morbidly devel-

Speaker: NA
Text: oped, on other occasions, when they are

Speaker: NA
Text: matched by increased productivity, these

Speaker: NA
Text: over-award payments may be eminently

Speaker: NA
Text: desirable. But trade union spokesmen do

Speaker: NA
Text: not want to declare a minimum price-in -

Speaker: NA
Text: deed, and in this they are following the

Speaker: NA
Text: line originally laid down by the Liberal-

Speaker: NA
Text: Country Party Government, they have set

Speaker: NA
Text: their face against these minimum prices.

Speaker: NA
Text: But they want to declare a maximum

Speaker: NA
Text: price. These trade union spokesmen, who

Speaker: NA
Text: want to compare the treatments of wages

Speaker: NA
Text: and prices, apparently have not realised

Speaker: NA
Text: the difference between a maximum and a

Speaker: NA
Text: minimum, and have consequently got

Speaker: NA
Text: themselves into a state of utter confusion.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let me repeat that, as the Prime Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter has said, the present pension rise is an

Speaker: NA
Text: interim rise only. In saying that it lifts

Speaker: NA
Text: pension to a record level, not merely in

Speaker: NA
Text: money terms but in terms also of real

Speaker: NA
Text: purchasing power, I do not mean that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government regards this as an ultimate

Speaker: NA
Text: goal. As productivity rises, so also should

Speaker: NA
Text: pensions. One other point is of major

Speaker: NA
Text: importance. Pension rates are not the only

Speaker: NA
Text: assistance which is vital to the pensioner.

Speaker: NA
Text: Housing, nursing services and home help-

Speaker: NA
Text: and indeed many of the fringe benefits

Speaker: NA
Text: most of which have been introduced by

Speaker: NA
Text: governments on our side of politics-ar e

Speaker: NA
Text: all vital. In the course of the present

Speaker: NA
Text: liament I believe it will be possible to

Speaker: NA
Text: improve them still further. The Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister has spoken of the 'fundamental

Speaker: NA
Text: review of social services' which is now in

Speaker: NA
Text: process. This is too large a matter to be

Speaker: NA
Text: dealt with here, where the time for debate

Speaker: NA
Text: before this Bill should be passed is so

Speaker: NA
Text: short. I hope before long to be able to

Speaker: NA
Text: bring before Cabinet the results of the

Speaker: NA
Text: review to which the Prime Minister has

Speaker: NA
Text: referred. I trust that the House will permit

Speaker: NA
Text: me to refer to this in passing rather than

Speaker: NA
Text: to anticipate any details. The Prime Minister down?

Speaker: NA
Text: ter also referred to consideration being

Speaker: NA
Text: given to 'method of adjusting' our benefits

Speaker: NA
Text: in the future. This matter also is under

Speaker: NA
Text: review, and, once again, I hope that

Speaker: NA
Text: Cabinet will be considering it before too

Speaker: NA
Text: long.

Speaker: NA
Text: Honourable members will note the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: plexity of the Bill. This stems from the

Speaker: NA
Text: fact that it is being incorporated in existing

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation which has from time to time

Speaker: NA
Text: been changed and become more complex

Speaker: NA
Text: with the changes. Some time ago I

Speaker: NA
Text: indicated to the House that I was hoping

Speaker: NA
Text: to have the whole Act codified and rewrit-

Speaker: NA
Text: ten in a simpler form. This matter has

Speaker: NA
Text: been referred to the Parliamentary Counsel

Speaker: NA
Text: but pressure of business has so far pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: vented it from being undertaken. Perhaps

Speaker: NA
Text: it may now be considered in conjunction

Speaker: NA
Text: with the fundamental review of the social

Speaker: NA
Text: services structure to which the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister has already referred. The Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment has decided that the increase in all

Speaker: NA
Text: pension rates will apply in respect of all

Speaker: NA
Text: pension payments made after 31st March.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is a repatriation pension pay day on

Speaker: NA
Text: 1st April, age and invalid pension on 8th

Speaker: NA
Text: April, and widow's pension on 13th April.

Speaker: NA
Text: The rate of Service pensions-whic h are

Speaker: NA
Text: paid under the Repatriation Act-depend s

Speaker: NA
Text: the upon the rates set in the Social Services

Speaker: NA
Text: Act.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is thus essential that the whole of the

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation should operate as from 1st

Speaker: NA
Text: April. Honourable members will note that

Speaker: NA
Text: clause 2 of the Bill provides for this, even

Speaker: NA
Text: though the legislation may not receive the

Speaker: NA
Text: Governor-General's assent by that date.

Speaker: NA
Text: Originally we thought that, following upon

Speaker: NA
Text: a public statement made some time ago by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Leader of the Opposition, the Bills

Speaker: NA
Text: would receive a speedy passage. We now
