Speaker: NA
Text: SEAMEN'S WAR PENSIONS AND referred

Speaker: NA
Text: ALLOWANCES BILL 1971

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill-b y leave-presente d by Mr Holten,

Speaker: NA
Text: and read a first time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: Mr HOLTEN
Text: Indi-Ministe r for Repa-

Speaker: NA
Text: triation) (SAT)- I move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the Bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is thc usual practice of the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: to keep the rates of pensions

Speaker: NA
Text: ances payable to seamen war pensioners

Speaker: NA
Text: under the Seamen's War Pensions and

Speaker: NA
Text: Allowances Act in line with the rates of recovered) byThe

Speaker: NA
Text: pensions and allowances payable

Speaker: NA
Text: war pensioners under the Repatriation Act.

Speaker: NA
Text: The purpose of the Bill now before the

Speaker: NA
Text: House is to raise, in relation to seamen,

Speaker: NA
Text: various rates of pension in line with the

Speaker: NA
Text: increases of corresponding rates being

Speaker: NA
Text: made in the Repatriation Bill just introamount

Speaker: NA
Text: duced. These increases are in accordance sub-section,

Speaker: NA
Text: with the higher rates recently announced plaint,

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Prime Minister.

Speaker: NA
Text: Clause 3 of the Bill increases the inter-

Speaker: NA
Text: mediate rate of war pension by SOc per

Speaker: NA
Text: week to $28.50. The intermediate pension

Speaker: NA
Text: is paid to seriously disabled persons whose

Speaker: NA
Text: war-caused incapacities render them incaa

Speaker: NA
Text: pable of working other than on a part-time

Speaker: NA
Text: basis, or intermittently. Clause 4 substitutes

Speaker: NA
Text: a new First Schedule to the Act to provide

Speaker: NA
Text: for an increase of 50c in the weekly rate

Speaker: NA
Text: overof pension payable to widows of Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian mariners. The Bill does not have to

Speaker: NA
Text: provide for the increase of $1.00 to $39.00

Speaker: NA
Text: per week in the rate of T.P.I, pension or

Speaker: NA
Text: for the increase of $1.00 in the weekly

Speaker: NA
Text: amounts payable in respect of certain disa-

Speaker: NA
Text: he bilities described in the Fifth Schedule to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Repatriation Act, as the increased rates

Speaker: NA
Text: under that Act will apply automatically to

Speaker: NA
Text: seamen pensioners by virtue of section 22A

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Seamen's War Pensions and Allow-

Speaker: NA
Text: As in the case in respect of the Repatria-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion legislation, the Government wishes

Speaker: NA
Text: to make it clear that the increases in pen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions for which the Bill provides will be

Speaker: NA
Text: payable from 1st April 1971, and that the

Speaker: NA
Text: retrospectivity involved on this occasion

Speaker: NA
Text: because of the special circumstances

Speaker: NA
Text: should not be taken as a precedent for the

Speaker: NA
Text: future, particularly in view of the very

Speaker: NA
Text: small time period involved and because of

Speaker: NA
Text: other factors to which I have already

Speaker: NA
Text: in my second reading speech on

Speaker: NA
Text: the Repatriation Bill. I commend the Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: to the House.

Speaker: NA
Text: DRIED FRUITS LEVY

Speaker: NA
Text: COLLECTION BILL 1971

Speaker: NA
Text: In Committee

Speaker: NA
Text: Clauses 1 to 7-b y leave-take n to-

Speaker: NA
Text: and allowgether, and agreed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: Clause 8.

Speaker: NA
Text: 8 -(1. following amounts may be

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commonwealth as debts due to

Speaker: NA
Text: to otber the Commonwealth:-

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) lev}' that is payable;

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) an amount that is payable to the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth under section 6 of this Act; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (c) an amount that is payable by way of

Speaker: NA
Text: penalty under the last preceding section.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2.) ln proceedings for the recovery of ao

Speaker: NA
Text: referred to in the last preceding

Speaker: NA
Text: an averment or statement in the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: claim or declaration of the plaintiff is evi-

Speaker: NA
Text: dence of the matter so averred or stated.

Speaker: Dr PATTERSON
Text: Dawson) (8.50)- I

Speaker: NA
Text: move:

Speaker: NA
Text: Omit sub-clause (2.).

Speaker: NA
Text: This sub-clause deals with the recovery of

Speaker: NA
Text: levy. The Opposition has no quarrel with

Speaker: NA
Text: sub-clause (1.) which relates to amounts

Speaker: NA
Text: that may be recovered by the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth as debts due to the Commonwealth.

Speaker: NA
Text: That provision is quite straightforward but

Speaker: NA
Text: sub-clause (2.) is quite obnoxious and con-

Speaker: NA
Text: trary to British justice. What it means is

Speaker: NA
Text: that any person, who has the right to go

Speaker: NA
Text: on to a producer's property if he or she

Speaker: NA
Text: chooses, can make any averment whatso-

Speaker: NA
Text: ever and that averment then can be taken

Speaker: NA
Text: as evidence and there can be no argument

Speaker: NA
Text: against it. This contravenes the very

Speaker: NA
Text: essence of democracy. To make matters

Speaker: NA
Text: worse the Commonwealth, if it is the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: secuting authority, can wait up to 5 years

Speaker: NA
Text: before the averment is dealt with. We will

Speaker: NA
Text: be dealing with that aspect soon. Any con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tention or any statement supposedly relat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing to a complaint can be made by a per-

Speaker: NA
Text: son acting on behalf of the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth. We must assume, therefore, that

Speaker: NA
Text: every such person-publi c servant, bailiff

Speaker: NA
Text: or whatever he may be-concerne d with

Speaker: NA
Text: this legislation will be scrupulously honest

Speaker: NA
Text: to the degree that he would never bear a

Speaker: NA
Text: grudge against a primary producer, never

Speaker: NA
Text: bear malice of any sort against any grower

Speaker: NA
Text: and never show any degree of bias. He

Speaker: NA
Text: will be a. pillar of virtue and impartial at

Speaker: NA
Text: every stage. We do not even accord this

Speaker: NA
Text: degree of virtue to the professionals, the

Speaker: NA
Text: police, yet we are prepared to accept any

Speaker: NA
Text: averment by a person who will be policing

Speaker: NA
Text: the levy.

Speaker: NA
Text: I find it incredible that a Country Party

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister can be a party to the sub-clause.

Speaker: NA
Text: One could imagine the admission of this

Speaker: NA
Text: type of evidence in some Gestapo state but

Speaker: NA
Text: it is foreign to Australian democracy. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: completely incredible that the Country

Speaker: NA
Text: Party Minister in charge of the Bill should

Speaker: NA
Text: agree to this type of averment against

Speaker: NA
Text: which there will be no argument. Any

Speaker: NA
Text: averment in the complaint by the plaintiff

Speaker: NA
Text: can be used as evidence and it may not be

Speaker: NA
Text: challenged for up to 5 years. Imagine this

Speaker: NA
Text: hanging over the head of a dried vine

Speaker: NA
Text: fruits producer who has a family to main-

Speaker: NA
Text: tain and whose children are going to

Speaker: NA
Text: school. But this is what the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: proposes. Australia is becoming almost a

Speaker: NA
Text: police state when the Minister for Primary

Speaker: NA
Text: Industry ( Mr Sinclair) starts these capers.

Speaker: NA
Text: The people whom the Minister allows to

Speaker: NA
Text: go on to properties to check trees or what-

Speaker: NA
Text: ever else it is can make an averment which

Speaker: NA
Text: can be used in evidence. For our part the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition will have no part of this.

Speaker: Mr SINCLAIR
Text: New England-Ministe r

Speaker: NA
Text: for Primary Industry) (8.55)- I think that

Speaker: NA
Text: the honourable member for Dawson (Dr

Speaker: NA
Text: Patterson) has inferred that the introduc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of an averment provision is in some

Speaker: NA
Text: way denying the fundamental rights of

Speaker: NA
Text: producers. In fact, the contrary is true. The

Speaker: NA
Text: purpose of the Bill, as has been agreed to

Speaker: NA
Text: generally during the second reading stage,

Speaker: NA
Text: is to provide for research for the purposes

Speaker: NA
Text: of the industry. The Bill does not levy a

Speaker: NA
Text: tax for consolidated revenue. It is designed

Speaker: NA
Text: to ensure that all growers join in con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tributing on a $1 for $1 basis with the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government to facilitate research which

Speaker: NA
Text: we all agree is highly desirable. That is the

Speaker: NA
Text: first point that it is essential for people to

Speaker: NA
Text: recognise. Secondly, it is true that in order

Speaker: NA
Text: to ensure that all growers contribute it is

Speaker: NA
Text: necessary for there to be some sort of

Speaker: NA
Text: penal provision in the legislation so that

Speaker: NA
Text: one or two growers do not hang off and

Speaker: NA
Text: leave it to those many responsible growers

Speaker: NA
Text: who are prepared to make the contribution

Speaker: NA
Text: and over whom there is no necessity to

Speaker: NA
Text: have supervision. Those one or two grow-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers should not enjoy the advantages but

Speaker: NA
Text: deny the responsibilities which the provi-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion entails.

Speaker: NA
Text: In order to ensure that all growers con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tribute and that equity is done to growers

Speaker: NA
Text: in the implementation of the Bill, which

Speaker: NA
Text: we all agree is highly desirable, there are

Speaker: NA
Text: enforcement provisions. The way in which

Speaker: NA
Text: these enforcement provisions can be

Speaker: NA
Text: applied depends on the extent to which

Speaker: NA
Text: inspectors are available. True, if we had an

Speaker: NA
Text: inspector in every packing shed or in every

Speaker: NA
Text: vineyard we would be able to get away

Speaker: NA
Text: without an averment procedure because it

Speaker: NA
Text: would then be possible to provide evidence

Speaker: NA
Text: to show which fruits were being picked,

Speaker: NA
Text: what quantities were being consigned and

Speaker: NA
Text: to which packing house, and the whole

Speaker: NA
Text: procedure would be simple and capable of

Speaker: NA
Text: proof. But, of course, that is not the way

Speaker: NA
Text: in which the system operates. Relatively

Speaker: NA
Text: few inspectors are employed by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Department of Primary Industry in this

Speaker: NA
Text: field, and rightly so. What we do is to

Speaker: NA
Text: provide a few inspectors who cover the

Speaker: NA
Text: whole field and who move around as

Speaker: NA
Text: quickly as their resources will allow.

Speaker: NA
Text: In no way are the growers harassed. In

Speaker: NA
Text: order to ensure that they are not harassed

Speaker: NA
Text: but so that those facts which are clearly

Speaker: NA
Text: within the knowledge of the grower can be

Speaker: NA
Text: determined there is an averment provision.

Speaker: NA
Text: The grower has the knowledge and under-

Speaker: NA
Text: standing of what fruit has been delivered,

Speaker: NA
Text: what packing house has collected his fruit

Speaker: NA
Text: and what he has been paid for it. An aver-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment simply means that the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth can say that such and such is a fact

Speaker: NA
Text: and that fruit was delivered to a packing

Speaker: NA
Text: house but the grower has it completely

Speaker: NA
Text: within his knowledge to prove that this

Speaker: NA
Text: was not the case. He may have a delivery

Speaker: NA
Text: order indicating what fruit was delivered.

Speaker: NA
Text: The simple procedures of justice give him

Speaker: NA
Text: the capacity to deny what the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: would find it impossible to prove without a

Speaker: NA
Text: considerable back-up of inspectors. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: the reason for the inclusion of the aver-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, provision in this legislation and in

Speaker: NA
Text: many other similar pieces of legislation.

Speaker: NA
Text: is essential that we consider the general

Speaker: NA
Text: trouble and costs of administration which

Speaker: NA
Text: would be necessary if there were no aver-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment provision. This provision is not

Speaker: NA
Text: designed fbr the destruction of the rights

Speaker: NA
Text: of the grower. The contrary is the position.

Speaker: NA
Text: The purpose of the provision is to ensure

Speaker: NA
Text: that those facts which are not within the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government's knowledge can be averred

Speaker: NA
Text: and those facts which are within the grow-

Speaker: NA
Text: er's knowledge can be used to deny the

Speaker: NA
Text: averment if such should be necessary.

Speaker: NA
Text: Accordingly, the Government will not

Speaker: NA
Text: accept the amendment.

Speaker: Mr GRASSBY
Text: Riverina) (8.59)- I sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: port the points that were put by the hon-

Speaker: NA
Text: ourable member for Dawson (Dr Patter-

Speaker: NA
Text: son) and I want to comment on what was

Speaker: NA
Text: said by the Minister for Primary Industry

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Sinclair). The Minister says that the

Speaker: NA
Text: whole of this clause, in fact the whole of

Speaker: NA
Text: the penal clauses of this Bill which the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government is enacting, is there to ensure

Speaker: NA
Text: that one or two growers do not opt out

Speaker: NA
Text: or do not take advantage of the legis-

Speaker: NA
Text: lation and fail to make a proper contribu-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. We accepted the principle of the leg-

Speaker: NA
Text: islation at the second reading stage but 1

Speaker: NA
Text: would point out to the Committee that we

Speaker: NA
Text: are talking about a penalty of $200. The

Speaker: NA
Text: major objection that we put forward is

Speaker: NA
Text: that under the offending sub-clause (2.)

Speaker: NA
Text: of the actions by the inspector are

Speaker: NA
Text: validated and accepted while all tbe evi-

Speaker: NA
Text: dence of the growers can be challenged. It

Speaker: NA
Text: seems to me, as the honourable meniber

Speaker: NA
Text: for Dawson has said, that this sets aside

Speaker: NA
Text: important legal provisions and processes,

Speaker: NA
Text: provisions which are in many Acts, in

Speaker: NA
Text: many statutes. In relation to this matter

Speaker: NA
Text: a possible penalty of $200 what is being

Speaker: NA
Text: said here is that all of the statements by

Speaker: NA
Text: the inspectors-an d the Minister admits he

Speaker: NA
Text: does not have many-ar e accepted. If the

Speaker: NA
Text: inspector does call, no matter how hur-

Speaker: NA
Text: riedly he conducts his investigation and no

Speaker: NA
Text: matter how mistaken he may be, his state-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment is to be accepted.

Speaker: NA
Text: Surely this is a sweeping, hammer-like

Speaker: NA
Text: provision to put into a piece of legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: where we are dealing-an d the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: has admitted this-wit h possibly only one

Speaker: NA
Text: or two growers. He is setting aside a great

Speaker: NA
Text: principle for a very sniall reason. But the

Speaker: NA
Text: thing that concerns me perhaps even more

Speaker: NA
Text: It than the offending sub-clause (2.) is the

Speaker: NA
Text: provision that a prosecution for an offence

Speaker: NA
Text: against this sub-clause may be commenced

Speaker: NA
Text: at any time within 5 years. This is not

Speaker: NA
Text: reasonable. Imagine the situation of a man

Speaker: NA
Text: standing for public office. Five years pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: viously he could have committed an occur-

Speaker: NA
Text: rence for which action against him could

Speaker: NA
Text: possibly have been initiated. It may not

Speaker: NA
Text: have been initiated. It may be, of course,

Speaker: NA
Text: that someone with an eye to denying him

Speaker: NA
Text: public office could say: 'Well, it would be

Speaker: NA
Text: a very good idea to go ahead with this

Speaker: NA
Text: action now.' Surely there is no real

Speaker: NA
Text: reason

Speaker: The CHAIRMAN
Text: Mr Lucock)

Speaker: NA
Text: Order! ] think the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Riverina is possibly confusing the 2

Speaker: NA
Text: amendments which were foreshadowed.

Speaker: NA
Text: The one that the Committee is considering

Speaker: NA

Text: deals with proceedings for the recovery of

Speaker: NA
Text: an amount referred to. The matter of 5

Speaker: NA
Text: years and 12 months is dealt with in the

Speaker: NA
Text: second amendment proposed to be moved.

Speaker: Mr GRASSBY
Text: I am sorry; I defer, of

Speaker: NA
Text: course. I will withhold my comments on

Speaker: NA
Text: that until a later stage. I would just say in

Speaker: NA
Text: conclusion that I would like to submit to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister that this is taking a very

Speaker: NA
Text: heavy hammer in relation to the accept-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance of evidence in this matter and setting

Speaker: NA
Text: aside a great principle for something

Speaker: NA
Text: all involving, in fact, one or two growers. I

Speaker: NA
Text: think it is a noxious provision and we

Speaker: NA
Text: would be opposed to it.

Text: Dawson) (9.3)- I

Speaker: NA
Text: would like to comment briefly on what the

Text: Minister for Primary Industry ( Mr Sin-

Speaker: NA
Text: clair) said. Taking what he has said to be

Speaker: NA
Text: of true it would seem that this clause was

Speaker: NA

Text: Dawson) (9.12)- I

Speaker: NA
Text: move:

Speaker: NA
Text: In sub-clause (2.), omit 'five years', insert

Speaker: NA
Text: 'twelve months'.

Speaker: NA
Text: Sub-clause (2.) of clause 11 of this Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: deals with prosecution for an offence under

Speaker: NA
Text: this clause and it provides that prosecution

Speaker: NA
Text: may be commenced at any time within 5

Speaker: NA
Text: years after the commission of the offence.

Speaker: NA
Text: The part of clause II which the Opposi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion seeks to amend is that which relates

Speaker: NA
Text: to the time limit within which prosecution

Speaker: NA
Text: may be commenced. The Opposition takes

Speaker: NA
Text: Tellers: the view that to allow a prosecution for

Speaker: NA
Text: such an offence to be commenced at any

Speaker: NA
Text: time within 5 years after the commission

Speaker: NA
Text: of the offence is contrary to the spirit of

Speaker: NA
Text: this Bill. The offences covered in clause 11

Speaker: NA
Text: are not criminal offences. The Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: went to great pains to say that the levy is

Speaker: NA
Text: to be collected from persons concerned

Speaker: NA
Text: with the dried fruits industry and that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth will provide matching

Speaker: NA
Text: grants. In the event of an offence against

Speaker: NA
Text: clause 11 a certain penalty can be

Speaker: NA
Text: imposed. The Opposition's objection to

Speaker: NA
Text: clause 11 is the time of 5 years within

Speaker: NA
Text: which a prosecution may be commenced.

Speaker: NA
Text: One can imagine that if a grower, a packer

Speaker: NA
Text: or someone concerned with the provisions

Speaker: NA
Text: of this Bill committed some criminal

Speaker: NA
Text: offence the time limit of 5 years within

Speaker: NA
Text: which to commence prosecution may well

Speaker: NA
Text: apply. However, one can imagine a trivial

Speaker: NA
Text: offence being committed by such a person.

Speaker: NA
Text: For example, an inspector may find some-

Speaker: NA
Text: thing wrong and this would be hanging

Speaker: NA
Text: over the head of the producer and his

Speaker: NA
Text: family; they would be waiting for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth to make up its mind to

Speaker: NA
Text: prosecute. I believe this is wrong and con-

Speaker: NA
Text: trary to British justice.

Speaker: NA
Text: If the Commonwealth Government is

Speaker: NA
Text: properly to administer the provisions of

Speaker: NA
Text: this Bill it should be able to commence

Speaker: NA
Text: proceedings within 12 months. Why should

Speaker: NA
Text: it have to wait up to 5 years? This is an

Speaker: NA
Text: incredible clause. With all the resources

Speaker: NA
Text: available to the Commonwealth, if it can-

Speaker: NA
Text: not prosecute within 12 months after the

Speaker: NA
Text: commission of such an offence it must be

Speaker: NA
Text: guilty of mismanagement. This clause is

Speaker: NA
Text: offensive and it is contrary to the spirit of

Speaker: NA
Text: this Bill. It is not a Bill which makes

Speaker: NA
Text: provision for criminal proceedings. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Government should be able to commence

Speaker: NA
Text: proceedings within 12 months of the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mission of the offence. This is why the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition has moved this amendment.

Speaker: Mr GRASSBY
Text: Riverina) (9.17)-Earlie r

Speaker: NA
Text: I was directing my remarks to the

Speaker: NA
Text: wrong clause but let me direct myself very

Speaker: NA
Text: specifically to sub-clause (2.) of clause

Speaker: NA
Text: The honourable member for Dawson (Dr

Speaker: NA
Text: Patterson) has referred to this incredible

Speaker: NA
Text: provision to which I previously referred.

Speaker: NA
Text: The provision contained in this clause is

Speaker: NA
Text: that prosecution for an offence against

Speaker: NA
Text: clause 11 may be commenced at any time

Speaker: NA
Text: within 5 years after the commission of the

Speaker: NA
Text: offence. Let us look at what the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment has done. It has the agreement of the

Speaker: NA
Text: industry to have a levy for a certain pur-

Text: pose. This is desirable and we agree tbat

Text: all growers should contribute and should

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: which returns are not lodged or in which

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: the grower, in good faith. Mistakes may be

Speaker: NA
Text: made by government inspectors, also in

Speaker: NA
Text: good faith. Let us be quite clear on this.

Speaker: NA
Text: The onus here is on the grower.

Speaker: NA
Text: What we have agreed to is that anything

Speaker: NA
Text: the inspector says in evidence is to be

Speaker: NA
Text: accepted! There is to be no argument

Speaker: NA
Text: about it. This places the whole onus on fhe

Speaker: NA
Text: grower. I agree with the honourable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber for Dawson that the provisions of sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: clause (2.) are against the principles of jus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tice as they have applied in this country.

Speaker: NA
Text: In regard to the nature of the offence we

Speaker: NA
Text: find that the provision relates to the failure

Speaker: NA
Text: or neglect to furnish a return or the fur-

Speaker: NA
Text: nishing of a return or information that is

Speaker: NA
Text: false or misleading. The penalty provided

Speaker: NA
Text: is $200. That is not an inconsiderable pen-

Speaker: NA
Text: alty, but the onus is on the grower. The

Speaker: NA
Text: government inspectors enshrined in this

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation are never to be permitted to

Speaker: NA
Text: make an error. That is an incredible piece

Speaker: NA
Text: of infallibility, but there it it. We lost the

Speaker: NA
Text: vote on that issue and it has now been

Speaker: NA
Text: accepted. Now we are being asked to

Speaker: NA
Text: accept this, time limit in relation to this

Speaker: NA
Text: awful offence of failing to make a return

Speaker: NA
Text: or making an inaccurate return. Of course

Speaker: NA
Text: it is an offence but we are being asked to

Speaker: NA
Text: give the Commonwealth a period of 5

Speaker: NA
Text: years in which to launch a prosecution for

Speaker: NA
Text: such an offence. I draw the attention of

Speaker: NA
Text: this Committee to the fact that under the

Speaker: NA
Text: Crimes Act the statutory time limit for

Speaker: NA
Text: certain offences is 6 months. The Crimes

Speaker: NA
Text: Act deals with serious matters including

Speaker: NA
Text: assault on the person. It deals with a

Speaker: NA
Text: whole range of real crimes. In such a case

Speaker: NA
Text: the onus is on the State to marshal its case

Speaker: NA
Text: and to take action within 6 months. In this

Speaker: NA
Text: 11. case for this awful crime on the part of

Speaker: NA
Text: the grower of not furnishing his return or

Speaker: NA
Text: of making some inaccuracy in it we are

Speaker: NA
Text: asked to give the Commonwealth a period

Speaker: NA
Text: of 5 years within which to launch a prose-

Speaker: NA
Text: cution. This is an incredible provision. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition is opposed to it. I hope that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister will have second thoughts about

Speaker: NA
Text: it.

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to come back to a point which I

Speaker: NA
Text: previously mentioned. There could well be

Speaker: NA
Text: a situation in which a man has decided to

Speaker: NA
Text: contest a public oflice. A prosecution could

Speaker: NA
Text: be launched against him many years after

Speaker: NA
Text: the event. Let us imagine what happens in

Speaker: NA
Text: relation to the case. The case comes for-

Speaker: NA
Text: ward and the inspector's evidence must,

Speaker: NA
Text: under this Biil, be accepted. But perhaps

Speaker: NA
Text: the defendant's witnesses have died and

Speaker: NA
Text: their evidence is lost. The defendant is

Speaker: NA
Text: standing there naked and unashamed, with-

Speaker: NA
Text: out any hope of opposing the whole weight

Speaker: NA
Text: and resources of tbe Commonwealth in a

Speaker: NA
Text: matter such as this. Surely this is not

Speaker: NA
Text: reasonable. I hope that the Minister will

Speaker: NA
Text: take very serious note of the objection and

Speaker: NA
Text: refer to the Crimes Act in which there is

Speaker: NA
Text: an analogy. A Stale in these serious mat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ters is allowed only 6 months in which to

Speaker: NA
Text: act.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Commonwealth, with all the powers

Speaker: NA
Text: that it has taken unto itself-and , after

Speaker: NA
Text: this is not a very impressive offence, but

Speaker: NA
Text: is certainly a material one; let us put

Speaker: NA
Text: its proper perspective-i s asking for

Speaker: NA
Text: period of 5 years in which it can act. I head.

Speaker: NA
Text: submit this is neither desirable nor just. I

Speaker: NA
Text: ask the Minister to examine the submis-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions we have made in a reasonable way.

Speaker: NA
Text: We agree tbat one or two growers might

Speaker: NA
Text: want to be gently brought into line, but

Speaker: NA
Text: surely to goodness we do not want to drag

Speaker: NA
Text: the growers through a long drawn out

Speaker: NA
Text: period of prosecution in the way which

Speaker: NA
Text: envisaged under this Bill.

Text: (b) furnish, in pursuance of the regulations, a

Speaker: NA
Text: The point I make is that the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Dawson, by nodding his head,

Speaker: NA
Text: it grower must have known all the time that

Speaker: NA
Text: it in he had committed an offence, otherwise

Speaker: NA
Text: a the threat would not be hanging over his

Text: is that a prosecution for an offence must be

Text: 1 know that. Of

Speaker: Dr PATTERSON
Text: Dawson) (9.41)-Th e

Speaker: NA
Text: objective of the Pig Industry Research Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: 1971 is to provide for the establishment and

Speaker: NA
Text: to enable the operation of a Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth industry research scheme for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian pig industry. This Bili follows

Speaker: NA
Text: in principle the Dried Fruits Research Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: which we have just discussed. We are dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: cussing 3 Bills in this debate. One makes

Speaker: NA
Text: provision for the establishment of a research

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme: the second Bill authorises the

Speaker: NA
Text: imposition of a levy for research purposes;

Speaker: NA
Text: and the third Bill deals with the machinery

Speaker: NA
Text: for the collection of that levy. The basic

Speaker: NA
Text: objective i.s for a levy to be imposed on al!

Speaker: NA
Text: pigs slaughtered for human consumption,

Speaker: NA
Text: the moneys collected to be used to finance

Speaker: NA
Text: research schemes for the benefit of the pig

Speaker: NA
Text: industry throughout Australia. Under this

Speaker: NA
Text: proposal the maximum levy will be 10c

Speaker: NA
Text: per pig slaughtered. As with other research

Speaker: NA
Text: Bills, there is an operative rate and this

Speaker: NA
Text: has been fixed by the Pig Slaughter Levy

Speaker: NA
Text: Collection Bill at 5c per pig.

Speaker: NA
Text: in his second reading speech the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for Primary Industry ( Mr Sinclair) esti-

Speaker: NA
Text: mated that approximately $150,000 to

Speaker: NA
Text: $165,000 will be collected from the levy.

Speaker: NA
Text: He also said that the Commonwealth will

Speaker: NA
Text: make matching grants on a $1 for $1 basis.

Speaker: NA
Text: In other words, the total funds available to

Speaker: NA
Text: the industry for research will be double the

Speaker: NA
Text: amount collected. The levy will be payable

Speaker: NA
Text: by abattoirs and they will, of course, be

Speaker: NA
Text: the places where the pigs are to be

Speaker: NA
Text: slaughtered. The incidence of the levy will

Speaker: NA
Text: fall on the owner of the pigs at the time

Speaker: NA
Text: of slaughter. The pig industry is another

Speaker: NA
Text: industry which has joined the ranks of

Speaker: NA
Text: research. At the present time it is estimated

Speaker: NA
Text: that approximately 70 per cent of the total

Speaker: NA
Text: value of primary production or rural pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duction in Australia-an d this includes the

Speaker: NA
Text: pig industry-i s actually covered by pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: ducers who are making payments for the

Speaker: NA
Text: purposes of research. Therefore we have

Speaker: NA
Text: self-help which is backed by Federal

Speaker: NA
Text: finance. The Minister has informed us that

Speaker: NA
Text: the request for research arose through the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Commercial Pig Producers

Speaker: NA
Text: Federation which is the Federal organisation

Speaker: NA
Text: of thc pig industry. The Federation consists

Speaker: NA
Text: of 6 State councils which represent the

Speaker: NA
Text: great majority, as the Minister has said,

Speaker: NA
Text: of the pig farmers in Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Minister said that the ACPPF speaks

Speaker: NA
Text: with a national voice. He implied that all

Speaker: NA
Text: pig bodies are represented. This, ot course,

Speaker: NA
Text: is not strictly true. The Minister's second

Speaker: NA
Text: reading speech implied that the decision to

Speaker: NA
Text: implement a research scheme was a unani-

Speaker: NA
Text: mous one. From reading the Minister's

Speaker: NA
Text: second reading speech one gains the

Speaker: NA
Text: impression that the Federal body speaks

Speaker: NA
Text: with a national voice and it could be in-

Speaker: NA
Text: ferred that the whole of the industry was

Speaker: NA
Text: behind it. However, the pig committee of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Victorian Farmers Union does not agree

Speaker: NA
Text: with the proposition which is before the

Speaker: NA
Text: House. Also, the Australian Primary Pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: ducers Union pig committee in Queensland

Speaker: NA
Text: does not agree. I believe that the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: should have stated this in his second read-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing speech. It is desirable that, if possible,

Speaker: NA
Text: all organisations of a particular industry

Speaker: NA
Text: should be within a Federal body. I have

Speaker: NA
Text: always argued in this House that it is far

Speaker: NA
Text: better to speak with one voice than to speak

Speaker: NA
Text: with a divided voice.

Speaker: NA
Text: A delegation from the pig committee of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Victorian Farmers Union saw members

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Opposition and expressed the opinion

Speaker: NA
Text: to us that they would first of all like to

Speaker: NA
Text: see a referendum before legislation for a

Speaker: NA
Text: compulsory levy was introduced in this

Speaker: NA
Text: House. The delegation informed members

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Opposition that there was a signifi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cant difference of opinion on this issue

Speaker: NA
Text: within the industry throughout Australia. I

Speaker: NA
Text: made it clear to members of the delegation

Speaker: NA
Text: th^t if they could prove this and if in fact

Speaker: NA
Text: there was a considerable difference of

Speaker: NA
Text: opinion and widespread opposition to a levy

Speaker: NA
Text: for research in the pig industry the Opposi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion would take a responsible attitude and

Speaker: NA
Text: raise this question with the Government in

Speaker: NA
Text: the Parliament. The policy of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor Party is quite clear: If there is evi-

Speaker: NA
Text: dence of widespread opposition from the

Speaker: NA
Text: rank and file pig producers, we believe a

Speaker: NA
Text: referendum should be held.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let me summarise the policy of the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian Labor Party in respect of such a

Speaker: NA
Text: compulsory levy. If an industry asks for

Speaker: NA
Text: research and if a government believes that

Speaker: NA
Text: this research is in the best interests of the

Speaker: NA
Text: industrj' and the nation-an d this includes

Speaker: NA
Text: the consumers-tha t research levy should

Speaker: NA
Text: be implemented. Tn other words, if there

Speaker: NA
Text: is a unanimous decision within the industry

Speaker: NA
Text: and if the Government believes that such a

Speaker: NA
Text: levy is in the best interests of the nation

Speaker: NA
Text: and the industry, measures to effect it

Speaker: NA
Text: should be implemented. In this case, if

Speaker: NA
Text: there is uncertainty to the degree that there

Speaker: NA
Text: is a wide difference of opinion and open

Speaker: NA
Text: opposition among the rank and file pig pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: ducers, newspapers, delegations, parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: mentary representatives and so on, of

Speaker: NA
Text: course producers should have the right to

Speaker: NA
Text: express that opinion through a referendum.

Speaker: NA
Text: As an example, we can recall that some

Speaker: NA
Text: years ago a price reserve scheme was pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: posed for wool, although this was not a

Speaker: NA
Text: compulsory levy. Just recently we had a

Speaker: NA
Text: stabilisation scheme proposal for the dried

Speaker: NA
Text: vine fruits industry. Also, we hoped that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government would allow a referendum

Speaker: NA
Text: because of the widespread opposition to the

Speaker: NA
Text: lifting of the embargo of merino sheep.

Speaker: NA
Text: There has been wide opposition to all of

Speaker: NA
Text: these schemes. There has been wide opposi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion to the degree that members of Parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment received constant delegations from the

Speaker: NA
Text: rank and file primary producers and a crosswould

Speaker: NA
Text: section of the community. There was a

Speaker: NA
Text: definite case for a referendum. The Pig

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee of the Victorian Farmers Union

Speaker: NA
Text: has made it clear to us in writing that its

Speaker: NA
Text: pig producers are not opposed to research

Speaker: NA
Text: or a levy for research purposes. It seems

Speaker: NA
Text: tbat what they are basically opposed to is

Speaker: NA
Text: the way in which research moneys are

Speaker: NA
Text: allocated. They question the priorities on

Speaker: NA
Text: which research funds are allocated.

Speaker: NA
Text: The main point I am making here is that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition has given very careful con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sideration to whether or not it should

Speaker: NA
Text: move an amendment to defer this legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: until a referendum has been held. After

Speaker: NA
Text: careful consideration and consultation we

Speaker: NA
Text: came to the conclusion that this would not

Speaker: NA
Text: be fair unless we received evidence of

Speaker: NA
Text: spread opposition from pig producers them-

Speaker: NA
Text: selves. To be quite fair, despite previous

Speaker: NA
Text: concern and the possible need for a referenthe

Speaker: NA
Text: dum, we have not had this widespread

Speaker: NA
Text: opposition to the imposition of a research

Speaker: NA
Text: levy- I stress the term 'the imposition of a

Speaker: NA
Text: research levy' as distinct from the value

Speaker: NA
Text: of research or the allocation of research

Speaker: NA
Text: funds. I wish to say forcefully to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister that if there is evidence of wide- to Japan.

Speaker: NA
Text: spread opposition from the rank and file

Speaker: NA
Text: pig producers to the payment of the levy

Speaker: NA
Text: for research then a referendum should be

Speaker: NA
Text: held. But the Opposition has not received

Speaker: NA
Text: any factual evidence of widespread opposi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion from pig producers to research or to

Speaker: NA
Text: levy as distinct from the distribution crr

Speaker: NA
Text: allocation of funds for research and the

Speaker: NA
Text: priorities for research.

Speaker: NA
Text: I wish to make that clear, because when

Speaker: NA
Text: the Pig Committee of the Victorian

Speaker: NA
Text: Farmers Union first discussed the matter

Speaker: NA
Text: with us I must admit I was quite con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cerned, as I thought there was widespread

Speaker: NA
Text: opposition to the levy from the commercial

Speaker: NA
Text: pig producers of Australia. I conferred at

Speaker: NA
Text: some length with members of the Opposi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion and others to see if pig producers had

Speaker: NA
Text: come to Canberra and expressed their

Speaker: NA
Text: opposition to the levy. The Opposition will

Speaker: NA
Text: always move for referenda if it believes

Speaker: NA
Text: there is a case for them and particularly

Speaker: NA
Text: if there is controversy or opposition on a

Speaker: NA
Text: widespread basis or if it believes that the

Speaker: NA
Text: research is not in the best interests of the

Speaker: NA
Text: nation. I do not think that anybody in this

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament or any of the pig producers

Speaker: NA
Text: argue that research is not warranted

Speaker: NA
Text: at this point of time. However, the question

Speaker: NA
Text: is one of the evaluation of research. That

Speaker: NA
Text: is a different proposition.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Federal Pig Committee of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Victorian Farmers' Federation has

Speaker: NA
Text: expressed grave concern at the way research

Speaker: NA
Text: projects are frequently determined. Some

Speaker: NA
Text: criticism is made of the priorities and the

Speaker: NA
Text: benefits of particular research projects. As

Speaker: NA
Text: T mentioned in thc debate on the last Bill,

Speaker: NA
Text: there is some validity in this concern. I

Speaker: NA
Text: believe that there should be an annual

Speaker: NA
Text: evaluation of research funds to see whether

Speaker: NA
Text: they are being used to achieve the optimum

Speaker: NA
Text: benefits for the industry and for the nation

Speaker: NA
Text: as a whole. The pig industry in Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: has scope for expansion, but not as great

Speaker: NA
Text: widean expansion as many people would like.

Speaker: NA
Text: Some people believe that we have a great

Speaker: NA
Text: potential for increased pig production for

Speaker: NA
Text: export market. Before the war approxi-

Speaker: NA
Text: mately 15,000 tons of pig meats were

Speaker: NA
Text: exported each year. At the end of the war

Speaker: NA
Text: about 3,000 tons a year were exported.

Speaker: NA
Text: Since then there has been a slight surplus.

Speaker: NA
Text: In very recent years this has been increased

Speaker: NA
Text: to some degree with considerable exports

Speaker: NA
Text: The 2 major markets on the Continent-

Speaker: NA
Text: United Kingdom and the European

Speaker: NA
Text: Economic Community countries-ar e the

Speaker: NA
Text: biggest importers of pig meats in the world,

Speaker: NA
Text: the but these 2 markets are the most difficult

Speaker: NA
Text: for Australia to break into. The United

Speaker: NA
Text: Kingdom imports principally cured pig

Speaker: NA
Text: meats from Denmark, Poland and Ireland.

Speaker: NA
Text: The principal Common Market countries

Speaker: NA
Text: which import pork are France, West Ger-

Speaker: NA
Text: many and Italy. These are supplied by the

Speaker: NA
Text: European Economic Community countries

Speaker: NA
Text: themselves. As we are now more familiar

Speaker: NA
Text: with the common agricultural policy of

Speaker: NA
Text: the European Economic Community we

Speaker: NA
Text: know that it is virtually a free trade area

Speaker: NA
Text: in itself with a huge protective barrier

Speaker: NA
Text: around it inhibiting imports from countries

Speaker: NA
Text: not in the Common Market. This makes

Speaker: NA
Text: it most difficult for Australia to break into

Speaker: NA
Text: the 2 main traditional markets, the United

Speaker: NA
Text: Kingdom and Europe. It wilt be difficult

Speaker: NA
Text: to increase our exports to those 2 markets.

Speaker: NA
Text: The only other area which appears to offer

Speaker: NA
Text: prospects for increased exports of pig

Speaker: NA
Text: meats is Asia. One example is Hong Kong.

Speaker: NA
Text: We must realise that China is an

Speaker: NA
Text: important country as far as pig production

Speaker: NA
Text: is concerned. China has the capacity to

Speaker: NA
Text: swamp any Asian market of any conse-

Speaker: NA
Text: quence.

Speaker: NA
Text: Perhaps one of the best markets in the

Speaker: NA
Text: future will be Japan. If we handle the pig

Speaker: NA
Text: situation constructively Japan could

Speaker: NA
Text: emerge as a major importer of pig meats.

Speaker: NA
Text: The best market for pig meats is obviously

Speaker: NA
Text: our own domestic market. 1 would sound

Speaker: NA
Text: this note of warning about research into

Speaker: NA
Text: meats. There is a fairly stable aggregate

Speaker: NA
Text: demand for meat per capita. If one adds

Speaker: NA
Text: together the total consumption of beef, veal,

Speaker: NA
Text: mutton, lamb, poultry and pig meats one

Speaker: NA
Text: gets a fairly stable aggregate which is

Speaker: NA
Text: about 220 lbs of meat per annum. In the

Speaker: NA
Text: last 20 years or so the aggregate has varied

Speaker: NA
Text: around that figure. It is a fairly stable

Speaker: NA
Text: aggregate per capita per annum. Where the

Speaker: NA
Text: big change takes place is between meats.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have to be very careful about doing a

Speaker: NA
Text: lot of research and promotion in one of

Speaker: NA
Text: the meat industries. We could increase the

Speaker: NA
Text: domestic consumption of, say, pig meats

Speaker: NA
Text: at the expense of other meats. One could

Speaker: NA
Text: legitimately say: 'So what?' After all, pigs

Speaker: NA
Text: are competing with beef, lamb and so forth.

Speaker: NA
Text: It might be a good thing to reduce the con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sumption of beef and increase the con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sumption of pig meats at a time when we

Speaker: NA
Text: could sell all our beef on the export

Speaker: NA
Text: market and therefore gain a greater amount

Speaker: NA
Text: of export earnings. There is some logic in

Speaker: NA
Text: that.

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to warn the Government that

Speaker: NA
Text: we have to be very careful in the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: motion of meats. We are not going to

Speaker: NA
Text: get more people to eat more meat in the

Speaker: NA
Text: aggregate. It would simply mean that we

Speaker: NA
Text: would be spending a lot more money in

Speaker: NA
Text: the various research and promotion fields

Speaker: NA
Text: to get more people to change their dietary

Speaker: NA
Text: habits. One could then argue that it is a

Speaker: NA
Text: waste of resources simply to change from

Speaker: NA
Text: one to the other. The only people who

Speaker: NA
Text: would really benefit would be the adverti-

Speaker: NA
Text: sing companies. There has been a marked

Speaker: NA
Text: change in the dietary habits of Australians

Speaker: NA
Text: with respect to pig meats. In 1950 the

Speaker: NA
Text: consumption per head per annum of car-

Speaker: NA
Text: cass pig meats was approximately 7 Ibs At

Speaker: NA
Text: the present time it is about 20 Ibs. So there

Speaker: NA
Text: has been a significant increase in the'con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sumption per head and total consumption.

Speaker: NA
Text: On the other hand, the compensating

Speaker: NA
Text: factor has been a fall in beef and veal

Speaker: NA
Text: consumption. In 1950 the consumption per

Speaker: NA
Text: head of beef and veal was 124 Ib. This

Speaker: NA
Text: has fallen to about 90 Ib per head. So

Speaker: NA
Text: there has been a marked increase in the

Speaker: NA
Text: consumption of pig meats and a marked

Speaker: NA
Text: decrease in the consumption of beef. As

Speaker: NA
Text: I said before, there is nothing wrong with

Speaker: NA
Text: this provided that we can sell all our beef,

Speaker: NA
Text: which we have been able to do, and pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vided that the export market is as good as

Speaker: NA
Text: the domestic market.

Speaker: NA
Text: It would seem that there is considerable

Speaker: NA
Text: scope in Australia, however, for increased

Speaker: NA
Text: consumption of pig meats. 1 mentioned

Speaker: NA
Text: before that, taking bacon into account, the

Speaker: NA
Text: total consumption of pig meat per head in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia is 20 Ib to 25 Ib per annum.

Speaker: NA
Text: When we compare this with consumption

Speaker: NA
Text: in the United States of America, which "s

Speaker: NA
Text: approximately 65 lb per head per annum,

Speaker: NA
Text: we see that there is considerable scope for

Speaker: NA
Text: an increase in the consumption of pig

Speaker: NA
Text: meats in Australia. In European countries

Speaker: NA
Text: the consumption is as high as 85 lb per

Speaker: NA
Text: head per annum. So if Australia follows the

Speaker: NA
Text: pattern of other developed countries such

Speaker: NA
Text: as the United States, the United Kingdom

Speaker: NA
Text: and the continental countries, we can ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: pect to see a steady increase in the con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sumption of pig meats in Australia. There

Speaker: NA
Text: are several factors which will bring this

Speaker: NA
Text: about. One relates to the dietary habits of

Speaker: NA
Text: people. Since the War we have had an in-

Speaker: NA
Text: flux of migrants, who are perhaps more

Speaker: NA
Text: prone 10 eat pork than are Australians.

Speaker: NA
Text: There has been an increase in the quality

Speaker: NA
Text: of pig meat and more housewives are order-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing and cooking roast pork, pork chops and

Speaker: NA
Text: so on. than before.

Speaker: NA
Text: Another factor is the price of feed grains.

Speaker: NA
Text: The pig industry is peculiar in that it is

Speaker: NA
Text: one of the few industries in Australia in

Speaker: NA
Text: which there has not been a significant

Speaker: NA
Text: increase in the cost of production because

Speaker: NA
Text: 70 per cent to 80 per cent of the cash

Speaker: NA
Text: costs of production of pigs are feed costs.

Speaker: NA
Text: As there has been a tremendous change in

Speaker: NA
Text: the pattern of production, from the tradi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional by-products of the dairy industry to

Speaker: NA
Text: grains, one sees that this is an industry

Speaker: NA
Text: in which considerable savings can be

Speaker: NA
Text: effected. It is one of the few industries in

Speaker: NA
Text: which there has not been a significant

Speaker: NA
Text: increase in costs of production because the

Speaker: NA
Text: price of feed grains has not increased at

Speaker: NA
Text: the same rate as the price of other feed

Speaker: NA
Text: stocks which contribute to the costs of

Speaker: NA
Text: production in other industries. Another

Speaker: NA
Text: factor affecting the consumption of pig

Speaker: NA
Text: meats is Australia is the lower price

Speaker: NA
Text: relatively for skim milk. So, taken by and

Speaker: NA
Text: large, there is a climate for a steady

Speaker: NA
Text: increase in the annual per capita consump-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of pig meats in Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: What types of pig research are needed?

Speaker: NA
Text: The Victorian Farmers Union, whose

Speaker: NA
Text: representatives saw us, has put forward

Speaker: NA
Text: some constructive views on the types of

Speaker: NA
Text: research that are needed and what priori-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties they should be given. But looking at

Speaker: NA
Text: the problem of ihe pig industry in Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia as a whole and what we know from

Speaker: NA
Text: past experience, it is quite obvious that the

Speaker: NA
Text: productive efficiency of piggeries is rela-

Speaker: NA
Text: tively poor compared with overseas

Speaker: NA
Text: standards. Therefore we have those

Speaker: NA
Text: standards as a goal. This does not mean

Speaker: NA
Text: thai we will reach overnight the very high

Speaker: NA
Text: standards of productive efficiency in, say,

Speaker: NA
Text: Denmark, the Netherlands or parts of the

Speaker: NA
Text: United States, but it does allow us to have

Speaker: NA
Text: a goal which we can aim to achieve over

Speaker: NA
Text: a period of time. Research work already

Speaker: NA
Text: shows that each sow has approximately

Speaker: NA
Text: 1.5 litters annually. The number of pig-

Speaker: NA
Text: lets born each year can obviously be

Speaker: NA
Text: increased significantly.

Speaker: NA
Text: One of the most important avenues of

Speaker: NA
Text: fundamental and applied research in the pig

Speaker: NA
Text: industry is in regard to disease. I think

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia has made tremendous advances

Speaker: NA
Text: in this field in recent years. As I said be-

Speaker: NA
Text: fore, there has been a marked change in

Speaker: NA
Text: the pattern of pig production in Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: In fact 'pig' used to be a dirty word. We

Speaker: NA
Text: used to think of pigs being raised in a

Speaker: NA
Text: pigsty, and the pigsty was regarded as a

Speaker: NA
Text: place to be avoided if possible. Today pigs

Speaker: NA
Text: are raised on grain in immaculately kept

Speaker: NA
Text: piggeries in some parts of Australia. In

Speaker: NA
Text: fact the mating and farrowing facilities for

Speaker: NA
Text: some pigs are better than the housing of

Speaker: NA
Text: some humans. This is good. After all why

Speaker: NA
Text: should they not have decent housing? As

Speaker: NA
Text: has been shown in America, one of the

Speaker: NA
Text: most significant variables in relation to

Speaker: NA
Text: mortality is inefficient mating and farrow-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing facilities. I am. very pleased to see

Speaker: NA
Text: that the commercial pig owners are now

Speaker: NA
Text: devoting a great deal of attention to im-

Speaker: NA
Text: proving facilities for management and hus-

Speaker: NA
Text: bandry based on principles which they

Speaker: NA
Text: know to be correct because they have

Speaker: NA
Text: been proven in other countries as well as

Speaker: NA
Text: in Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is a great need for research into

Speaker: NA
Text: feeding. As I said before, 70 per cent to

Speaker: NA
Text: 80 per cent of costs of pig meat produc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion are in the feeding. 1 was amazed,

Speaker: NA
Text: when 1 studied in America, by the tremen-

Speaker: NA
Text: dous commercial efficiency of pig pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: ducers in the Mid-West. In fact most of

Speaker: NA
Text: their feeding programmes are worked out

Speaker: NA
Text: by computers. The best mixes and most of

Speaker: NA
Text: their profit variables in relation to those

Speaker: NA
Text: mixes are worked out by computers. The

Speaker: NA
Text: information is fed into the computers at

Speaker: NA
Text: the Universities of Iowa and Illinois. A

Speaker: NA
Text: farmer might ring up and say: 'What is the

Speaker: NA
Text: best mix to use under present prices?' He

Speaker: NA
Text: would get an answer within a matter of

Speaker: NA
Text: hours. It might include all the protein

Speaker: NA
Text: values, whatever it might be, but those cost

Speaker: NA
Text: facilities were there. This illustrates that

Speaker: NA
Text: there is considerable scope for feeding

Speaker: NA
Text: research in Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: Another avenue of research is breeding

Speaker: NA
Text: stock and culling. In the area of north

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland that I represent there must be

Speaker: NA
Text: some of the worst pigs in Australia. Most

Speaker: NA
Text: of them seem to be half wild or wild pigs.

Speaker: NA
Text: In fact if a person wants to get a pig for

Speaker: NA
Text: his lunch he goes out into the bush and

Speaker: NA
Text: spends a few hours finding one and catch-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing it. I can tell honourable members that

Speaker: NA
Text: they are pretty tough to eat.

Speaker: Mr SINCLAIR
Text: A s Mrs Beeton says, first

Speaker: NA
Text: catch your hare.

Speaker: Dr PATTERSON
Text: Yes . Of course this

Speaker: NA
Text: is not the standard I am talking about when

Speaker: NA
Text: discussing this Bill. Certainly there has

Speaker: NA
Text: a great improvement in pig standards in

Speaker: NA
Text: recent years. Surely the principles that

Speaker: NA
Text: to animal husbandry in regard to cattle

Speaker: NA
Text: apply also to pig husbandry. We must have

Speaker: NA
Text: good breeding stock and sound animal

Speaker: NA
Text: husbandry principles in regard to culling.

Speaker: NA
Text: The objective is the same-t o get the

Speaker: NA
Text: maximum possible turnoff per annum. A

Speaker: NA
Text: man who can market 18 pigs per sow per

Speaker: NA
Text: year is financially better off than one who

Speaker: NA
Text: can market only 12.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Robinson-H e is doing pretty well.

Speaker: Dr PATTERSON
Text: 1 am quoting levels

Speaker: NA
Text: that have been achieved in Australia and

Speaker: NA
Text: Ttainly in other parts of the world. Maxi-

Speaker: NA
Text: mum turnoff and minimum mortality are

Speaker: NA
Text: matters on whicb the research people,

Speaker: NA
Text: under this Bill, will obviously give a lead

Speaker: NA
Text: been to the industry. My time is almost up. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition will move the same amendments

Speaker: NA
Text: apply and go through the same motions, though

Speaker: NA
Text: perhaps for no* as long, with regard to

Speaker: NA
Text: penalties. Here we have exactly the same

Speaker: NA
Text: amendments regarding averment and the 5

Speaker: NA
Text: year provisions relating to the commence-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of prosecutions.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr Lucock)-

Speaker: NA
Text: Order! The honourable member's time has

Speaker: NA
Text: expired.

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate (on motion by Mr Robinson)

Speaker: NA
Text: adjourned.

Speaker: NA
Text: House adjourned at 10.12 p.m.

Text: The ioi,owing answers to questions

Speaker: NA
Text: Tarifl! Board

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question Nu. 1990)

Speaker: NA
Text: D r J.  . Cairns asked the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Trade and Industry, upon notice:

Speaker: NA
Text: U) Does the Tarifl Board ignore statements on

Speaker: NA
Text: Government policy by the Prime Minister and

Speaker: NA
Text: himself.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) Has he stated that there is no way in which

Speaker: NA
Text: he can inform the Board on Government pol-

Speaker: NA
Text: icy.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) lf so, will he seek die support of the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister in lairing steps to enter into negotiations

Speaker: NA
Text: with the Board with a view to the establishment

Speaker: NA
Text: of clear and understandable guidelines to tariif

Speaker: NA
Text: policy.

Speaker: Mr ANTHONY
Text: Th e answer to the hon-

Speaker: NA
Text: ourable member's question is as follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: U) and (2) ln the House on 24th September

Speaker: NA
Text: 19h9 my predecessor as Minister for Trade and

Speaker: NA
Text: Industry said that 'there would be no precedent

Speaker: NA
Text: for the Minister responsible for the Tariff Board

Speaker: NA
Text: writing to the Board and instructing it or seeking

Speaker: NA
Text: to influence it'.

Speaker: NA
Text: Where the Government has considered i l neces-

Speaker: NA
Text: sary to inform the Tariff Board of a specific pol-

Speaker: NA
Text: icy objective when referring a particular industry

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Board this has been made clear in the

Speaker: NA
Text: terms of reference sent to the Board. In such

Speaker: NA
Text: cases thc Tariff Board has always taken the Gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment's specific objectives into account.

Speaker: NA
Text: i ' i In iis rtcem Annual Reports the Tariff

Speaker: NA
Text: Board has suggested a progressive review of the

Speaker: NA
Text: tarifl and has described the approach it proposed

Speaker: NA
Text: to apply in considering whether an industry is

Speaker: NA
Text: economic and efficient and the level of tariff it

Speaker: NA
Text: would recommend.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government has decided that there should

Speaker: NA
Text: be a progressive review of tbe tariff and that tbe

Speaker: NA
Text: principles to be observed by Ihe Tariff Board in

Speaker: NA
Text: that review, and in its normal tariff reviews,

Speaker: NA
Text: should be the subject of further examination by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 2132)

Speaker: NA
Text: D r J. F. Cairns asked the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Trade and Industry, upon notice:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) Has additional staff been sought by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Tariff Board.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) Did the Pubhc Service Board recommend

Speaker: NA
Text: the creation of additional staff positions at the

Speaker: NA
Text: beginning of June 1970.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) Was the Chairman of the Tariff Board

Speaker: NA
Text: informed that ihe matter raised important ques-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions whicb be should discuss with the Minister at

Speaker: NA
Text: the first opportunity.

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) Has the Tarifl Board stated that the

Speaker: NA
Text: resources available to it have been fully occupied

Speaker: NA
Text: on normal tariff revision, dumping and New Zea-

Speaker: NA
Text: land and Australia Free Trade Agreement inquir-

Speaker: NA
Text: ies and tbat it expects an increase in the number

Speaker: NA
Text: of by-law, dumping and NZAFTA matters.

Speaker: NA
Text: ANSWERS TOQUESTIO NS UPONNOTIC E

Speaker: NA
Text: upon notice were circulated:

Speaker: NA
Text: (5) Has he had discussions with the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for Customs and Excise about the additional staff

Speaker: NA
Text: required by the Tariff Board; if not, why not.

Speaker: NA
Text: (6) If he has had such discussions, what was

Speaker: NA
Text: the result.

Speaker: NA
Text: (7) Was the desire of the Tariif Board for more

Speaker: NA
Text: staff considered to be a matter of policy; if so,

Speaker: NA
Text: why.

Speaker: NA
Text: (8) Is il a fact that the Government does not

Speaker: NA
Text: desire the Tariff Board to obtain more staff

Speaker: NA
Text: because of the possibility lhat i l may then pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceed with inquiries into high tariff areas and

Speaker: NA
Text: embarrass ihe Government by recommendations

Speaker: NA
Text: for reductions.

Speaker: NA
Text: (9) Has it been decided that this is tbe best

Speaker: NA
Text: way lo maintain independence of the Tariif Board

Speaker: NA
Text: whilst still avoiding problems of having to deal

Speaker: NA
Text: with any recommendations it may make for tarifl

Speaker: NA
Text: reductions.

Speaker: NA
Text: (10) When does he anticipate that the Tariff

Speaker: NA
Text: Board will have sufficient staff to complete the

Speaker: NA
Text: inquiries envisaged in its reports for 1967-68,

Speaker: NA
Text: 1968-69, 1969-70 which are not yet completed or

Speaker: NA
Text: even begun.

Speaker: Mr ANTHONY
Text: Th e answer to the hon-

Speaker: NA
Text: ourable member's question is as follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) During 1970, 38 additional positions were

Speaker: NA
Text: created in thc Office of the Tariff Board. Submis-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions seeking a further 20 positions were made

Speaker: NA
Text: towards the end of ihe year and these are under

Speaker: NA
Text: consideration by the Public Service Board.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) , (3), (7), (8) and (9) On 10th and 12th June

Speaker: NA
Text: 1970, the Public Service Board recommended the

Speaker: NA
Text: creation of a number of additional positions and

Speaker: NA
Text: approved the reclassification of a number of exist-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing positions. In respect of nine of the additional

Speaker: NA
Text: positions, the Minister Assisting the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Trade and Industry in response to a letter from

Speaker: NA
Text: the Chairman of the Tariff Board advised him

Speaker: NA
Text: that the conditions under which the Public Service

Speaker: NA
Text: Board recommended creation of these positions

Speaker: NA
Text: raised important policy questions which he would

Speaker: NA
Text: discuss with the Minister for Trade and Industry

Speaker: NA
Text: who had been overseas at that time. These nine

Speaker: NA
Text: Tariff Board additional positions were sought for work in con-

Speaker: NA
Text: nection with inquiries which would form part of

Speaker: NA
Text: a progressive review of the Tariff. At that time

Speaker: NA
Text: the question of whether there would be a progres-

Speaker: NA
Text: sive review of the Tariff was under consideration

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Minister. The additional nine positions

Speaker: NA
Text: were approved by the Governor-General-in-

Speaker: NA
Text: Council on llth September 1970. The Government

Speaker: NA
Text: has since decided that there should be a progres-

Speaker: NA
Text: sive review of the Tariff and that the principles to

Speaker: NA
Text: be applied by the Tariff Board in that review and

Speaker: NA
Text: in normal tariff inquiries would be the subject of

Speaker: NA
Text: further examination by the Government.

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) The Tariff Board stated in its Annual

Speaker: NA
Text: Report for 1969-70 that the resources available to

Speaker: NA
Text: it had been fully occupied on normal tariff revi-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion inquiries (including inquiries on some sec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions of chapter 84 of the Tariff) and dumping

Speaker: NA
Text: and NZAFTA inquiries. The Board also stated in

Speaker: NA
Text: its 1969-70 Annual Report that the Minister had

Speaker: NA
Text: recently informed the Board that he expected a

Speaker: NA
Text: significant increase in the number of by-law

Speaker: NA
Text: dumping and NZAFTA matters referred to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Board.

Speaker: NA
Text: (S) and (6) Ministerial responsibility for the

Speaker: NA
Text: staffing of the Office of the Tariff Board rests

Speaker: NA
Text: with the Minister for Trade and Industry.

Text: (Question No. 2133)

Speaker: NA
Text: D r J. F . Cairns asked the Minister f o r

Speaker: NA
Text: Trade and Industry:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) Did the Tariff Board in 1966-67 propose a

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Board of the structure and levels of protection in

Speaker: NA
Text: the tariff, together with public inquiries into the

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: no recent public inquiry and where the levels of

Speaker: NA
Text: protection were in the medium to high range.

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: review and what public inquiries has the Board

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: the levels of protection are in the medium to high

Speaker: NA
Text: range.

Speaker: NA
Text: which have (a) a high level of protection, (b) a

Speaker: NA
Text: medium level of protection and (c) a low level of

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: the likely effects on other industries and their

Speaker: NA
Text: prospects for more competitive production.

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Text: Defence: F l l l CA i r c r a ft

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 2541)

Speaker: Mr LES JOHNSON
Text: the Minister f o r

Speaker: NA
Text: appreciation Defence, upon notice:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) Is it a fact that due to poor operating

Speaker: NA
Text: capabilities and escalating costs, production of the

Speaker: NA
Text: F l l l -C fighter-bomber will end next year?

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) If so, what changes have been made or will

Speaker: NA
Text: be made to the Australian order?

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Gorton-Th e answer to the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member's question is as follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) At present the production of F - I ll aircraft

Speaker: NA
Text: is scheduled to continue until July 1972 when a

Speaker: NA
Text: total of 540 aircraft, including two F - l l l Ks origi-

Speaker: NA
Text: nally intended for the United Kingdom, will have

Speaker: NA
Text: been manufactured. The Australian Government is

Speaker: NA
Text: not aware of the extent lo which funds will be

Speaker: NA
Text: made available for further, if any, aircraft by the

Speaker: NA
Text: United States Government, or of any reduction in

Speaker: NA
Text: funds. Consequently I am not in a position to

Speaker: NA
Text: advise when production might cease.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) No changes have been made to the order

Speaker: NA
Text: for the 24 F-111C aircraft. These aircraft have all

Speaker: NA
Text: been manufactured, but, in accordance with the

Speaker: NA
Text: Agreement dated 14th April, 1970 Mr Fraser

Speaker: NA
Text: signed with Mr Laird, United States Secretary of

Speaker: NA
Text: Defence, will not be accepted until they achieve

Speaker: NA
Text: certain specified technical and operational criteria.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Woo l Industry Conference

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 2686)

Speaker: NA
Text: D r Patterson asked the Minister f o r

Speaker: NA
Text: Primary Industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) Does he, like his predecessor, the present

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Trade and Industry, recognise the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Wool Industry Conference as being

Speaker: NA
Text: fully qualified to speak on behalf of the wool

Speaker: NA
Text: growers of Australia and with the full backing of

Speaker: NA
Text: the wool industry in general.

Speaker: Mr SINCLAIR
Text: Th e answer to the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member's question is as follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: The Australian Wool Industry Conference was

Speaker: NA
Text: established by the two federal woolgrower organis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ations in Australia, the Australian Woolgrowers'

Speaker: NA
Text: and Graziers Council and the Australian Wool

Speaker: NA
Text: and Meat Producers Federation.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Conference comprises 25 members each

Speaker: NA
Text: from the Council and the Federation and an inde-

Speaker: NA
Text: pendent Chairman.

Speaker: NA
Text: Since the Conference is representative of both

Speaker: NA
Text: federal woolgrower organisations I feel that it can

Speaker: NA
Text: reasonably claim to be qualified to speak on

Speaker: NA
Text: behalf of woolgrowers.

Speaker: NA
Text: Defence: F l l l CA i r c r a ft

Text: (Question No. 2723)

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Barnard asked the Minister f o r

Speaker: NA
Text: Defence, upon notice:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) How many F l l l C aircraft were accepted by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Government?

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) How many of these aircraft were returned

Speaker: NA
Text: on loan to the United States Air Force?

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Gorton-Th e answer to the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member's question is as follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: ' ) One aircraft was accepted on behalf of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Government on 4th September 1968,

Speaker: NA
Text: but because of difficulties with the wing carry

Speaker: NA
Text: through box the aircraft was placed in storage.

Speaker: NA
Text: The 24 F l l l C aircraft ordered by the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Government, including the one referred to above,

Speaker: NA
Text: have been manufactured. However in accordance

Speaker: NA
Text: with the agreement signed with Mr Laird, United

Speaker: NA
Text: States Secretary of Defense, on 14th April 1970,

Speaker: NA
Text: the aircraft will not be accepted by the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Government until they achieve certain specified

Speaker: NA
Text: technical and operational criteria.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) No F l l l C aircraft have been returned on

Speaker: NA
Text: loan to the United States Air Force.

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Text: ernment Printer, up to 60 copies of any speech

Text: he makes and a question addressed to him and

Speaker: NA
Text: his answer thereto.

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of the Parliamentary Reporting Staff under

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: binding".

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Text: liament House, his Department or any other

Speaker: NA
Text: address nominated by him.'

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: copies, usually in duplicated form, are prepared in

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister's oflice or in the Department and

Speaker: NA
Text: their cost is borne by the Departments concerned.

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
